more entrenched in their poverty and more marginalized from partaking in
increasingly global markets. n3 Both in the United States and abroad, there are
development communities n4 that focus on fixing this problem by attempting to
boost participation by the poor in the market, and often by implication, in
mainstream n5 society. n6 These communities have identified at least three more
[*219]  specific structural problems that impede their task. I describe these
problems as: 1) market failure in those markets that are accessible to the poor;
2) lack of formal participation by the poor in markets that do function; and 3)
the absence of indigenous values in potential solutions to the first two
problems, which prevents such solutions from "sticking" in the target
populations. n7

   Bangladesh appears to be part of the solution to the aforementioned
structural problems. Presently, there is a growing momentum behind the notion
that the particular model of microlending n8 developed by the Grameen Bank in
Bangladesh might - literally - eliminate the universal problem of entrenched
poverty. Formed in 1976, the Grameen Bank's mission is to lend to those whose
needs are not met by commercial lenders; thus, the Bank's borrowers are
primarily the landless poor, who represent approximately fifty percent of
Bangladesh's population. n9 The Bank makes tiny loans of between  [*220]  ten
and fifty U.S. dollars to help borrowers start their own microenterprises. n10
The Bank claims that these loans are not acts of charity, but rather fill a gap
in the market. n11

   Politicians, the popular press, and development communities here and abroad
have converged on three particular characteristics of the Grameen Bank's model
that appear to be the secret to the Bank's success. The first is a device called
a "solidarity circle," which serves as a replacement for physical collateral.
n12 Grameen Bank loans require borrowers to form groups of five. n13 The Bank
will only loan money at first to two members of the circle. n14 Each member of
the circle, however, must guarantee repayment of those two loans to the Bank.
n15 Only after those two borrowers establish a successful repayment record will
the Bank lend successively to the other members of the solidarity circle. n16
The peer pressure that circle members impose on each other is the collateral for
the loans. The second characteristic is the Bank's requirement that borrowers
comply with a borrower-generated agenda for social development called the
"Sixteen Decisions," n17 which directs borrowers to refrain from such socially
unhealthy behaviors as giving and receiving dowry, defecating in open fields,
and having too many children. n18 The third characteristic is the Bank's focus
on women, who make up ninety-five percent of its borrowers. n19 The particular
appeal of this combination of features to politicians and the popular press
appears to be the promise of a short-term infusion of capital to solve a problem
that had previously been addressed by welfare and other long-term "maintenance"
strategies. n20

   Politicians and the media are not alone in their praise of microcredit.
Development communities both here and abroad are also enchanted. Indeed, the
last decade has witnessed hundreds of attempts to replicate some form of the
Bank's model in the United States. n21 I posit that this fascination is aroused
[*221]  by the Western n22 development community's assumptions that the three
key features of the Bank's model solve the three structural problems that have
plagued its attempts to integrate the poor into the market. For example,
development thinkers see the solidarity circle as closing the information gap
between commercial lenders and impoverished borrowers with no credit record or
collateral by making the borrowers, who typically know each other, vouch for
each other's creditworthiness. n23 Additionally, the solidarity circle
incorporates indigenous values by using those very values as a basis for
pressuring fellow borrowers within the circle to repay their loans. n24 My
analysis challenges these assumptions.

   Specifically, I argue that, partly because the information we have about the
model is more myth than fact, the development community in the United States has
reached unsupportable and false conclusions about the model's ability to solve
market failure, increase participation by the poor in functioning markets, and
incorporate indigenous values. In reality, the solidarity circle and the other
key features of the model fail to eliminate the informational and other problems
that contribute to market failure in poor communities, arguably leaving the poor
with even fewer resources to sell their products or services. And, far from
teaching the poor the values necessary to participate in mainstream markets, the
three key features of the model encourage the poor to engage in informal
behaviors that have the opposite effect.

   But it is the model's failure to solve the third problem that should inspire
the Western development community to reassess its most basic assumptions about
the development process. I argue that the indigenousness that the Grameen Bank
appears to have captured, an indigenousness that the Bank claims causes its
program to "stick" with its target population, is a facade. The more chilling
reality is that those features of the Grameen Bank that are so attractive to the
development community in the West are largely a reflection of Western values,
which had previously been exported around the world. Thus, the indigenousness
that the Western development community perceives is in fact what I describe as a
more dubious hybridity that fails to incorporate the true values of the target
population. The implications of this hybridity ought to give us pause as we
consider the pros and cons of the Grameen Bank model. This discovery should also
require us to confront the extent to which the West's increasing market
dominance redefines the struggle for cultural integrity and economic survival at
the most local level.

   I begin in Part I by reflecting upon why U.S. observers of the Grameen Bank
are so attracted to its model. I focus on the Grameen Bank because its model is
emblematic of the programs that people in this country are interested in
replicating and because it implicates the most prominent issues and goals of
microlending. In this Part, I also describe the microcredit movement in the
[*222]  United States, which, despite a decade of hard work, has failed in some
important respects. In many respects, the rest of the Article diagnoses the
failure. In Part II, I begin to unpack the myths surrounding the model by
analyzing important differences between the Grameen Bank and the Western
development community in their conceptions of two foundational concepts: the
question of how to measure success in alleviating poverty and the notion of
operative markets. I argue that the Bank's understanding of these two concepts
is so different from our Western understanding that our perspective on the
Bank's goals and methodologies is fundamentally distorted. In Part III, I
explore the images of the Grameen Bank that have found their way into the
Western media and question whether they accurately reflect the functioning,
effects, and successes of the Bank. I conclude that, in important respects, they
do not. In Parts II and III, I draw upon empirical studies of the Grameen Bank
and of its transferability to the United States. I focus primarily on those
aspects of the Bank's methodology that have intrigued those in the United States
who have contemplated that migration: the solidarity circle device, the Sixteen
Decisions, and the use of women as lending targets. n25

   In Part IV, I examine whether the Bank's model solves the three structural
problems that challenge development communities as they seek to integrate the
poor into the market. I argue that the lessons to be learned from the Bank's
experiment are not what the Western development community might have hoped. I
conclude in Parts V and VI with a discussion of the implications of using a
hybrid model such as the Grameen Bank's version of microcredit. I argue that the
Bank's adoption of ostensibly indigenous values and mores that look so
intrinsically similar to Western values and mores should raise a cautionary
flag. In addition, I provide some thoughts about how we might achieve a better
model for economic development in the inner cities, in part by developing a more
nuanced approach. In doing so, I suggest that the particular choice of
microcredit as a model might not be the right one. Although my focus in this
Article is to analyze the model's ability to meet the goals that the development
community has identified as important, in Part VI, I also address more directly
another fundamental question in development: whether credit, or capital
development, or similar economic development criteria are as indispensable to
development as Western development communities assume.

   In my assessment, I hope to draw attention to the question of how the law
supports, and whether it should support, the market-based strategy of
microcredit financing. The law's involvement is important not only for the
reasons described so effectively by the Law and Development movement: that the
rule of law is itself a strategy of development. n26 Nor is it important only
for the reasons described by critical legal theorists: that law underlies, often
only implicitly, our notions of rights and social relations. n27 Law's
involvement also  [*223]  is important for practitioners - the ones responsible
both for crafting and teaching the rules of participation to low-income
individuals in microcredit programs and for enforcing the rights and
responsibilities of the participants. Said another way, this Article considers
the role of practitioners as they attempt to practice "transactional law" on
behalf of the poor.

   I. Why the Grameen Bank Model?

   A. An Apparent Match in Values

 Many have identified the Grameen Bank as a promising model for poverty
reduction in the United States, including Republican and Democratic politicians,
n28 feminist scholars and organizations, n29 and a number of scholars and
practitioners in the Community Economic Development ("CED") movement. n30 The
particular appeal of the Grameen Bank model in the United  [*224]  States is its
apparently successful use of microcredit as a means of creating permanent jobs
n31 in the form of microenterprises. n32

   Through no fault of our own, however, the picture that we have of the Grameen
Bank is a limited, and rosy, one. First, we view the Grameen Bank as a
non-profit organization n33 that acts like a for-profit institution.
Specifically, although the Bank provides financial services to an impoverished,
rural population, largely composed of women, it does not do so as an act of
charity. n34 Rather, the Bank behaves exactly as any other commercial lender
behaves, but on a smaller scale, hence the term microlender. n35 Moreover, many
in the West admire the claim that the Bank has the potential to make a profit
from microlending alone, without aid of foundation or government support. n36

    [*225]  The Bank's use of a "solidarity circle" or peer lending approach
also elicits admiration. n37 As stated previously, the Bank requires borrowers,
as a condition of receiving a loan, to form groups of five members. Upon
formation of a solidarity circle, only two borrowers in the circle receive a
loan. Each member of the circle must guarantee repayment of the two loans. After
the initial borrowers, with the help of the circle if need be, establish a
successful record of repayment, another one or two borrowers in the circle get a
loan until every member of the circle has received a loan - each of which is
guaranteed by all the other circle members. n38 By leaving the task of enforcing
loan terms to circle members, who, of course, do not want to have to make
payments for delinquent borrowers within the circle nor to lose access to their
own source of credit, the Bank takes advantage of informal peer pressure to
ensure repayment of its loans. Moreover, even if peer pressure fails to produce
repayment by the delinquent borrower, the Bank has four guarantors from whom to
seek repayment.

   The use of a solidarity circle not only addresses the lending conundrum of a
lack of physical collateral for loans; it also reduces the Bank's costs of
lending by effectively leaving to the borrowers in the circle the task of
determining whether each individual borrower is a good credit risk. n39 This
[*226]  system appears to have the added benefit of developing borrowers'
business judgment by teaching them to evaluate whether a given business proposal
is likely enough to be successful to be worth risking their own money as
guarantors. n40 The success of the solidarity circle may depend also upon the
potential for future credit. Borrowers tend to remain in the circle even after a
complete round of loans is given because of the likelihood of obtaining
additional loans from the Bank. n41

   To some members of the development community, the solidarity circle is also
attractive because it appears to capture an indigenous lending device. n42
Specifically, lending circles commonly known as "rotating credit associations"
(or RCAs) have existed in marginalized communities around the world for
centuries. n43 The RCAs typically function by pooling money from a circle of
contributors and then lending the larger pooled amount successively to members
of the circle. n44 In this respect, they are strikingly similar to the
solidarity circle. Moreover, the solidarity circle appears to be a superior
refinement of the RCA model because it seeks ultimately to bring borrowers into
the mainstream credit market (and other mainstream markets). n45

    [*227]  A third attractive feature is the Grameen Bank's social development
effort. It takes the form of a sixteen point list of behaviors, called the
Sixteen Decisions, that the Bank requires borrowers to memorize and repeat to
their loan officers as a condition of receiving loans. n46 These behaviors
include promises to follow the principles of discipline, unity, courage and hard
work; to grow vegetables all year round; to keep families small; to build and
use pit-latrines; and to refrain from giving and receiving dowry. n47

   Finally, numerous commentators (including feminist scholars) identify as a
positive characteristic the Bank's focus on women as lending targets. n48 In
[*228]  its last decade of lending, the Bank has targeted women almost
exclusively. In fact, as of now, approximately 95% of the Bank's borrowers are
women. n49 The Bank claims that its focus on women is an attempt to extend to
women the benefits of development and wealth generation. n50 In addition, the
Bank claims that it lends to women because women are more likely than men to use
loans for the benefit of their families rather than for their own personal
benefit. n51

   On the basis of this relatively spare yet Elysian vision, supporters of the
transferability of the Grameen Bank model to the U.S. inner city find a good
deal about which to be hopeful. n52 For example, some members of the  [*229]
CED movement conclude that the model's combination of social and economic
development is ideally suited to their purposes and philosophy. CED's goal is to
replicate for impoverished individuals the political and social empowerment that
the middle class gains from active participation in an accessible market. n53
Specifically, the CED movement seeks to decrease poverty by providing low-income
people with the tools to participate in the market, and thereby, to participate
democratically in their communities. n54 CED's chosen method is neighborhood
revitalization, with a focus on localizing - and thus increasing - access to
housing, jobs, credit, and more generalized community participation in and
through the neighborhood structure. n55 Thus, from CED's perspective,  [*230]
people who are economically invested in their neighborhoods will become
politically and socially invested as well. n56

   On the market side of the happy equation, CED and other supporters praise the
model's potential for teaching people of lower income how to maximize their own
wealth, thereby attaining the same economic advantages - and values n57 - as
those in middle-class society. n58 Unlike welfare-to-work initiatives, which
have been regularly criticized for teaching people dead-end skills for low-end
jobs, n59 people can learn this lesson by starting their own small businesses
and bootstrapping themselves into the market. n60 The notion that the only help
required in order for low-income people to participate fully in the market is a
one-time injection of capital (in sharp contrast with the continuous maintenance
strategy of welfare) is, of course, immensely appealing to a broad group of
supporters. n61

    [*231]  For those examining the economic causes of poverty, including some
in the CED movement, the model appears particularly attractive, because it
appears to be a low-cost, highly efficient fix to the problem of market failure
in the inner city. n62 Once the microlender injects capital into a start-up
microenterprise, the Grameen Bank model leverages the informal pressures and
collective action of the solidarity circle to ensure appropriate, efficient, and
successful market participation by individual borrowers. n63 At the same time,
however, some development thinkers value the formality imposed by loan
transactions that purport to meet the standards and rigors of the market, both
because of the efficiencies gained by market participation rather than
bureaucratic complications and because such formality teaches socially
appropriate values and behaviors. n64

   This bootstrapping model seems even more appealing to many because of its
focus on the individual (rather than the collective) as the agent of change and
self-sufficiency. n65 The possibility that individuals, no matter how poor, can
[*232]  succeed by "going it alone" is a potent one in a culture where rugged
individualism is closely associated with the pursuit of the American Dream. n66

   The allure of rugged individualism also relates to a second set of
market-focused advantages in the Grameen Bank model: the microlenders themselves
might also attain "self-sufficiency" in the course of providing microcredit. n67
Supporters often comment on the superiority of the Grameen Bank model because
the Bank has the goal, which it claims is within reach, of being able to provide
its services without any governmental or outside financial support. n68 In this
respect, the Grameen Bank aspires to be a truly  [*233]  capitalist institution,
able to sustain itself permanently on the interest it receives in return for its
loans. n69

   On the social development side, supporters point to the Sixteen Decisions as
a successful model for reinforcing the lessons learned in the course of
bootstrapping into the market. The requirement that borrowers agree to adhere to
the Sixteen Decisions in order to obtain a loan serves to remind the low-income
borrowers, in particular women, of the importance of entrepreneurialism, hard
work, business judgment and discipline. n70 Moreover, the particular values
embodied in the Sixteen Decisions reinforce a number of Western values,
including the "Protestant ethic," n71 political participation, n72 and
formality. n73 For example, greater interpersonal formality not only increases
efficiency in transactions but teaches the values of success and social
benefits, such as the respect accorded mainstream market participants. n74
Particularly important to the CED movement is the notion that participation in
the market at the neighborhood level will tap into inchoate potential for
neighborhood involvement more generally and thus result in participation in the
politics of the neighborhood community. n75 CED's emphasis on the neighborhood
as the laboratory for social renewal resonates particularly with the Bank's use
of pressure from neighbors, who know each other and expect to be involved in
[*234]  repeat transactions, n76 as a means of teaching discipline and enforcing
economically and socially appropriate behavior. n77

   B. Microcredit in the United States

 Attempts to replicate the Grameen Bank model began as early as 1986. One early
effort in the United States was by the South Shore Bank and its affiliate the
Women's Self Employment Project (WSEP), both in Chicago, Illinois. n78 By the
early 1990s, several sources, including the Bank itself, claimed that more than
100 organizations in the United States were using the Grameen model to relieve
poverty, though there were, and are, many microlenders who do not claim to use
the Grameen model and are, in fact, quite different. n79 Many of these
organizations are active participants in a self-described microenterprise
movement, which is even represented by a trade association. n80 In addition,
several organizations, including the Aspen Institute  [*235]  and Accion
International, have conducted detailed studies of U.S. microlenders and produced
numerous publications concerning best practices in microlending and
microenterprise development. n81 The Aspen Institute also provides support
services to microlenders such as feasibility studies, information about funding,
and research support. n82 In 1997, a number of leading U.S. microlenders joined
with similar institutions in developing countries to form the Microcredit
Summit, the mission of which is to use microcredit to eliminate poverty
worldwide by the year 2025. n83

   Although quite diverse, microlenders in the United States (and around the
world) share a few features. Most see themselves as lending to a population of
lower-income individuals who have difficulty obtaining credit from the
mainstream commercial lending sector. n84 Moreover, most U.S.  [*236]
microlenders lend comparatively small amounts of money for the specific purpose
of creating microenterprises. n85 The typical microlending organization is
non-profit, n86 targets a specific population of lower-income individuals
(largely focusing on women, racial minorities or both), n87 and is either urban
or rural in focus. n88 On the other hand, the programs themselves differ widely.
Some use a form of the Grameen Bank's solidarity circle or peer lending
methodology. n89 Others require physical assets as collateral for individual
loans, much like mainstream commercial lenders. n90 Still others require no
collateral or guarantees at all. n91

    [*237]  As I will discuss in greater detail below, a number of U.S.
organizations have explicitly tried to import the Grameen Bank model, either
wholesale or in part. n92 For example, the Women's Self Employment Project in
Chicago has closely followed the Grameen Bank's solidarity circle methodology.
n93 Similarly, many organizations follow the example set by the Grameen Bank's
focus on women. n94 While few organizations have explicitly integrated a social
development agenda like the Sixteen Decisions into their lending programs, many
perform social development in the form of extensive training. n95

   Perhaps the most significant difference between the typical U.S. microlender
and the Grameen Bank is that the former places a heavy emphasis  [*238]  on
training in support of microenterprise. n96 Indeed, some U.S. microlenders
identify training to be even more central to their mission than the granting of
credit. n97 In this respect, many U.S. microenterprise organizations are really
quite distinguishable from the Grameen Bank in mission and philosophy, because
whereas the Grameen Bank focuses on the granting of credit, the U.S.
organizations focus on the development of self-employment skills.

   Although this Article focuses on those organizations that describe themselves
as lending-focused and that have attempted to follow specific characteristics of
the Grameen Bank model, many of my conclusions are more broadly applicable to
training-focused organizations as well. n98 In addition, as I will discuss, even
where the programs differ in strategy or ideology from the Bank, some of my
critiques nevertheless apply to analogous strategies n99 as well as to similar
ideologies. n100

   U.S. microlenders and their observers have employed much the same rhetoric
about microcredit as is used by the Grameen Bank. n101 For example,  [*239]
microlenders emphasize the market focus of their efforts. n102 Since serious
efforts at dismantling the welfare system began during the Clinton
administration, n103 many U.S. microlenders have promoted their programs as
alternatives to other welfare-to-work programs. n104 And perhaps as much as any
other value, U.S. programs have emphasized the self-sufficiency of their own
organizations as an important and attainable goal. n105 Finally, particularly
those  [*240]  programs that target female borrowers have emphasized the
importance of the social conditioning that they are performing. A board member
of the Women's Initiative for Self-Employment in San Francisco, for example,
stated that "Once you've been able to create ... a viable home situation and a
viable person that has self-belief, confidence, money management skills, and
everything else ... in place, then you have the opportunity to create a business
that can succeed in achieving community economic development." n106

   There are both similarities and differences between the Grameen Bank's
borrowers and the borrowers targeted by U.S. programs. Both, of course, are
relatively poor and have little access to credit from other sources. n107 Both
often are seen as unsophisticated in matters of business and money. n108  [*241]
The businesses that the borrowers in the two countries establish also have some
similarities. Many are retail or service enterprises. n109

   II. Mismatched Goals and Speculative Assumptions: A Preliminary Look at
Cultural Differences Concerning Poverty and Markets

 The rosy picture of the Grameen Bank that has found its way to the United
States is no accident. It is an image that has been largely constructed by the
Bank's founder, key employees, and outside funding sources, many of whom claim
that the Grameen model is both successful and transferable world-wide. n110 This
image of a market-based response to entrenched poverty has caught the excitement
and imagination of many people around the world, including the popular press.
n111

   Unfortunately, however, the image of the Grameen Bank that the U.S. public
has imported is at best incomplete and at times quite disputable. In this
section, I describe two broad misunderstandings that have occurred in the
translation from East to West. Specifically, differences in the meaning of
markets and in conceptions of how to measure success distort the Western  [*242]
understanding of the Grameen Bank's methodology and success. I address these
differences as a preliminary matter here because they contribute to a broader
understanding of problems with translation in the United States, and even
problems of reception in Bangladesh.

   "Credit without strict discipline is nothing but charity. And charity in the
name of credit will destroy the poor, not help them. Thus credit institutions
must make sure that any loans get paid back in full, and in due time." n112 This
quotation by the founder of the Grameen Bank typifies the prevailing U.S.
understanding that the Bank is first and foremost a market-based institution. It
is an understanding that is fostered by the Bank itself. And indeed the Bank
behaves in many respects like a market-focused institution. The Bank has always
charged at least market rates of interest for commercial banks in Bangladesh.
n113 As a matter of fact, the trend, partly attributable to the Bank's efforts
to achieve financial self sufficiency, n114 seems to be toward above-market
interest rates, n115 with more recent reports showing interest rates that are
double the rates charged by commercial banks in Bangladesh. n116 The Bank is
also extraordinarily rigorous in enforcing on-time loan repayment. Sources both
internal and external to the Bank attribute the Bank's startlingly low default
rate (an average of two to five percent, as compared to the significantly higher
rate of commercial banks in Bangladesh n117) to the peer lending model, the
Bank's extensive network of loan officers whose primary focus is loan
collection, the frequency and small size of payments, and the motivational
[*243]  force on borrowers to repay on time in the hope of receiving future
credit from the Bank. n118 All of these goals, as well as many of the
techniques, typify or emulate those used by mainstream financial institutions.
n119 For example, while peer lending is atypical in the mainstream commercial
sector, the Bank and others justify its use as a substitution for physical
collateral. n120

   But the Bank goes beyond forcing upon itself the rigors of market
participation and self-sufficiency; it also claims that it applies those same
rigors to the behavior of its borrowers. In other words, the Bank claims to
measure its success as a market participant not only by its own lending
practices, but also by the success of the poor people whom it helps to
participate in the market via microenterprise. n121 I have no quarrel with the
[*244]  Bank's means of evaluating its own lending practices against the
standards of the market. I do, however, question its second claim.

   One would expect the Bank to measure its success by the number of start-up
microenterprises it successfully funded, as well as the number of such
microenterprises that lasted long enough to lift their proprietors out of
poverty more than momentarily. This, however, does not appear to be the Bank's
primary focus. n122 Instead, the Bank - and its admirers - appear to evaluate
its success vis-a-vis its borrowers by the number of loans it extends, n123 and
by increases in the nutritional levels and health of the borrowers and their
families, amounts of personal physical assets (such as changes of clothes and
land), educational level of children in the borrowers' families before and after
borrowing began and other similar criteria. n124 The Bank also tracks income
levels of borrowers and their families, claiming that its lending raises a
significant percentage of its borrowers over the poverty line. n125

    [*245]  The Bank claims that it also tracks the borrowers' microenterprises
by regularly confirming that borrowers have actually used their loan funds for
purposes of starting a particular small business (rather than diverting such
funds for a different business or for payment of dowry, purchase of land, or
other impermissible purposes). n126 However, recent studies have revealed that
the Bank only requires the chairpersons of borrower groups and other leaders in
the borrowing center to complete and update forms reporting borrowers' uses of
loan funds, that loan use is regularly misreported on such forms, and that the
center leaders and bank workers are not ignorant of such misreporting. n127
These forms are rarely verified by loan officers through visits, witness
corroboration, or other similar devices. n128 As a consequence, many of the loan
funds are not actually used for their stated purposes. n129 Moreover, according
to one study, thirty-eight percent of the time, funds in a study village were
not even used to benefit any income-producing activity, but instead were used
for explicitly impermissible purposes. n130 This level of inaccuracy leaves
serious doubt about the Bank's focus on tracking the sustainability of
microenterprises. n131

   Leaving aside the questions of what exactly the Bank's measurements of
success are and whether the Bank ought to correct these standards, this data
also suggests that those in the West interested in transferability should look
beyond the Bank's claim that it is a capitalist institution aiming to transform
the poor into entrepreneurs. They must carefully examine how the Bank determines
whether it has accomplished this goal. They should begin by questioning why the
Bank appears to measure success by what the U.S. public  [*246]  might call
social welfare indicators, rather than by market participation. n132 In fact,
the indicators that the Bank uses are the very indicators that the United States
typically has used to evaluate welfare and "maintenance" programs such as the
Aid for Families with Dependent Children and Temporary Assistance to Needy
Families n133 program. My point is this: factors that may be well-matched to
social goals reveal little about the viability of the market as the engine of
poverty reduction.

   If the ultimate goal in using the microcredit model is to alleviate poverty
through permanent income generation by means of self-employment, n134 Western
importers should consider how seriously the Grameen Bank's unique understanding
and evaluation of that goal implicates the vitality of its model in the United
States. If permanent income generation is the real measure of success vis-a-vis
borrowers, even the Bank's statistics about income levels are not nearly as
useful as information about the creation and sustainability of the
microenterprises. n135 Evidence of welfare improvement in borrowers is not an
appropriate stand-in because it may simply evidence the (temporary) benefits
from the initial infusion of capital by the Bank rather than the permanent
benefits of long-term and sustained income generation. While improved welfare
may be the ultimate goal of economic development, the particular  [*247]  focus
of microlending programs is to accomplish this goal by catalyzing sustained
income generation.

   Alternatively, Western admirers could recalibrate their goals to match those
of the Grameen Bank more closely. To do so, however, would mean abandoning the
fundamental purpose of microcredit programs - creating small businesses. Perhaps
of equal importance, to do so would mean to stray considerably from the economic
theory underlying many of the more promising and progressive historical efforts
at poverty reduction (including some of CED's efforts). n136 Some of the more
laudable initiatives for the poor have as their basis not just the goal of
increasing incomes of low-income individuals so that the national or regional
market can benefit from their spending; n137 rather, they seek to overcome
market failure by means of market participation n138 by the poor in multiple
forms, as both neighborhood shopkeepers and as empowered consumers, as both the
local work force and the local patrons. n139

   This ideology is arguably the most potent advantage that modern attempts at
poverty reduction can claim over welfare and other social "maintenance"
programs. n140 This is what neutralizes the critique that the Grameen Bank model
is just a shell for wealth redistribution. And this is why it would represent a
significant shift of objectives for these programs to measure success only by
increased nutritional levels, health, personal assets and even income levels of
its target population. n141 These are the measures that  [*248]  may
appropriately be used by social maintenance programs, and only in an ancillary
way by income generation and job creation programs. n142 Western importers must
have a means by which to measure whether their programs result in market
integration of low income individuals, as suppliers as well as consumers. n143

   In their quest for transferable models, Westerners must also consider
carefully whether the Grameen Bank's understanding of the market itself is
transferable to the inner city. Others have cautioned that the Grameen Bank and
other microlenders in developing countries might have met with much greater
success than microlenders in the United States can expect because the markets in
those countries are much less formal than those in the United States. n144
According to these other appraisals, the greater informality in those  [*249]
countries results in quicker, easier, and deeper penetration of the market by
new entrants. n145 This is so partly because the informality of both business
structures and business relationships reduces start-up costs. New entrants do
not have to learn about, or spend resources putting into place, written
contracts and other formal instruments of transaction.

   Moreover, some claim that informal markets are the dominant, or even only,
markets that exist in many of these countries. n146 In other words, there are no
large firms providing many goods and services. Thus, those microenterprises that
are successful as a result of microcredit funds are not simply benefiting from a
redistribution of wealth from larger firms to micro-firms but rather from
creation of new wealth in the context of a more robust informal market. n147 In
the language of market failure theory, these differences in markets require
critical analysis of whether, for example, new entrepreneurs in the U.S. inner
city require more information than their Bangladeshi counterparts in order to
gauge appropriate access points to even their local markets. n148 Such
information might relate to whether there are certain industries that are
dominated by larger firms in such a way as to make entry impossible or to
whether consumers would expect certain signals of formality in order to engage
in transactions with the new entrants. n149 My argument here  [*250]  is not
that the Bank is misunderstanding the nature of the market in rural Bangladesh
but rather that Western development programs cannot assume that inner city
markets have the same characteristics. n150 The nature of the market failure may
be different in each location, and thus the solutions may also diverge.

   In addition, in developing countries, at least at the regional level, there
is less reason to worry about the possibility raised by Kenneth Anderson that
microcredit creates "faux" or marginal markets for the poor and the poor only
(rather than a connection to the mainstream market). n151 In other words, the
more affluent members of the typical Bangladeshi neighborhood will be as likely
to go to the new microbusiness selling cow's milk as to a more established, but
just as small, seller of cow's milk. n152 However, this is a much more real
concern in the U.S. inner city, where more affluent members of the community
might trust only the larger, more well-established firms to provide quality
products, defined among other things as those products that meet regulatory
safety tests n153 and that have tested well with many consumers. n154 Thus, U.S.
programs cannot avoid the question of which market they seek to help the poor
join - their own marginal market or a more regional, national, or global market.
Perhaps microlenders in developing countries have been able to avoid this
question for the very reason that the informality of their local markets
obscures the enormous leaps required to join larger markets. As I will discuss
in greater detail below, U.S. programs must confront this question more
imminently, if for no other reason than that informality may be a barrier for
market entry in the inner city much earlier than it appears to be in the
developing world. n155

   My concerns about the overly hasty importation of goals find some support in
the experiences of microcredit organizations in this country. In the United
States, we have had the opportunity to conduct in-depth empirical studies of
microlending. Although the rhetoric used in discussing both the Grameen Bank
model and the income-generating potential of microcredit in the United States is
quite similar - many describe the value of microcredit as  [*251]  the potential
to create entrepreneurs by bootstrapping the poor into the market n156 - most
studies have found that microcredit has simply not generated permanent
income-producing opportunities, or microenterprises, in large numbers. n157 In
particular, microcredit in its current iteration only works for a narrow
cross-section of the welfare population. n158 A number of commentators have
concluded that microenterprise simply is not a viable solution for the very
poor. n159 In addition, the majority of microenterprises that are formed fail to
survive. n160 Perhaps most discouragingly, those microenterprises that do not
fail  [*252]  generally do not generate enough income to lift their proprietors
out of poverty. n161 Thus, even those microenterprises that succeed arguably
cannot be described as a means of permanent income generation, because their
proprietors still depend on other sources of income in order to sustain
themselves. n162

   Interestingly, many U.S. microlenders follow the Grameen Bank's example by
defining their own organizational success using market-based factors, such as
the ability of the lender to attain self-sufficiency and the amount of funds
lent. n163 Indeed the success of microlenders as market participants seems to be
the focus of much of the research generated about this industry. n164 In large
part, both the Aspen Institute and Accion International, another leading
publisher of microlending statistics, publish manuals on how to establish and
run microlending institutions. n165 Thus, it is not clear whether  [*253]
consistent and independent efforts are being made to track systematically the
success rate of U.S. microenterprises started with the aid of microcredit. n166

   III. An Empirical Look at the Three Key Features of the Grameen Bank Model

 In this section, I seek to fill in the picture of the Grameen Bank with
information from a number of empirical studies conducted by independent
economists, sociologists, and anthropologists. My hope is to provide a more
complete view of the characteristics that seem amenable to transfer to the U.S.
inner city: namely, the solidarity circle, the focus on women as lending
targets, and the Sixteen Decisions. I also review some of the empirical studies
of U.S. experiments with these factors.

   In my empirical review, I rely extensively on a limited number of studies of
the Grameen Bank that provide some disturbing information that had only been
alluded to in prior analyses. As I have suggested, I suspect that this
discrepancy in information may result partly from the independence of these
newer studies as distinguished from earlier studies, many of which were financed
by the Bank or its funding sources. n167 However, I am aware that there has thus
far been very little empirical work done pertaining to the Bank. Moreover, these
more recent studies may also reflect the biases of the researchers. Thus, my own
reliance on these studies ought to be reexamined at a later date when more
research has been completed. It is possible, for example, that some of my
conclusions will be inaccurate if later studies  [*254]  discredit some of the
studies on which I rely. At the very least, it is appropriate to take two
conclusions from this review. First, while the more recent studies may not
provide enough information by themselves to deem the Grameen Bank's program a
failure, they certainly reveal that the Bank's impact is uncertain. Second, much
more empirical analysis is necessary before we can proclaim the Bank's program a
success. n168

   A. The Solidarity Circle

   1. In Bangladesh

 Probably the most lauded innovation of the Grameen Bank model is its use of a
solidarity circle, where small groups of borrowers guarantee each other's loans
as a substitute for physical collateral. As described above, many in the United
States view this innovation as a means to retain the formality of the
requirement of collateral in a mainstream commercial lending relationship, while
reducing the costs and risks of lending by transferring the tasks of loan
screening to the borrower circle (which has more information than even a broad
network of local loan officers). n169 The solidarity circle, it is claimed, has
the added benefits of teaching the borrowers business judgment, self-confidence,
and collaboration. n170

   However, more recent studies conclude that some of the assumed benefits have
not in fact been realized. In addition, the use of the solidarity circle has
resulted in some distinct disadvantages. Perhaps most importantly, because the
Grameen Bank model solves the informational problem by relying on borrowers to
screen their own peers for participation in the solidarity circle, borrowers
regularly screen out the poorest members of their villages. n171  [*255]
Moreover, many borrowers either overtly or covertly violate the Bank's rules by
forming circles with extended family members or using extended family members to
control a number of circles. For example, one study found that, in one of the
first villages to receive aid from the Grameen Bank, most of the solidarity
circles were led by extended family members of one of the first borrowers to
form a solidarity circle in the village. n172 That borrower was a more senior
member of a large family in the village that appeared to be of higher social
status. n173 She was able to influence decisions in other borrower circles by
convincing more junior relatives to form and lead those circles. n174 This type
of influence extends not only to decisions about who should be accepted into the
circles but also to decisions about whose loan applications should be approved
and for what purposes. n175 Thus, at least in that particular study village, the
expected benefits of developing business judgment and collaboration in the
marketplace were not realized in the face of more "factional" decision making.
n176 This conundrum may very well contribute to the Bank's failure to help the
poorest of the poor.

   A second unexpected disadvantage of the solidarity circle is also one of the
greatest benefits claimed by its proponents, namely that the circle leverages
social collateral to pressure borrowers to repay their loans in order to avoid
causing friction with their neighbors, with whom they must interact for a
lifetime. It seems, however, that even the Grameen Bank did not anticipate just
how much pressure some of its borrowers would feel. A number of studies have
found that the Bank's strong enforcement of on-time repayments, even in the face
of family illnesses, deaths, natural disasters, and other extraordinary events,
translates into enormous pressure by the circle upon the individual borrower.
n177 Such studies have documented occasions on which members of a circle, when
unable to make up a borrower's delinquent payment, have taken and sold that
borrower's household items or personal assets, n178 demanded that  [*256]  the
borrower's family members make up the payment, n179 and committed violence
against the borrower. n180

   These studies have documented two frequent coping mechanisms used by
individual borrowers in order to avoid these extreme consequences, mechanisms
that conflict with the Bank's stated goals. First, borrowers use other household
assets, such as savings (including savings accounts established with the Bank),
and may sell personal and even business assets, in order to make payments on
their Grameen loans. n181 Second, borrowers who cannot resort to these reserves
recycle loans, frequently by obtaining loans informally from their relatives,
but also regularly by obtaining loans from money lenders (who can charge annual
interest of 100% to 200%) in order to meet their Grameen Bank payments. n182
This, of course, results in higher overall debt and greater financial
instability for the borrowers. n183

   2. In the United States

 Those programs in the United States that have attempted to use the solidarity
circle appear to have recognized quite early that giving borrowers the choice of
co-guarantors meant leaving the poorest out of the programs. A number of U.S.
programs have eschewed the requirement that borrowers pick their own group,
instead assigning borrowers to groups. n184 However, those programs have had to
sacrifice the notion that solidarity circle members guarantee each other's loans
on the ground that it is simply unfair to require people to guarantee the loans
of those about whom they do not have enough information. n185 Other programs
have retained the voluntary structure of circle  [*257]  formation, but they
have either dropped the guarantee requirement or have been less rigorous in
their repayment and collection procedures, thereby lessening the pressure on
co-borrowers to guarantee each other's loans. n186 Others have retained
voluntary formation and strict enforcement procedures, but have generally
provided such small loans that they arguably are not so much a source of capital
as a training program. n187 In all these examples, the lenders have interposed
themselves more extensively between the borrowers and the market, thereby
creating greater differences between their lending programs and those that the
borrowers would encounter in the mainstream commercial lending context. n188

   B. The Sixteen Decisions as Contractual Conditions

   1. In Bangladesh

 Many have praised the Sixteen Decisions and similar social development efforts
by microcredit programs as techniques for teaching, and enforcing, social norms
in the context of the financial transaction. n189 Such norms include
"self-respect," "self-reliance," and "work ethic." n190 As noted  [*258]
earlier, Grameen Bank borrowers are required to memorize and abide by the
Sixteen Decisions as a condition for receiving a loan. n191 A number of studies
have concluded that, as a result of the Bank's involvement, borrowers have been
more likely than the general population to use birth control, n192 to be more
articulate, n193 and at least to be aware of the positive effects of the
directives even if they do not actually adopt the behaviors. n194 Although some
studies have found that women's economic and social status both within their
families and in their villages has been enhanced as a result of adherence to the
Sixteen Decisions, n195 none of the studies appears to have reported on the
impact of the Bank's social development efforts on the borrowers' level of
success in market participation. Nor have they presented any correlation between
the behavioral directives and the rate of formation and sustainability of
microenterprises funded by the Bank.

   More troublesome are the suggestions from some recent studies that some
aspects of the Bank's credit and social development program contribute to an
actual and/or perceived hierarchy, with bank workers at the top and the
borrowers at the bottom. Specifically, those studies have commented that the
Bank's requirements that borrowers "chant slogans," perform physical exercises,
and call their loan officers "sir" may contribute to the hierarchical
relationship between borrowers and the Bank. n196

    [*259]  Finally, a number of studies have discovered that the borrowers do
not follow some of the most highly publicized directives, including those
prohibiting dowry and requiring the use of pit latrines. n197 The reasons given
by these studies range from bank workers' failure to act as models for the
borrowers by their overt disregard especially of the dowry directive, n198 to
the Bank's decreasing emphasis on the Sixteen Decisions in its weekly meetings
with borrowers (in favor of greater emphasis on on-time payments), n199 to the
Bank's lack of expertise in guiding the borrowers in their compliance especially
with the directive to use pit latrines. n200 In general, the picture that
emerges is that borrowers simply don't comply with those directives that are at
odds with their social or cultural norms. n201 Thus, while we in the United
States have an image of consistent social conditioning in aid of better market
participation, the truer picture of the Grameen Bank is of a more fragmented
series of experiments in social conditioning, many of which do not work - and
none of which have been proven to aid market participation. One must ask whether
the social directives were chosen by, or even acceptable to, the borrowers as a
condition of receiving loans, n202 and more broadly, whether a social
development agenda such as the Sixteen Decisions makes sense in the context of a
microlending program.

   2. In the United States

 Even those programs that claim to follow the Grameen Bank model closely have
not implemented a substantially similar version of the Sixteen Decisions. In
considering the transferability of the social development agenda of the Bank,
Western programs surely have had to ponder just how they would translate
directives such as prohibiting dowry, requiring use of pit latrines, or even
requiring year-round vegetable cultivation. Would they, for example,  [*260]
prohibit borrowers from using drugs, drinking alcohol, or eating fast food as a
condition of receiving microloans?

   Understandably, U.S. microlenders have generally avoided these difficult
questions. Instead, many U.S. programs seem to have transformed the social
development agenda into a training plan. n203 While some programs offer a
relatively extensive array of classes on business development and financial
management, many (perhaps the majority) seem more focused on behavioral or even
psychological development as a step toward market participation. n204 Thus, for
example, many programs seem to focus on helping women feel more confident about
their business ideas, become better public speakers, and so on. n205

    [*261]  It appears regularly to be the case that many of these programs fail
to articulate whether market participation is indeed the ultimate goal of their
training efforts. As I have described, there is evidence that U.S. programs have
followed the Grameen Bank's example by measuring the success of their training
(and lending) efforts by the use of social maintenance criteria, including such
fuzzy standards as greater business knowledge, more self confidence, and more
stability. n206 It is also unclear whether the tremendous resources spent on
training by U.S. programs have in fact led to greater market participation. n207
The low rate of successful microenterprise creation suggests little correlation.
Finally, it is unclear, as it is in Bangladesh, whether the borrowers who go to
U.S. programs for credit in fact get what they requested.

   C. Women as Lending Targets

   1. In Bangladesh

 A third much-lauded characteristic of the Grameen Bank's program is its focus
on women as lending targets. Some have noted that the Bank's decision to target
women serves the purpose of formalizing the informal economy, because a far
greater percentage of female workers participate in the informal economy than in
the formal economy. n208 Others in the United States  [*262]  have also
commented approvingly that the Bank's focus on women adds a positive social
development facet to the Bank's capitalist agenda. n209 According to this view,
women, more than men, benefit from the Bank's efforts to teach the poor socially
and economically appropriate behavior. n210

   While consistently expressing a desire to empower women in the course of its
economic development efforts, n211 the founder of the Grameen Bank has also
articulated another explanation: "Given the opportunity to fight against poverty
and hunger women turn out to be natural and better fighters than men." n212 The
Bank claims that, after lending equally to male and female borrowers in its
early years of operation, the Bank began to target women because it found that
women used household resources more selflessly, resulting in a greater increase
in nutritional levels, health, and income of the female borrowers' families than
those of the male borrowers. n213

   A number of recent studies have focused on the gender issue. While their
findings do not generally contradict the Bank's conclusions that "women are
natural and better fighters," some of these studies have concluded that the
familial benefits from women's borrowing activities are often attained directly
at the expense of the women's empowerment, however that is defined. n214  [*263]
Specifically, several studies have noted that lending to women results in higher
rates of repayment precisely because women are easier to control than male
borrowers. n215 Rahman, for example, has quoted bank workers as saying that
women are "shy," "submissive," and "immobile," making it easier to keep track of
and discipline them for errant behavior, whereas men are "arrogant,"
argumentative, and have even threatened bank workers. n216 Rahman concludes that
two additional cultural norms dovetail with the Bank's collection-related goals.
First, women's lack of options outside of marriage precludes them from fleeing
their homes and villages when they default on loans. n217 Second, gender
expectations impose on women, much more than men, the burden of maintaining
their families' honor and avoiding shame. n218 Rahman tells of a defaulting
female borrower who was locked by bank workers inside a bank building as
punishment and infers from his interviews of the villagers that, had a man been
punished in the same way, it would not have affected his social position in the
village. However, because the woman faced shame, social ostracism, and violence,
she hanged herself inside the bank building. n219

   According to Rahman and other recent studies, women were also disempowered
through the lending process because their husbands or other male members of
their families often used the women's loan funds for their own personal or
business purposes. n220 Rahman found in his sample that women retained full or
partial control of their loans only twenty-two percent of the  [*264]  time,
n221 despite the Bank's claims that it tracks funds in order to ensure that the
borrowers use them for their own income-generating activities. The Grameen Bank
imposes formal liability for repayment only on the borrowers, and not also on
those family members who actually use the loan funds. n222

   Rahman found that this dual imposition on women, from their male family
members as well as from the Bank, can put women in a much more vulnerable
position than they had been prior to receiving the opportunity to borrow from
the Bank. His study found that women are regularly coerced by male family
members to join the Bank as borrowers and are pressured by both family members
and bank workers to repay loans on time, but are nonetheless often excluded from
income-generating opportunities. n223 Disturbingly, in his study, fifty-seven
percent of female borrowers reported an increase in "verbal aggression" after
joining the Bank and an additional thirteen percent reported an increase in both
"verbal aggression" and "physical assault." n224

   2. In the United States

 A large number of U.S. programs that claim to replicate the Grameen Bank model
also have chosen to focus exclusively or largely on women, n225 often expressing
a desire to follow the Grameen Bank's goal of empowering women economically,
socially, and politically. Indeed, there is regularly an explicit assumption
that women, more than men, need the business training and confidence building
that some microlenders claim to specialize in providing. n226 A number of these
programs have claimed tremendous success. n227 However, it  [*265]  is not clear
that any studies have yet determined whether the problems found in Bangladesh
have also surfaced in the United States. Given the alarming results found by
Rahman's study in particular, such a task is clearly necessary. While the
particular forms of coercion and vulnerability in the United States may be
different, the Grameen Bank experience suggests that those designing such
programs should be conscious of the risk, particularly in light of the pressures
that impoverished women in the United States already face. n228

   U.S. microlenders must also inquire whether the majority culture in the
United States similarly imposes upon poor women unstated assumptions that they
are natural and better fighters against poverty, and if so why. Furthermore,
while the Grameen Bank may be comfortable with its decision to contribute to
social norms that reify gender stereotyping, U.S. microlenders should be
considerably less sanguine about perpetuating socialized gender roles. n229

[*266]

   IV. The Model's Structural Failures

 In this section, I posit that the solidarity circle, the Sixteen Decisions, and
the focus on women have been the subject of so much attention because they
appear to solve three structural problems that the development community (both
here and abroad) perennially endeavors to fix. These three problems are market
failure, lack of transactional formality, and cultural hegemony (or, put in the
negative, a failure of development programs to incorporate indigenous values).
However, the Bank's model consistently fails to solve the three structural
problems; in fact, the model actually exacerbates one of them.

   A. Market Failure

 Simply defined, market failure occurs when one or more of the conditions for a
functioning market are missing. Economists define a perfectly functioning market
as one characterized by many buyers and sellers, homogeneous products, perfect
knowledge, no entry or exit barriers, and no transaction costs. n230 When one or
more of these assumptions diverges greatly from reality, certain transactions
that would result in a net economic benefit simply do not occur, resulting in
what economists call market failure. Those who have examined inner city
economies broadly concur that such economies are fraught with market failure.
n231 For example, often there are very few sellers even of basic items such as
food, n232 extraordinary limitations in knowledge of sellers who either ignore
or do not know the needs of inner city buyers, n233 and tremendous barriers to
market entry by members of the local community. n234

   Similarly, there is a consensus that the inner city market for credit has
failed. n235 Many attribute the cause of market failure at least in part to the
enormous inefficiencies experienced by mainstream commercial institutions that
try to make small loans to inner city borrowers. n236 These inefficiencies
[*267]  result when the costs expended in obtaining information needed to
determine whether a borrower is a credit risk outweigh the returns on tiny
loans. n237 Informational problems arise not just in the initial screening
decision but also in the context of monitoring loan repayment and enforcement.
n238 Because lenders cannot rely on the availability of physical collateral
through which to recoup a loan upon default, the lenders' costs of monitoring
loan repayment increase. n239 Similarly, because lenders do not have the
perceived ease of judicial enforcement by means of asset foreclosure, they must
use less swift and efficient enforcement techniques. n240 The problem is
compounded by usury laws prohibiting banks from charging even the rates of
interest now charged by the Grameen Bank. n241

    [*268]  Both here and abroad, discussions about the causes of, and the
solutions for, the credit market's inaccessibility to the poor are ubiquitous.
Programmatic efforts to remedy market failure in the inner city market for
credit have varied and are ongoing. These include the federal Community
Reinvestment Act n242 and the community development banking movement. n243
Members of the CED movement have regularly contributed to these efforts. For
example, Professor Simon discusses at length the problem of "market limitations"
as concerning problems of "incentives, information, and coordination." n244 Some
Law and Economics analyses have contributed to these efforts as well. n245
Overseas, Western developers, particularly in the Law and Development movement,
have participated in a parallel set of discussions, even when the programmatic
conclusions differ greatly. n246

   It should be little wonder, then, that early reports about the solidarity
circle were a beacon of hope for development economists. The solidarity circle
appeared to solve seemingly intractable informational problems. n247 First, by
assigning borrowers the task of screening loan applicants, the circle appeared
to allow the lender to take advantage of the greater knowledge that borrowers in
a community have of each other's character and trustworthiness, knowledge that
even a local institution with many employees cannot expect to have. n248 Again,
such knowledge is useful both in the initial screening decision  [*269]  and in
the course of monitoring and enforcing compliance with loan terms. n249 Second,
the solidarity circle appeared to help the lender overcome coordination and
incentive problems, and to reduce transaction costs further, by facilitating the
lender's ability to make numerous small loans within a single neighborhood. The
lender should thereby be able to take advantage of close associations,
references from current borrowers about new ones, and similar networks. n250 In
other words, a lender should be able to recoup its initial investment of
employees and branch location by penetrating a particular market deeply. n251

   In the United States, however, the solidarity circle, where used, has failed
to fulfill its promise to solve the structural problem of market failure. This
result is quite predictable. Even where the manipulation of local knowledge
networks increases lender information in the inner city credit market, there are
several additional informational and cost-related gaps that are left unfilled.
First, the solidarity circle solves only part of the lender's informational
problem. In order to complete a mainstream commercial loan transaction
successfully, a lender must not only have information about its borrower's
character and reputation, but also must be able to assess whether the borrower's
business is likely to succeed. The Grameen Bank and some U.S. commentators claim
that the solidarity circle solves this part of the informational problem as
well: The circle saves the lender the trouble of screening anything about the
borrower - character or business plan - because the lender can recoup its loans
from the other borrowers in the circle. n252 Thus, these other borrowers are the
ones who must obtain information about each other's businesses, and advocates of
the circle strategy claim that participation in the circle develops the
necessary business judgment in borrowers to do just that. n253 Unfortunately,
this altruistic prediction has not come to pass.

    [*270]  Even leaving aside more recent studies of the Grameen Bank that
suggest that borrowers screen each other on grounds other than business plans
(or even trustworthiness), U.S. experiments have reached much more mixed
conclusions about whether borrowers can acquire the necessary business judgment
to perform this piece of the screening function. n254 This result should come as
no surprise, given the extraordinary complexity of running a business in this
country. n255 Thus, in transferring the solidarity circle to the inner city,
U.S. programs will have to face the possibility that the circle will reduce only
the costs of obtaining information about borrowers' trustworthiness, and not
about the strength of their business plans. n256

   The difficulties of transforming communal character judgments into sound
business assessments aside, the benefits gained by leaving to borrowers the
tasks of screening and monitoring each other must be weighed against the
potential exclusion of the poorest and most marginal members of the community -
whose creditworthiness will find few advocates. Indeed, a number of commentators
have concluded that microlending is not an answer for the poorest members of
society; n257 hence, those who describe microlending as a more comprehensive
solution n258 must investigate whether the Grameen  [*271]  Bank's inability to
sweep the poorest within its net will be replicated in the U.S. inner city.

   Solving these informational problems, however, reaches only one side of the
market failure - the lender's informational problems. The solidarity circle does
not address the second set of informational problems: the increased
transactional costs imposed by the circle methodology on the borrowers. In other
words, the lender's reduced transactional costs (and risk) are transferred
directly to the borrowers in the solidarity circle, n259 who are required to
spend time and resources in peer group meetings, learning each other's
businesses, and monitoring each other's compliance. n260 At the very least, this
creates inefficiency in the borrower's participation in the lending process.
Additionally, the increased costs are imposed on those least able to afford
them. n261

   Should inefficiency on this side of the lending equation matter? The answer
necessarily implicates the goals of those who are interested in microlending in
the United States. If the goal is only to increase investment, by mainstream
institutions or by a new class of non-profit organizations (such as community
development corporations) in the inner city, then the remainder of my analysis
may be superfluous. So long as lenders either accept or overcome the added costs
necessary to solve my first market failure concern (that of screening borrowers'
business plans), then success may be claimed. However, the goal should be much
more ambitious: poverty reduction by means of increased access by the poor to
the market. And where credit is concerned, such poverty reduction results from
the process of providing credit to inner city residents in order to spur them
into market participation through microenterprise development. Therefore, the
development community should be concerned about the link between the imposition
of non-mainstream transaction costs on low-income borrowers and the failure rate
of their micro-businesses. In other words, it is quite plausible that
microcredit borrowers, both in Bangladesh and in the United States, may have
more difficulty maintaining their small businesses because they are confronted
with added  [*272]  costs in the lending process that are simply not faced by
mainstream borrowers. n262

   In addition to higher transaction costs, the solidarity circle imposes
another distinct burden on low-income borrower-entrepreneurs. By imposing joint
liability through its guarantee requirement, the solidarity circle strategy may
hinder borrowers from taking the risks that mainstream businesses can readily
assume. Specifically, the possibility of repaying the loans of another circle
member eliminates the benefit of limited liability that is the lynchpin of
American corporate law. n263 The solidarity circle strategy thus comprehensively
inhibits risk-taking behavior in an entire segment of the commercial population,
which may in reality contribute to market failure. n264

   Relatedly and perhaps most importantly, there is nothing inherent in the
solidarity circle strategy that solves the information, incentive, and
coordination problems for the borrowers as entrepreneurs, as distinguished from
the informational problems of lenders and borrowers in the lending process.
This, then, is the third aspect of market failure that the solidarity circle
fails to solve. In other words, informational and other gains for the lender
(and even the borrower) in the lending process do not necessarily translate into
gains for the borrowers as they attempt to form and maintain small businesses.
To the extent the Grameen Bank has addressed this concern, it has done so by the
rather simplistic assumption that the business acumen and financial knowledge
gained by borrowers through their participation in  [*273]  solidarity circles
will have the collateral effect of teaching borrowers how to maintain their own
small businesses. n265

   At the very least, this assumption cries out for empirical evaluation. It is
not at all clear that by learning how to obtain a loan, would-be entrepreneurs
will also learn how to do market analyses concerning the viability of their
products or services, acquire the skills necessary to produce their goods or
provide their services, learn how to market their goods or services, or acquire
the myriad other skills required to maintain even a tiny enterprise. n266 If,
like many Grameen Bank borrowers, inner-city U.S. borrowers fail to learn how to
craft a loan commensurate with their repayment abilities, then they too risk the
difficulties resulting from borrowing too much in the face of uncertainty,
thereby risking loss of savings and debt recycling. n267

   A notable attempt to remedy this third aspect of market failure may be those
U.S. programs that are more training focused. These programs, which appear
increasingly to dominate the U.S. microenterprise industry, n268 might very well
succeed in remedying some of the information problems of new
micro-entrepreneurs. n269 Their success, however, may come at the expense of the
efficiencies claimed by the Grameen Bank and other lending-focused programs.
n270 Moreover, their success will effectively have proven the inefficacy in the
United States of the Grameen Bank model, which eschews training on grounds that
indigenous instincts are the key to successful market integration of the poor.

   These hurdles will be even more difficult to overcome if the goal of market
integration means integration into more than a highly localized market. n271
Posner, in positing a theory of "primitive society," sets out a number  [*274]
of assumptions concerning economic transactions in such societies. n272 Some of
his assumptions resonate with CED's assumptions about the makings of market
failure. To use Posner's vocabulary, the development community will have to
examine whether the solidarity circle strategy results first in a greater
variety of goods produced, and second in a broader circle of trading, than a
highly localized economy can support. n273 In other words, new entrepreneurs
will have to obtain market data about a more complex regional or even national
economy in order to test the profitability of their products or services, and so
on. n274 If Posner is correct, this will require more than additional effort,
hard work, and even information. Rather, in order to support this level of
participation, new entrepreneurs will have to be able to access some of the
formal systems and rights (such as intellectual property rights) propounded by
Law and Development theory. n275 This, then, is a fourth piece of the market
failure problem: The inaccessibility of these formal rights adds insurmountable
transaction costs and may be a barrier to market entry for many
microentrepreneurs.

   U.S. microlenders, including those involved in the CED movement, might have
hoped and assumed that some of the gaps that I have described above could be
filled by the social development piece of the Grameen Bank model. In order to
serve this function, however, one would expect the "social" development agenda
to be more focused on market values. In other words, it would seem more useful
to teach the values of business development rather than the values of social
development. As I have described earlier, however, this is neither the focus of
the Grameen Bank nor of a significant number of U.S. replications. n276 At best,
then, proponents of a Grameen-style social development agenda can only claim
collateral benefits in producing market-enhancing behavior. Seen in this light,
neither the Sixteen Decisions nor any other aspect of the Grameen strategy
solves the second and third market failure gaps identified above. n277 To borrow
again from Law and Economics  [*275]  vocabulary, the model does little to
increase commensurability in economic decision-making by low-income individuals.
In other words, it fails to teach would-be entrepreneurs enough business
judgment to be able to compare the consequences of different economic
alternatives, thereby establishing a necessary condition to economically
rational (and participatory) behavior. Simply put, it fails to teach the poor
how better to maximize their wealth.

   It does not appear that the Grameen Bank has found a way in which to reduce
transaction costs for borrowers. Indeed, the Bank's strategy relies in important
respects on inconvenience as a motivational tool for participation and on-time
payment. n278 Further, the Grameen Bank does not fill the informational and
other gaps that serve to bar market participation in the form of successful
entrepreneurship. In fact, with respect to this latter gap, the Bank claims that
it is an important part of its strategy to leave questions about market
participation (including product and business development) to the borrowers to
sort out. n279 This may indeed be a successful strategy in Bangladesh (though
again we do not have the research to support this conclusion fully). But it
would be irresponsible indeed not to question it anew before importing it to the
United States. n280

   Finally, as a means of fixing market failure, the Grameen Bank's focus on
women seems at best superfluous, and at worst a drawback. If the Grameen Bank is
a good case study, then the only market-related benefit of this gendered
strategy redounds to the lender, who can more easily "control" the behavior of
female borrowers than male borrowers. Thus, while it may be a laudable social
goal to make the market more accessible to female participants, it has not been
claimed (nor can it be easily proven) that a focus on women (to the exclusion of
male entrepreneurs who currently also lack access to the market) would result in
greater poverty reduction through a higher level of market participation. n281
In other words, while women may be "natural and better fighters" against poverty
because they are more likely to use household resources for the benefit of the
family, there is no reason to believe that women are natural and better
entrepreneurs who will be more capable of closing the information gap and
overcoming other market-based hurdles. Moreover,  [*276]  unless the goal is to
create a new women-only market, the focus only on female entrepreneurs imposes
an additional division between the borrowing program and participation in a full
and free market. n282 As I discuss in the following section, such a division
runs the risk of creating a false sense of participation in the market. n283 In
addition, even as an interim measure, it creates differences between the market
for the poor created by microenterprise programs and a broader market, thereby
potentially making entry into the latter market even more difficult. n284

   In addition, U.S. microlenders might do well to consider whether it is
programmatically appropriate to impose solely on women the burden of poverty
reduction through the rigorous process of market participation. Again, the
historical assumption that women are the primary caretakers of children in U.S.
society dovetails perhaps too easily with similar assumptions by the Grameen
Bank. In the United States, this assumption is well documented. n285 Given this
reality, U.S. microlenders might find that a larger percentage of their
borrowers are women even if microlenders do not make extra efforts to target
them. By doing so, however, microlenders are, purposefully or not, perpetuating
cultural gender roles. Certainly, this is not justified by economic theory about
the causes and cures for market failure. n286

   Unfortunately, rather than attempting directly to address specific causes of
market failure, industry studies of microlending in the United States have
focused more and more on testing the ability of microlenders, rather than
micro-borrowers, to attain self-sufficiency. n287 At the very least, more
