empirical work is required in order to understand the benefits and disadvantages
of microcredit as a strategy for avoiding market failure.

   Such empirical work must be supplemented with more careful theoretical
analysis of market failure. Currently, theoretical assumptions about the
economics of market failure are ubiquitously made without a clear  [*277]
indication of whether such economics apply in Bangladesh or in the United
States. I suspect this is because the development community assumes that causes
of market failure around the world are universal and can be generalized. n288
Thus, attempts by U.S. programs to transfer the model to the very different
economy in the United States are made more difficult by the lack of clarity
concerning the economics of market failure in the United States versus in
Bangladesh. n289

   B. Formal Participation in the Market

 A second structural problem that development thinkers both here and abroad seek
to solve is that of teaching the poor formal market participation. This
structural problem arises because another pervasive goal of the development
community is to integrate the poor into the same market as that in which the
middle and upper classes participate. Thus, while it is acknowledged that the
poor participate in the "informal economy" in large numbers, n290 the goal here
is to teach the poor the more efficient forms of market participation inherent
in the formal transactions engaged in by mainstream society. Economists might
view this second structural conundrum as part of the systemic market failure
that occurs in the inner city, in that the costs to borrowers of transacting
business in the mainstream market are prohibitively high. n291 Other development
thinkers might see it as a broader, more systemic cousin of market failure. As I
discussed earlier, market failure, while clearly systemic, can be thought of as
a breakdown in one or more of several relatively well-defined characteristics of
a functioning market. However, some development thinkers acknowledge that, even
if there were a highly localized and informal market with many lower-income
buyers and sellers, homogenous products, breadth of knowledge, limited barriers
to market entry, and limited transaction costs, there might still be additional
barriers preventing the poor from moving beyond that market to integrate into
the more formal market of the middle and upper classes.

   For reasons that I will discuss shortly, the development community in the
United States has focused less directly on overcoming this more diffuse
structural problem. By contrast, in the Third World context, the Law and
Development movement has explored it at great length, in considering both the
greater impoverishment of Third World nations vis-a-vis the West, as well as the
plight of the poor vis-a-vis the more well off in those nations. At its
inception in the 1960s, the Law and Development movement sought to export to the
developing world the twin strategies of capitalism and democracy as a means of
"catching up" developing countries to the status enjoyed by the First  [*278]
World. n292 After significant reevaluation of its mission in the 1970s, n293 the
movement reemerged in the 1990s as an important locus for discussions about a
more inclusive yet still market-focused path to development. n294

   Perhaps the most specific embodiment of theories that address this diffuse
problem is a broad, indeed unifying, principle underlying the Law and
Development movement: that the "Rule of Law," broadly defined, catalyzes
economic development. In its most simplified (and idealized) form, a system
characterized by the Rule of Law might be described as one governed by a
comprehensive set of legal rules, imposed on governmental and non-governmental
actors alike, and enforced by independent arbiters exercising as little
discretion as possible. n295 The Law and Development movement assumes that
economic development toward a more efficient market occurs where the law is used
predictably and consistently to protect rights that otherwise would be protected
informally, and thus less efficiently. n296 Perhaps the most fundamental "right"
that the Law and Development movement seeks to protect formally is ownership of
private property. n297 However, this Article focuses predominantly on the
importance of clear, unambiguous contracts, rather than on the creation and
protection of private property rights. Integral to the efficiency of formal
property and contractual rights is the ability to assert and  [*279]  enforce
these rights under a set and predictable rule of law. In other words,
transactional formality assumes that a party who has been damaged by a breach of
contract will have the ability to enforce that contract, and to do so in an
independent and transparent forum. n298 Even more basically, transactional
formality assumes transparency concerning whether a contract actually exists and
what each party's rights are pursuant to the contract. n299

   The most articulate spokesperson for development efforts to help the poor
overcome informality is Hernando De Soto, who has argued that, by formalizing
ownership of property, developing countries can overcome the "mystery of
capital." De Soto claims that, by representing title to property in a simple
legal document, that property can be used by the poor for purposes beyond just
its physical purpose. In his words, "Any asset whose economic and social aspects
are not fixed in a formal property system is extremely hard to move in the
market ... . [This is] why the exchange of most assets outside the West is
restricted to local circles of trading partners." n300

   In the United States, it is hard to find programmatic efforts that focus
directly on solving the informality problem, despite the proliferation of street
vendors and other informal workers especially in urban areas. n301 Nonetheless,
some members of the CED and Law and Economics movements have incorporated
rhetoric about formality in their prescriptions for the poor, rhetoric which
reflects certain aspects of the Rule of Law. n302 With regard to the second
structural problem, then, there is a divergence in programmatic efforts between
Western developers overseas and the development community in the United States.
In addition, there is a divergence between rhetoric and programmatic efforts in
the United States.

   Yet, the limited number of explicit references to formality in U.S.
development circles, in my view, does not mean that U.S. development thinkers
find formality to be unimportant in economic transactions. On the contrary, the
apparent silence about formality evidences an implicit and  [*280]  foundational
assumption that formality not only is important to economic efficiency, but in
fact already exists almost everywhere in the United States. Consequently, the
Law and Development movement has often adopted the United States as a model
country for illustrating the importance of the Rule of Law to an economic
infrastructure.

   Furthermore, the programmatic emphasis on training in the United States can
be reasonably interpreted as an alternative strategy for addressing the very
same problem of formalized market participation that the development community
is trying to solve in the Third World. Thus, by teaching everything from
accounting skills to self-confidence, U.S. programs attempt to teach the poor
how to participate in the mainstream and formal market economy. In short, both
here and abroad, the development community is looking for creative new solutions
to the same intractable problem.

   Just as the Grameen Bank model has been heralded for solving the problem of
market failure, the model has also been applauded for integrating the poor into
the market by teaching them how to run their own small businesses. But here,
too, the success of the Bank's model is marginal. n303

   The Grameen Bank model's shortcoming in teaching market participation,
however, is of a different sort than in the case of market failure. The
shortcoming is not that the Bank's model fails to fix a problem that the Bank
claims it can fix. Rather, it is that the development community wrongly assumes
that the model will teach the poor the rules of formal market participation when
in fact the Bank's practices, as some of its own literature acknowledges, teach
the opposite. While it is almost inconceivable that the development community
has not really recognized this, the reason appears to be a reflexive assumption
that the Bank will inevitably achieve its professed goal of market integration
according to the rules that, in recent years, have been well-mapped - indeed
well-established - by the Law and Development movement abroad (and the Law and
Economics movement here). Among these rules is a move toward greater
transactional formality. As I will show, however, it appears that the Bank
simply has not been playing by the same rules. Thus, while it claims - as one of
its goals and achievements - the integration of the poor into the market, the
Bank does not profess to follow the same path to market integration, or indeed a
path to the same market, n304 as its Western admirers might expect.

   In analyzing the model's failure to solve this second structural problem, I
will focus on its failure to increase transactional formality. I do so with what
is in my view a well-founded assumption that this analysis is relevant to U.S.
efforts to transfer the model. This is so, first, because we ought to pay
attention to the effect of greater informality on a system (i.e., the  [*281]
U.S. economy) that assumes formality. n305 And second, as I will demonstrate,
some of my critiques apply equally to such U.S. programmatic efforts to
accomplish market integration as training.

   Rule of Law principles would hold that parties to a clear and unambiguous
written contract will behave more rationally and efficiently in an economic
transaction than will parties who do not have a written contract, because the
parties with a written contract will better be able to predict each other's
behavior and the outcome of a transaction. n306 Perhaps most importantly,
predictability is related to efficiency as it allows parties to leverage their
assets with less risk.

   Under the Rule of Law construct, the formalization of credit transactions
plays a critical role in increasing the efficiency of, and access to, markets.
It is through the loan transaction that the value of a physical asset expands
from its physical utility to the owner to its utility as collateral. n307
Moreover, it is the loan transaction that creates the leverage necessary to
generate what De Soto describes as the "surplus value" of capital. n308 The
logic here is that, to the extent a transaction can be effectuated pursuant to
the most simple and transparent set of rules, consistently applied, and enforced
without need of interpretation or discretion, information and other transaction
costs are reduced, confidence is inspired, and thus efficiency is increased.
n309 In the loan transaction, the medium through which these benefits are
obtained is the loan agreement. The more objective and simple that document is,
the easier it should be to enforce, and the more transparent and efficient the
loan transaction should be.

   Thus, one would expect development thinkers both here and in developing
countries to develop simple, enforceable, written n310 contracts to effectuate
credit transactions. The Grameen Bank's model does the opposite. n311 From the
perspective of increasing formality, the first troubling aspect of the Grameen
Bank model is its imposition of the Sixteen Decisions, particularly the
requirement that borrowers recite the Sixteen Decisions by memory to the  [*282]
loan officer as one of the conditions precedent to receiving a loan. n312 A
range of difficulties inheres in imposing this type of social development agenda
in the context of providing a financial service. The first is quite practical:
In order to maintain the formality of the transaction, the social development
requirements would naturally have to be included in the loan agreement in the
form of contractual conditions. This would mean including in a financial
services agreement the cultural equivalents of the Bank's directives prohibiting
dowry and requiring use of pit latrines. Such a contract would be difficult to
draft n313 and virtually impossible to enforce. It boggles the mind to think how
a court could or should interpret - let alone enforce - such behavioral
requirements. Would standards of reasonable behavior and best efforts suffice in
judging borrowers' compliance with a requirement that they, for example, refrain
from more than two drinks per day? These problems get worse as the conditions
become more abstract (e.g. "work hard" or "be disciplined"). n314 Moreover, the
greater costs of drafting and of enforcement would add transaction costs
atypical of mainstream transactions. n315

   There is very little precedent in mainstream transactions for requiring
non-business related behavioral changes in the form of conditions or
consideration. n316 Given the Grameen Bank's practice of lending money at
[*283]  market or even above-market rates of interest, it does not seem
far-fetched to describe such social conditioning requirements in a loan
agreement as imposing a double standard. The poor have to do more for their
loans, which are below-market in size and above-market in interest rate. n317

   One justification for imposing this double standard might be that it is
market-driven, in that lenders, even non-profit microlenders, will not lend to
the poor if their only protection comes in the form of market interest rates and
business-related conditions, unless such conditions are so burdensome that they
could never be met by would-be entrepreneurs. In other words, the argument in
support of behavioral conditions, as opposed to business conditions, may simply
be that the poor have an easier chance of complying with them. At the very
least, this assumption ought to be tested. Given the studies about the Grameen
Bank's questionable success in its social development agenda, and the costs of
enforcement, it is not at all clear that such conditions would be easier to
impose and enforce. n318

   U.S. microlenders have avoided including conditions like the Sixteen
Decisions in their loan transactions. Instead, their behavioral conditioning
comes in the form of training, usually as a prerequisite to obtaining a loan.
n319 However, the difficulties that I have outlined above apply equally to those
lenders whose training addresses problems such as self-confidence. n320 In
addition, even inclusion of business training as a condition of obtaining a loan
does not fully obviate the problem of increasing formal participation. The point
is that these conditions are still different from those required of mainstream
borrowers. n321

   Many of these questions are equally applicable to the solidarity circle,
which also serves to thwart transactional formality. On the surface, the  [*284]
solidarity circle may appear to mimic mainstream transactional concepts such as
guarantees and joint liability. n322 However this analogy breaks down upon
closer inspection. In effect, the solidarity circle replaces the need for
physical collateral with "social collateral." n323 The power of the solidarity
circle is precisely the ability of members to enforce repayment by means of
informal pressure. Practically speaking, this means that members of the circle
use their relational ties (and the verbal and potentially physical pressures
that accompany them) in place of the loan collection strategies that a
mainstream lender would employ pursuant to its contract, such as default
notices, debt acceleration, asset foreclosure and related judicial remedies.
n324 In other words, the solidarity circle creates a pocket of informality
within the formal loan transaction. n325

   Whatever U.S. admirers of the Bank's model may have been expecting, it is
clear that the Bank itself chose this device precisely because of its informal
and non-transparent character. The founder of the Bank extols the fact that the
Bank does not use any written loan documentation at all as a virtue of the
Bank's model, claiming that the Bank operates on trust rather than on legal
rights. n326 More recent studies suggest, however, that the Bank operates
neither on trust nor legal rights, but rather on the ability to leverage peer
pressure (and the resulting shame, ostracism, and threats) to the point of
eliminating its borrowers' options to do anything but repay.

   Again, if U.S. programs choose not to import this level of informality, but
nonetheless want to maintain something resembling the solidarity circle, then
they will have to face the difficulty of translating the circle methodology into
loan documentation. Will a certain level of pressure be acceptable? What will
the remedies be if arms are broken as a means of enforcing payment?

   And, equally important, who will enforce these remedies? If it is to be the
courts, then U.S. programs will have to define informality to some extent so
that courts know what to enforce. In the context of rotating credit
associations, Professor Lan Cao argues convincingly that, to leverage
informality to its maximum capacity, courts should leave enforcement entirely in
the hands of the local community. n327 To do so, however, risks the types of
vigilante justice discovered by some of the recent studies of the Grameen
[*285]  Bank. n328 In this regard, U.S. programs will essentially be choosing
between informality and the predictability and transparency that are the
(idealized) hallmark of the U.S. legal system.

   These problems aside, it is highly questionable whether this informal means
of enforcement could result in penetration of the mainstream market; it is not
one that would inspire confidence by mainstream commercial institutions. n329
Thus, if U.S. microlenders choose to import social conditioning and the
solidarity circle, then they must face the distinct possibility that the final
product of their efforts will be an alternative credit market for the poor, the
standards of which are quite different from those imposed on other businesses.
By importing social development into their microcredit contracts, microlenders
risk "muddying" their market-focused lessons. n330 By further capitalizing on
the unpredictability and lack of transparency of the solidarity circle device,
they prevent the poor from turning to formal legal institutions to enforce
bargained-for rights.

   Moreover, devices such as these fail to teach market participation by
example, which is purportedly one of the major goals of microlending both in
Bangladesh and in the United States. n331 Consider the difficulties faced by
graduates of microlending programs such as these when they first seek loans in
the mainstream credit market. Quite literally, they will face a completely new
set of rules for which they are completely unprepared. Indeed, if the real goal
of microlenders is to change the social behavior of borrowers, then it is hard
to classify their interest in borrowers as commercial at all. Following this
logic, microlenders would essentially have created a more politically palatable
form of social welfare - one that disguises economic maintenance as market
participation. n332

    [*286]  Lastly, from the perspective of market integration, the Grameen
Bank's focus on women as lending targets is only marginally useful, but
potentially quite damaging. The greatest opportunity for mischief results from
the combination of a formal loan document (in which the female borrower is
solely liable to the microlender), the informal solidarity circle (in which
female borrowers are subject to social pressures), and whatever unregulated
additional social pressures the female borrowers are subjected to at home
(including confiscation of loan funds by family members). It seems particularly
egregious to single out female borrowers to attain the goal of integrating poor
women and men into the mainstream market. Indeed, one has to wonder whether
these efforts are in fact decreasing options for women (as they arguably are in
Bangladesh), rather than fulfilling their purported goal of creating more
opportunities for women to participate in the mainstream economy. n333

   C. Social and Political Perspectives

 If, as I posited in the last section, U.S. microlenders are going to be forced
to choose between informality on the one hand and predictability and
transparency on the other as they consider importing the Grameen Bank model,
then one might at least hope that the model would capitalize on the benefits of
informality. And indeed, U.S. admirers of the model have associated its
informality with its ability to solve a third major structural problem of
development - that of cultural hegemony. Development thinkers both here and
abroad have for several decades recognized the importance of incorporating local
values and habits as a means of increasing the chances that their programs will
be adopted and sustained in new contexts. n334

   From their perspective, the Bank accomplishes indigenousness "beautifully,'
both in origin and in its ability to capture the indigenous behaviors of the
target population. n335 For example, by using peer pressure as a  [*287]
repayment mechanism, the Bank appears to incorporate, and indeed to rely on,
local values and cultural judgments about respectable behavior. The media has
reinforced the notion that the model was completely homegrown. Examples abound.
A local stool-maker inspired the Bank's founder to lend tiny amounts of money.
n336 The bank developed the solidarity circle in response to the local condition
of landless poverty. n337 The solidarity circle capitalizes on local notions of
shame. n338 The Sixteen Decisions were developed by borrowers at a national
conference. n339 The development community takes the indigenousness of the model
as an unquestioned fact. Thus, even if the model's informality impedes
integration into mainstream markets, at least the model might catalyze some
forms of market behavior that would "stick" long enough to benefit the local
population.

   As such, the model appears to be a significant improvement over the "one size
fits all" development models exported by the Law and Development movement in its
early years. n340 The model further appears progressive, modern, and even
post-colonial as it takes into account the different perspectives of the
respective target population. This deference to indigenousness, one might
assume, makes the model more likely to succeed. It not only avoids the costs
associated with cultural translation, n341 it also does not appear to be an
externally imposed program. The target population is thus more likely to welcome
and accept the model and will actually want the benefits flowing from successful
use of the model. n342 Moreover, although the model was developed specifically
for, and to a certain extent by, poor Bangladeshis, n343 some in the West
[*288]  apparently also assume that poor people in this country are sufficiently
similar to those in Bangladesh that the Grameen model will be workable here.
n344

   But indigenousness alone does not explain its tremendous appeal to developers
in the West. What the Western development community finds particularly
enthralling about the model is that the indigenous values that have been
discovered look so extraordinarily similar to Western values. This is a highly
potent combination. It appears that after years of experimentation by the
Grameen Bank and empirical research about the Bank's impact, the development
community has unearthed universalism as an empirical fact. It is little wonder
that development thinkers also assume that these values are therefore necessary
preconditions to economic development.

   1. Perceived Universalism

 Two particularly compelling commonalities between the Grameen Bank's values and
Western values are worth mentioning here, partly because they have caught the
imagination of influential development thinkers in the United States. First,
microcredit appears to encourage republicanism, the value of the individual's
direct participation in political processes. n345 Republicanism historically has
been connected with poverty reduction, because it has been assumed that property
interests, particularly those that engender economic "self-sufficiency" within a
community, create political investments within a community. n346 The microcredit
model fits republican values because it creates  [*289]  small, local businesses
whose owners, as a result of their business interests, are more likely to
participate in local community politics. Moreover, the solidarity circle could
be seen as modeling such behavior within the larger microcredit model by
subjecting even the process of obtaining a loan to a democratic process of
review and approval by one's peers.

   At least one member of the CED movement also analogizes the solidarity circle
to Max Weber's conception of the Protestant ethic. n347 By this reasoning, the
Grameen Bank's use of social collateral within a circle as a means of
surveillance by community members is a working example of the values of
constraint, discipline, and valorization of wealth that are central to the
Protestant ethic. n348 The success of this use of social collateral is
reinforced by the Sixteen Decisions, which include the directive to be
disciplined. n349

   2. Indigenousness Misperceived

 In this section, I suggest that the discovery of these extraordinary
commonalities is, in fact, too good to be true - that what appears to be
indigenous is a Western translation. I also demonstrate that what many in the
United States see as indigenous is, in many respects, their own values
super-imposed on the target population. In the next section, I suggest that what
results is a particularly unsatisfactory form of hybridity that is evidence of
anything but a universalism of values. It appears that the Bank regularly
facilitates this hybridization.

   There can be no more compelling demonstration of the false indigenousness of
the Bank's model than its use of women as a target population. First, the model
appears to be based on the perspective of male Bangladeshis, including both
Grameen Bank workers (over ninety percent of whom are men n350) and rural men in
Bangladesh. This perspective leaves out half of the culture and most of the
target population. For example, the solidarity circle methodology assumes a
context in which villagers have frequent contact with each other, over matters
of money as well as more social matters. This type of contact, however, occurs
regularly among male Bangladeshis and less often among females. n351 Moreover,
the Bank apparently  [*290]  assumes that such social pressure, while strong
because of the frequency of contacts, is not necessarily so strong that it will
result in complete social ostracism, including ostracism from the family,
ineligibility for marriage, and utter social immobility. These latter pressures
are of course those experienced by women, not men. n352

   The Bank's model is based on values, beliefs, and behavioral norms that are
largely male-centered. In effect, it is dealing with the problem of a double
minority by accounting for only one part of that status: that of Third World
male culture. It is ignoring the cultural and gender perspectives unique to
poor, female Bangladeshis. This, of course, is a classic mistake, one that
arises not only in many international development programs, n353 but also in
many U.S. programs and remedies ranging from welfare n354 to employment
discrimination n355 to pensions. n356 As I discuss below, it should come as no
surprise that the failure to account for women's perspectives results in some of
the negative consequences described by recent studies.

    [*291]  However, the inattention to female indigenous norms does not stop
there. The Bank does not simply adopt the Bangladeshi male perspective. n357 It
compounds the problem by superimposing on and through the model a more Western
perspective about women's rights, needs, and liberation. n358 For example, it
seems to assume, without question, that women want to start their own
microenterprises and that the views expressed by some Bangladeshi women that it
is not their place to handle money are patriarchal (imposed by men in their
society), sexist, and oppressive. n359 Further, it assumes that, by gaining
access to the formal economy, or at least to income generating activities, women
will have more freedom, rights, and self-confidence. n360 It seems at least
relevant to ask why, from the perspective of the target population, access to
the formal economy is desirable. n361 Will it actually lead to greater political
and social participation, or at least freedom to participate? Will it lead to
other protections? n362 Are any of these rights and protections desired by the
target population? n363 Similarly, would women choose to bear the primary
responsibility for poverty reduction assigned to them by the Grameen Bank as
natural and better fighters against poverty? n364 Defenders of the Grameen
Bank's use of women may argue that it is the only choice. This is an imperfect
answer. n365

    [*292]  It is my hope that these questions will allow the development
community, and its critics, to avoid essentializing Third World women - either
as capitalists or as anti-capitalists, as victims of poverty or as "natural and
better fighters." Indeed, until these questions are answered, I may be guilty of
essentializing target populations in my own assumptions. n366

   Perhaps it is this inattention to women's perspectives that leads the Bank to
choose a means of achieving the goal of women's independence and liberation,
defined on the basis of Western values, that arguably contradicts that very
goal. Of the numerous studies that have lauded the solidarity circle, very few
have discussed the benefit to, or impact on, the primarily female borrowers,
focusing instead on the primarily male lenders' perspectives. n367 Moreover,
those studies that have discussed the impacts on women have discussed the
potential for teaching business judgment and networking, or the potential of the
Bank's social development program, without digging deeper to ask whether such
gains are desired by the target population. n368 In Bangladesh at least, the
choice of the solidarity circle as a means of lending money in a commercially
sound manner arguably decreases women's independence and takes advantage of -
indeed increases - their social and economic vulnerability. Again, according to
a number of studies about the Bank, a significant majority of the time female
borrowers lose control of their loan funds and never start their own income
generating activities, while remaining solely liable for repayment of such
funds. n369 Thus the solidarity circle, and the lending process more generally,
leads to greater social dependence and vulnerability of female borrowers.

   Moreover, the Sixteen Decisions or equivalent social development techniques
may not suffice to counterbalance the non-indigenous nature of the solidarity
circle. First, the Bank's claim of indigenous origin of the Sixteen Decisions
warrants investigation. While it may certainly be true that the Sixteen
Decisions were developed by a group of female borrowers who  [*293]  advanced to
leadership positions in the Bank's structure, n370 it seems presumptuous to
conclude that the directive to limit the size of families is an acceptance by
borrowers of the various forms of birth control and other population control
initiatives propounded by the Bank. It is a very real question whether the
Sixteen Decisions actually incorporate the perspectives of the majority of
borrowers. n371

   Second, both the Bank and a number of U.S. organizations appear to assume
that female borrowers benefit more from social development, in the form of
counseling to develop self-confidence for example, than do men. n372 It is not
clear, however, that anyone has ever tested this assumption by trying similar
models on poor men. Finally, one has to wonder whether U.S. programs choose
women as a target population primarily because it is more comfortable for the
development community - or the lending community - to do so. n373

   Rather than challenging the Bank's failure to incorporate Bangladeshi women's
perspectives and values, Western admirers believe that the Bank has succeeded in
this regard. This is understandable: None of the news reports appear to cite
studies about whether the borrowers really want to be running small businesses
(as opposed to being relieved to have more cash, however temporary its benefit).
Additionally, Western assumptions about Bangladeshi society feed into their
misperceptions about the success of the Bank's model. In other words, Western
admirers assume true indigenousness. They assume that Bangladeshi women want to
be empowered, independent, and entrepreneurial, just as they assume that
American women hold these values.

   The result of imposing the Grameen Bank model on women, both in Bangladesh
and here, without accounting for their own perspectives and values, may well be
a terrible synergy. In Bangladesh, the result has been further marginalization
of women as a cost of increasing income levels. As I described earlier, the
benefits - to the lenders of having more "submissive" borrowers and to
non-profit enterprises of capitalizing on women's "instincts" to serve their
families over themselves - have been attained directly at the  [*294]  women's
expense. n374 Such marginalization has included the gravest social harms, such
as domestic violence and suicide. n375 U.S. programs that wish to continue to
follow the Grameen Bank's gendered approach must proceed with great care. Even
if they conclude that problems such as loss of control of loan funds and undue
pressuring of borrowers are solvable, they must confront the fact that
overcoming these problems will require a very different kind of program than the
one-time infusion of capital contemplated by politicians and the popular press
in this country. n376

   V. Narcissism: The True Face of Microcredit?

 What I hope to have demonstrated by now is that what appeared to be true
indigenousness in the Grameen Bank's model is in fact a complex and detrimental
form of hybridity. This failure of indigenousness implicates the model's
efficacy in Bangladesh and, in a far more complicated way, threatens its
importation to the U.S. inner city.

   A. Hybridity as a Product of Narcissism and the Problem of Double Translation


 I attempt in this section to define hybridity and to map out the extent to
which it affects the Grameen Bank's model. I then suggest some of the questions
that are raised thereby. n377

   I use the term hybridity to describe the combination of Eastern and Western
components that comprise the Grameen Bank's model. My claim is that, rather than
reflecting only the values, practices, and mores of Bangladeshi women, the model
combines Bangladeshi customs with more foreign beliefs. But my claim is also
more specific. The secret to the model's appeal to the West is in its particular
combination of East and West. Purposefully or not, the model presents itself in
such a way that Western admirers of the model readily see in the model only what
they want to see. Thus they look for, and are encouraged to find, core Western
values such as empowerment, independence, economic value, and individual rights.
In fact, what they see are local cultural practices that they "read" as evidence
of the existence of those values. For  [*295]  example, it appears that no one
has ever surveyed female Grameen borrowers to ask them whether they want to own
and run small businesses - or even if they want independent economic standing in
their society. But they have seen women running small businesses and handling
money. Rather than questioning whether such behavior is evidence of other core
values, Westerners assume that it is evidence of their own core values of
independence and empowerment. n378 A more manipulative form of this occurs when
development experts go beyond "reading" cultural practices as evidence of core
values to actually using those practices to uphold core Western values. Both
forms, I believe, are undergirded by the further assumption that development
simply cannot be accomplished without these basic values as a prerequisite.

   By failing to ask the real questions about core values, the Western
development community succeeds in seeing a reflection of itself. This is nothing
more or less than narcissism. Its troubling nature may best be understood by
mapping exactly where East meets West - a place, as I will suggest, where
Western values are serviced by Eastern practices. n379

   In some important respects, the Grameen Bank model is not only male-centered,
it also is not clearly Bangladeshi. In raising this concern, I wish to do more
than point out that the founder of the Bank was educated in the United States.
n380 I question whether the very notion of credit in support of microenterprise
is indigenous. In Bangladesh, there is significant evidence that it is not. The
most obvious support for this conclusion is that Islam, which includes its own
legal codes, forbids the giving of credit in return for interest. n381  [*296]
Moreover, cultural Islamic notions about purdah forbid women from working
outside the home. n382 In addition to these two well-known and significant
facts, I would expect an anthropologist to uncover much more evidence of the
foreign-ness of aspects of the Grameen Bank model. And, indeed, Aminur Rahman
has. n383

   The Grameen Bank knows that some of its work is contrary to, in fact
challenges, local culture. n384 However, this fact seems somehow to have been
glossed over by most U.S. observers when they claim that the Grameen Bank's
invention of microcredit is evidence of its indigenous roots. On the other hand,
the notion of credit in support of enterprise is completely indigenous to
Western (majority) culture. Indeed, the main attraction of microcredit in the
United States is its involvement of marginal populations in the market-based
practices of the majority. Thus, without a very complete picture of the Grameen
Bank's work, Western admirers assume that they have found a non-Western model to
accomplish a Western, market-oriented goal: providing credit to individuals so
that they can start their own small businesses.

   Moreover, it is not at all clear that the Grameen Bank's solidarity circle
methodology is indigenous. In making this claim, I acknowledge the existence of
rotating credit associations ("RCAs"), which appear to be wholly indigenous in
their formation. n385 However, simply by virtue of its institutionalization by
the Grameen Bank, this indigenous device for obtaining credit is changed in
important ways. n386 First, in contrast to the "typical" RCA, members of the
solidarity circle do not pool their own resources and then take turns borrowing
from the pool (i.e., from each other). n387 Instead, solidarity circle members
borrow from an entity that is only nominally (for financial and management
purposes, anyway) owned by its borrowers. n388 Thus, the  [*297]  incentives
required to induce people to repay their loans have to be different. For
example, solidarity circle members are motivated to pressure each other to pay
on time because of the rule that prevents them from getting their own loans
until their circle members repay their respective loans. By contrast, in the
RCA, the motivation appears to be much more socially driven, relating to duty,
shame and reputation. n389 Second, RCAs develop their own rules for borrowing
and management in general, while the Grameen Bank sets strict rules for
borrowers. n390 Thus, the solidarity circle uses "social collateral" for the
more limited purposes of screening, monitoring and enforcement, but not for
institutional management. Third, arguably none of the institutional concerns of
maintaining or attaining self-sufficiency exist in the RCA. n391 Fourth, as
Professor Cao suggests, RCAs are dependent upon the existence of a homogenous,
cohesive community with well-developed social norms. While such a community may
not require a common ethnicity, Professor Cao's analysis suggests that in the
United States RCAs are unique to immigrant communities precisely because of the
key role played by ethnic ties. n392 It may be plausible to develop a
microlending program that more closely mimics the values and procedures of RCAs.
Such a program, however, would perform a much more limited function than that
attempted by the Grameen Bank.

   The institutionalization of the Sixteen Decisions triggers similar concerns.
The Sixteen Decisions were developed by a group of female borrowers, most of
whom were leaders of their local loan centers, at a national conference in 1984.
n393 But the mere fact of indigenous origin does not prove that the Sixteen
Decisions are representative of the beliefs of the target population. n394
Further, their adoption for use by the Bank results in a potentially inorganic
permanence. Had they been developed by the circle, they could be changed by the
circle, whenever and as often as the circle desired.

   The intervention of the Grameen Bank in what may at one time have been
indigenous practices adds foreign motives, beliefs and practices, some of
[*298]  which look decidedly Western. n395 For example, the solidarity circle
"looks like" a laboratory for cultivating social and even political
organization, creating community bonds, and seeking to democratize, where such
tendencies may have previously been latent or even nonexistent. n396 Similarly,
the Grameen directive to exercise discipline in all aspects of living reflects
the Weberian view that the Protestant ethic is the foundation for
entrepreneurial (and capitalist) behavior. n397

   Let me be clear: My point here is not that the Bank's arguments against
certain cultural barriers are inherently unsound. Nor am I saying that values
such as wealth maximization, freedom, and independence are definitively not
shared by Bangladeshi women. Further, I am not suggesting that the solidarity
circle and the Sixteen Decisions would be acceptable if they were truly
indigenous in origin and values. n398 Rather, I am arguing in favor of a truly
participatory decision either to reject indigenous practices or to uphold
certain values (or to create a hybrid program), a decision that must be made
first and foremost by the targets of the Bank's development program. I am also
claiming that a lack of indigenousness contributes to the failure of the Bank's
methodology, both in Bangladesh and in the United States.

   It is important to note that hybridity is not just limited to Western
attempts to uphold indigenous values - to the extent values can be distinguished
from the pragmatic question of whether a model works in an economic, political,
or social sense. If we look at the model's ability to solve the structural
problems of market failure and lack of formal market participation, a similar
theme of hybridity emerges. Specifically, it seems fair to describe the lending
relationship embodied in the Grameen transaction as being between a lender who
fits the description of a typical Western commercial institution and a Third
World borrower. The particular concern of the Grameen Bank to ensure that it, as
the lender, complies with the rigors of market-based behavior is a Western
notion. In some important respects, the Bank's lending practices are explicitly
modeled on those of commercial banks. n399

    [*299]  In addition, as U.S. admirers consider importing the Grameen Bank
model to solve the problems of market failure by means of market integration,
their ultimate hope (as discussed earlier) is to integrate the poor into the
mainstream, and very Western, market surrounding the inner city enclaves. n400
While U.S. programs attempt to leverage social collateral as a means of ensuring
repayment, their primary aim is to increase participation in a form of
entrepreneurial behavior and market participation defined by Western standards.

   Again, there are some disturbing implications about the precise point at
which East meets West. For example, it is particularly troubling that the
Western lender imposes on the Eastern borrower n401 some of the transaction
costs typically borne by Western lenders. n402 It is appropriate to ask whether
the Grameen Bank or Western lenders would impose different standards on
mainstream borrowers. Might there be alternative models of market participation
indigenous to the practices of the target population? There are also concerns
about the choice of exactly which Western practices to keep and which to replace
with Eastern practices. The most relevant question is why so many in the West
are drawn to a means of poverty reduction that reinforces the notion of the free
(and fair) market developed in and by the West.

   Hybridity also impacts the objective of formalized market participation
sought by the Law and Development movement. Recall that the very notion of
formality is attributed by that movement to American legal liberalism. n403
Again, the trouble occurs where the cultures meet. Consider, for example, the
solidarity circle, an ostensibly indigenous device, here used to serve Western
economic behavior. By shifting the risk (in addition to the transaction costs)
of extra-judicial enforcement from the lender to the borrowers, the circle
preserves the formalized market participation of the Western lender while
compromising that of the borrowers. n404 The Bank's social development agenda
raises similar issues, entirely directed to changing the behaviors of borrowers.
n405 Yet microlenders would consider it ludicrous to try to change their own
behaviors in order to meet borrowers half way.

   The confounding effects of Westerners' assumption that they have discovered
universal values do not end with this detrimental form of hybridity. Rather,
because Western development thinkers assume they have uncovered a universal form
of indigenousness, they assume that they can import the model to an entirely new
context without questioning whether there is a match in  [*300]  values. This
assumption compounds the effects of hybridity into a problem of double
translation. These Western thinkers have exported their values for purposes of
developing the less developed in other countries, and now enthusiastically are
re-importing those values encased in a newly indigenized form for purposes of
developing the less developed here.

   At the very least, these problems of hybridity and double translation raise
some broad concerns about the model's potential for success in the U.S. inner
city. By assuming that they have imported an indigenous model, Western programs
may have blinded themselves to its potentially negative consequences. It is
simplistic to reason that, because it worked there, surely it will work here on
a seemingly similar (i.e., poor) population. It may be insidiously easy to
superimpose foreign values on a form that Western programs believe is indigenous
while simultaneously - and fortuitously - matching Western values. n406

   In addition to the apparent lack of indigenousness of some aspects of the
Grameen Bank model, the implications surrounding the true nature of the values
embedded in the model are equally important. We must ask whether a program is in
fact indigenous (and by implication incorporates universal values), or instead
is simply based on Western values exported to the East and now re-imported.
Equally critical is whether, and to what extent, the non-indigenous values are
meaningful to the target population - not only in Bangladesh but also in the
U.S. inner city. Ultimately, it seems fair to ask whether the Grameen Bank has
simply developed a more sophisticated version of the "one size fits all"
development schemes appropriately rejected by Law and Development scholars three
decades ago. n407 If this is the case, then we can anticipate that if poor women
in the United States do not succeed as well as poor women in Bangladesh, they
will be further stigmatized for their failures.

   These questions and concerns must be asked separately in Bangladesh and in
the United States. While the above analysis implicates the success of the
Grameen Bank's model in Bangladesh, the question of whether Western values might
impair the model's success in the U.S. inner city is more complicated. This is
because U.S. inner cities surely must have more claim to Western values as
indigenous values than does rural Bangladesh. Hence, the first question to be
answered is what values are indigenous to the U.S. inner city. This is a broad
question that can only be answered specifically and thus  [*301]  incrementally.
Each inner city is different and diverse, not only geographically, but in
constituencies. n408

   The second question flows from the first. We surely must ask why Western
developers adopted a model for poverty reduction and market integration that
they exported to the Third World and then re-imported. In other words, is our
understanding of indigenousness somehow dependent on Eastern origin? More
broadly, to what extent does indigenousness of origin matter? It might be at
this point that we could begin to understand whether, as so many seem to assume
implicitly, certain values are universally shared by the poor. Hence the
expectation that the inner city poor in this country will be entrepreneurial and
value market participation as much as Westerners assume the rural poor in
Bangladesh do.

   The third question in this inquiry is likely the most difficult to answer:
What kind of a model would we develop based on inner city indigenous values? To
what extent would it resemble the Grameen Bank model? To what extent would it
resemble rotating credit associations? To what extent would it leverage
informality? Would it produce an alternative conception of the market?

   B. The Important Relationship Among CED, Law and Development,
Post-Colonialists and Feminists

 As the story of the Grameen Bank has emerged, so, too, has a connection between
two movements that previously had little to do with each other. In this section,
I briefly describe the connection between the CED and Law and Development
movements, with the hope that more comparative analysis of the two will advance
both their causes. I also suggest that some of the answers they seek,
particularly concerning indigenousness, may best be explored with the help of
the critical thinking of post-colonialist and feminist scholars.

   As should be clear by now, both the CED and Law and Development movements
historically have been concerned with integration of the poor into the market
and, relatedly, with elimination of market failure. In addition, both movements
share a concern with social and political development as a corollary of economic
development. Proponents within the two movements have even justified development
choices with similar theoretical arguments. However, these movements have had
little cross-pollination. n409 In some respects, that may not be a problem. One
of the clearest lessons from our  [*302]  experience with the Grameen Bank thus
far is that careless hybridization may cause more harm than benefit.

   Nonetheless, there is still a place for collaborative work between the two
movements. First, a collaboration between CED and Law and Development might
allow the latter movement to test Law and Development theory in the U.S. inner
city, which should be the perfect laboratory for developing and testing
market-based solutions to poverty because of the ease of empirical study. n410
Additionally, at least theoretically, there should be fewer problems associated
with cultural translation in a society where the ideals of a free market and
entrepreneurialism are so embedded. My goal here is to impose analytical rigor
in testing prescriptions that have previously been unavailable for testing.

   Second, perhaps because of the pressures of globalization, the two movements
may be able to share knowledge about processes for reaching similar goals. For
example, assuming that indigenousness remains an important ingredient in any
development program, the two movements may be able to share valuable
information, not about what indigenousness means, but rather about the process
by which to unearth it. Similarly, the two movements can and should be asking
many of the same questions about the market. n411

   Finally, there are issues concerning which neither movement has much
sophistication. Indigenousness is a prime example here, too. In my own analysis,
I have relied on two sets of literatures that I propose should be used much more
extensively by both movements: post-colonial studies n412 and feminist studies.
In particular, post-colonial discussions of indigenousness are  [*303]  among
the most advanced. n413 Indeed, this school has developed its own notion of
hybridity, which may serve as an important counterpoint to the hybridity
discussed in this Article. n414 Thus, it is my hope that these two schools will
help development thinkers begin to uncover a path toward understanding the
aspects of any development program that might or might not be representative of
the target population's views.

   VI. Toward A More Nuanced Vision

 My purpose in unpacking the myth of the Grameen Bank is to contribute in the
most pragmatic way to discussions about market-based solutions to poverty,
rather than deconstructing them. Thus, I do not mean to suggest that the Western
development community's interest in transferability is irremediably misguided.
Nor do I mean to suggest that hybridity is inevitably the source of hegemony, or
that the search for indigenousness is hopeless. Instead, what I argue here is
that the particular aggregation of values in the microcredit model of
market-based poverty reduction, and more specifically the Grameen Bank's
microcredit model, appears headed for failure. n415 It is both premature and
unwarranted for the development community to put so much faith and so many
resources into a strategy that has thus far not proven successful.

   First, it seems clear that indigenousness must be part of any solution. The
successful use of rotating credit associations, as distinguished from the
hybridized solidarity circle, supports this conclusion; but so do many other
indigenous initiatives. One example is the cooperative self-help groups formed
by women in many parts of Asia and Africa. n416 Another is the success of street
vendors as informal business people in their Harlem communities, as described by
Regina Austin. n417 By her account, "in places like New York City,  [*304]
Washington, D.C., and Philadelphia, most black street vendors work without a
license and in violation of applicable vending regulations and sales tax laws."
n418 As the development community continues to look for truly indigenous
representation in the solutions it develops, I propose that it start from the
premise that a social development agenda, in any institutionalized form, cannot
be indigenous. As my analysis has demonstrated, such an agenda is simply too
fraught with hegemonic tendencies.

   Moreover, the quest for indigenousness must be considerably more refined and
more penetrating than current efforts, such as the Sixteen Decisions. The
development community should no longer avoid seeking specific economic,
political and social agendas that are indigenous to its target populations.
Analogies should no longer suffice. Development thinkers must ask the difficult
questions about what members of their target population actually want. In asking
these questions, they may get some surprising answers. For example, Rebecca
Johnson of Cooperative Economics for Women in Boston found that some of her
clients did not want ultimately to own and run microenterprises, but rather
wanted different forms of permanent income generation. n419 The indigenousness
of process that U.S. organizations believe the Grameen Bank model provides
cannot substitute for indigenousness of values.

   The Harlem street vendors described by Regina Austin may well represent this
more refined indigenousness. These entrepreneurs clearly do not have imposed on
them the social development agenda of any development institution. Moreover, it
is simply wrong to suggest that they are not participating in the social, and
perhaps even political, community in which they live and work. As is the case
with the Bangladeshi stool maker, it is not clear whether their choice of
occupation is indeed freely made. However, it is clear that these businesses are
a more organic form of market participation, not dictated by development
institutions. n420

   It seems worth inquiring whether, in a place such as Harlem, a more
successful means of economic development would be to facilitate, in effect
incubate, such examples of wholly home-grown entrepreneurship, rather than to
impose the social development agendas, or even market-based conditions, that
U.S. organizations currently dictate. With training that U.S. programs provide,
for example, comes the formality and learned institutional behavior that might
rob these small businesses of the survival skills with which they began.
Instead, perhaps a more effective means of incubation, one that would better
preserve indigenousness, would be to eliminate some of the regulatory
limitations, including laws prohibiting vending and requiring permits, which
[*305]  currently prevent street vendors from stabilizing their businesses. n421
Such a strategy would require consideration of whether informality may be a
potentially useful, even beneficial, feature of market participation by the
poor.

   Second, the development community must reach a much more clear understanding
of "the market" before it can begin to define a path toward integrating the poor
into the market. Before it fixes market failures, it must know which markets to
fix. Before it increases participation, it must anticipate the outcomes of such
participation. In other words, it must wrestle with the ambivalence described by
Kenneth Anderson in his discussion of the unstated goals and assumptions of
microlenders. n422 It must agree upon which market it seeks to create for the
poor, or alternatively, into which market it seeks to integrate the poor. This
inquiry must be guided by local desires.

   I suspect that once development thinkers take this first important step, they
will also have a clearer picture of appropriate regulations of the market.
Perhaps regulatory efforts will be directed to market participants other than
the poor. Thus, if the ultimate goal based on indigenous agendas is market
integration of Harlem's street vendors, development thinkers could look for
alternatives to regulating the vendors at the inception of their businesses.
Instead, in the context of incubating informality, it might be more appropriate
to regulate the participation in inner city markets of more established
businesses (the Wal-Marts and chain grocery stores, for example), at least for
the limited purpose of allowing vendors to establish themselves before facing
these national competitors. n423 Such regulations could be as diverse as zoning
limitations n424 and tariffs. n425

    [*306]  Of course, if integration into a larger market is the appropriate
goal, development thinkers will need to consider the proper moment at which to
end the incubation period. At some point, such businesses will have to accept
the greater level of formality that will inevitably be required in order to
participate in the global market. In addition, such businesses will have to
survive in competition with the larger businesses participating in the same
market. This can and should be an appropriate subject for regulatory efforts.

   Alternatively, development thinkers might conclude that even more regulation
of the target population is necessary. If so, they would have to accept the
increased burden to ensure that such regulation would be representative of
indigenous values and goals. This might not be impossible. For example, there
might be specific contexts in which it would be truly representative of an inner
city population to form businesses using a cooperative model. This type of
development would entail a very different role for lawyers involved in the
effort. Rather than working to eliminate regulations that limit small
businesses, while establishing further regulations on larger businesses, lawyers
would perform more transactional work, such as ensuring proper formation,
representation and regulation of the cooperative form of business. n426

   As a final lesson, the development community must tread carefully in choosing
a hybrid model. Simply put, any reliance on its own values likely means the
displacement of indigenousness. This too should be a presumption. For example,
development thinkers should question the consequences of a goal such as CED's
goal of involving mainstream businesses in poverty reduction. While laudable,
such a goal has resulted in over-deference to the "rights" of free market
participation of such businesses - directly at the expense of the needs of
would-be entrepreneurs. The development community ought to deal skeptically with
the assumption that values, goals and agendas are universal.

   The unfortunate consequence of this last lesson is that it simply may not be
possible to attain the appealing level of hybridity, the overall aggregation of
values, that the microcredit model appears to attain. This is because such an
extraordinary aggregation comes at the expense of indigenousness. For example,
development programs may have to choose market integration over indigenousness
or vice versa. I hope that the choices will not be so stark, but the development
community should acknowledge that possibility. Failure to do so risks exactly
the kinds of negative consequences that the microcredit model seductively
appeared to avoid.

tremendous relevance to this Article. See discussion infra Part V.B. See, e.g.,
Hernando de Soto, The Other Path: The Invisible Revolution in the Third World
passim (1989); Paul W. Kahn, The Cultural Study of Law: Reconstructing Legal

context); Chandra Talpade Mohanty et al., Third World Women and the Politics of
Feminism passim (1991); Amy L. Chua, Markets, Democracy, and Ethnicity: Toward a
New Paradigm for Law and Development, 108 Yale L. J. 1, passim (1998) (using the
terms "First World" and "West" interchangeably); Rebecca Johnson, Welfare/Social
Justice: Where Do We Go from Here?, 19 W. New Eng. L. Rev. 41, passim (1997)
(comparing programs used to improve the economic situations of women in "Third
World" countries to programs used to aid impoverished women in the United
States); Audrey G. McFarlane, Race, Space, and Place: The Geography of Economic
Development, 36 San Diego L. Rev. 295, 298-303 (1999) (examining how

Bureau, Current Population Reports, Money Income in the United States: 1999
(2000), available at http://www.census.gov (last visited Apr. 23, 2005). In
addition, in 1995, the top 10% of U.S. households owned 71.8% of all household
wealth. Lisa A. Keister, Wealth in America 64 (2000). The widening gaps appear
to affect the working poor as well as the very poor. Steven A. Holmes, Children
Of Working Poor Are Up Sharply, Study Says, N.Y. Times, June 4, 1996, at C19
(suggesting that globalization negatively affects the working poor, who are
generally less skilled). These trends are reflected overseas as well. See, e.g.,
Globalization Challenge Initiative, Growing Danger of Economic Apartheid: How
the World Bank Group's Private Sector Development (PSD) Strategy Threatens Basic
Service Provision (Health, Education and Water), Debt Reduction and PRSP
Processes, Sept. 2001, at 1 ("In country after country, efforts [through loan
conditionalities] by the World Bank Group to privatize health, education, and
water systems are pushing the costs of public services out of the reach of
ordinary people."); Mahmood Monshipouri, Promoting Universal Human Rights:
Dilemmas of Integrating Developing Countries, 4 Yale Hum. Rts. & Dev. L.J. 25,
32 (2001) ("Even those analysts who stress the tremendous potential benefits
that globalization has for developing countries, warn about the ways in which
globalization exacerbates inequality and heightens social

David Sanders & Mickey Chopra, Globalization and the Challenge of Health for
All: A View from Sub-Saharan Africa, in Health Impacts Of Globalization: Towards
Global Governance 105, 118 (K. Lee ed., 2003) ("The forces of
globalization...have had continuing negative impacts on poor families and on
their social safety net, including basic health care."). See generally Michel
Chossudovsky, The Globalization of Poverty: Impacts of the IMF and World Bank
Reforms (1997) (discussing the increases of corporate assets, global poverty,
income inequality, and environmental depletion vis-a-vis the history of the IMF
and World Bank). But see David Dollar & Aart Kraay, Spreading the Wealth,
Foreign Aff., Jan.-Feb. 2002, at 120, 120-21 ("The current wave of
globalization, which started around 1980, has actually promoted economic
equality and reduced poverty....In general, higher growth rates in globalizing
developing countries have translated into higher incomes for the poor.").

   Unless otherwise specified, I use the terms "poor" and "poverty" to refer to
the working poor and the poorest of the poor. Moreover, I typically intend my
usage to be broad enough in scope to encompass both technical definitions of the
terms based on such things as income levels as well as more common usage.





n3.  See Holmes, supra note 2; Hope Lewis, Global Intersections: Critical Race

n4.  By development communities, I mean those scholars and practitioners who
develop the theories and implement the programs of economic development. By
"economic development," which I will use interchangeably with "development," I
mean attempts to erase class differences among individuals by increasing the
economic (and thus social) status of low-income individuals. Therefore, my use
of the terms "economic development" and "development" encompasses initiatives
both in the United States and in the developing world.





n5.  I use the term "mainstream" throughout this Article to refer to a market
that is not subject to widespread or consistent market failure and/or to the
market in which the middle and upper classes participate. I use this term to
maintain consistent terminology with others who have written about problems of
market failure in the credit market and lack of access by the poor to the credit
market. See William H. Simon, The Community Economic Development Movement 50
(2001) (describing the Grameen bank as lending to "a huge class of rural women
who had been written off as uncreditworthy by mainstream lenders"); Lan Cao,
Looking at Communities and Markets, 74 Notre Dame L. Rev. 841, 848 (1999)
(discussing certain immigrant communities' lack of access to credit from
"mainstream, majority-owned banks"); Louise A. Howells, The Dimensions of
Microenterprise: A Critical Look at Microenterprise as a Tool to Alleviate
Poverty, 9 J. Affordable Housing & Community Dev. L. 161, 161 (2000) ("Because
of their focus on very small businesses, microenterprise programs have filled a
significant credit gap, extending credit to small businesses overlooked by
mainstream lenders."); Jameel Jaffer, Microfinance and the Mechanics of
Solidarity Lending: Improving Access to Credit through Innovations in Contract

"the mainstream banking sector"); Susan R. Jones, Representing the Poor and

Attorneys as Partners in Community Economic Development: Creating Wealth for

U.N. GAOR, 52d Sess., 77th plen. mtg., U.N. Doc. A/RES/52/194 (1998) (stating
that "microcredit programmes have proved to be an effective tool in freeing
people from the bondage of poverty, and have led to their increasing

n6.  The development communities that I discuss most are the Community Economic
Development movement, which focuses on development in the United States, and the

n8.  I use the terms microcredit, microlending and microfinance to refer to the
making of small loans of $ 25,000 or less in the United States. See The Aspen
Institute, 2002 Directory of U.S. Microenterprise Programs xii (2002) (using the
same loan amount); Susan R. Jones, Small Business and Community Economic
Development: Transactional Lawyering for Social Change and Economic Justice, 4

Grameen Foundation USA, at http://www.gfusa.org/index.html (last visited June
24, 2005) (describing microcredit as the providing of tiny loans, often under $
100). In this Article, unless I specify otherwise, I refer to microenterprise
organizations or programs synonymously with microcredit, microlending, or
microfinance organizations or programs. My usage is typical of that in the
United States, although many increasingly describe microfinance and
microenterprise organizations as providing a broader range of services,
including a focus on savings, training, or "technical assistance" rather than on
lending. See Ayse Can Talen et al., The Future of Microfinance in the United
States: Research, Practice and Policy Perspectives, in Replicating Microfinance
in the United States 331, 333 (James H. Carr & Zhong Yi Tong eds., 2002). As I
use the term, a microenterprise is a newly created, or start-up, business with
less than $ 15,000 in start-up capital and with little access to the commercial
banking sector. See Jones, supra, at 196 n.3 (defining a microenterprise as a
business that can use a loan of under $ 15,000); Lewis D. Solomon,
Microenterprise: Human Reconstruction in America's Inner Cities, 15 Harv. J.L. &
Pub. Pol'y 191, 192 (1992) (defining a microenterprise as a business with less
than $ 5,000 in start-up capital). See also Talen et al., supra, at 331, 334.

n29.  See, e.g., Margareth Etienne, Addressing Gender-Based Violence in an
