Grameen Bank has provided an opportunity for women to achieve previously
unimaginable goals and to promote change in their own lives and the lives of
other women...enabling women to fulfill their roles as "the real agents of
change in rural society.'"). See also Katherine Spengler, Expansion of Third
World Women's Empowerment: The Emergence of Sustainable Development and the
Evolution of International Economic Strategy, 12 Colo. J. Int'l Envtl. L. &
Pol'y 303, 340 (quoting the World Resources Institute: "the achievement of
sustainable development is inextricably bound up with the establishment of
women's equality; one cannot be accomplished without the other"). There have
also been a number of feminist critiques of microlending. See, e.g., Press
Release, Susy Cheston, Senior Vice President for Policy and Research,
Opportunity International, Women and Microfinance: Opening Markets and Minds
(Feb. 5, 2004), available at
http://usinfo.state.gov/journals/ites/0204/ijee/cheston.htm (last visited Apr.
12, 2005) (suggesting that while microfinancing can serve as a model for
empowering women and alleviating poverty, it, along with other microfinancing
institutions, may serve to reify certain cultural and gender stereotypes: "The
very microfinance industry that has served women so phenomenally well
nevertheless runs up against the same cultural barriers found throughout
society. Grameen Bank in Bangladesh, a groundbreaker in reaching women clients,
for many years has maintained between 5 and 10 percent female loan officers.");
Taylor, supra note 20, at 327 ("Loan circles can deepen poor women's enmeshment
in traditional relationships of domination.").





n30.  See, e.g., Simon, supra note 5, at 52-54 (discussing the transferability
of the solidarity circle and social development agenda); Jones, supra note 5, at
389-91 (discussing the success of the Grameen Bank model); Morin, supra note 5,
at 133-36 (discussing the transferability of the Grameen Bank model).





n31.  Although the two are not the same, particularly in social science
literature, I use the terms "income generation" and "job creation"
interchangeably because that is the norm in legal scholarship. It also appears
to be the norm in the microcredit industry in the United States.





n32.  Solomon, supra note 8, at 194-95 (stating that the Grameen Bank "has
successfully tested the hypothesis that the poor can engage in productive
self-employment if supplied with capital") (internal citations omitted); Abu N.
M. Wahid, The Grameen Bank and Poverty Alleviation in Bangladesh: Theory,
Evidence and Limitations, 53 Am. J. Econ. & Soc. 1, 6 (1994) (discussing the
Grameen Bank's success at creating jobs). More broadly, microcredit has been
touted as a job creation mechanism. See, e.g., Servon, supra note 20, at 4
("Public officials at all levels in the United States are clamoring for ways to
move poor people from public dependency to self-sufficiency, and the
microenterprise strategy, with its bootstrap logic and impressive record in the
developing world, has emerged as a promising front-runner in the race for new
ideas."); Morin, supra note 5, at 132 (discussing "job creation CED strategies
such as micro-enterprise development that can successfully help poor people make
the transition from an era of entitlements to an era of "self-help'"); Skip
Kaltenheuser, Fitting Microcredit into a Macro Picture, Christian Science
Monitor, Feb. 5, 1997, at 19 (quoting a representative of Citibank, a sponsor of
the Microcredit Summit in Washington, as stating that "by creating jobs at the
margin, microcredit is an economic stabilization program").





n33.  See, e.g., Amy L. Chua, The Paradox of Free Market Democracy: Rethinking
Development Policy, 41 Harv. Int'l L.J. 287, 343 (2000) (describing the Grameen
Bank as a "nongovernmental, nonprofit microcredit organization...which engages
in group lending to poor villagers to promote small-scale entrepreneurship in
developing country villages"); John Boudreau, It's one way to change the world
on a budget, San Jose Mercury News, Aug. 11, 2002, available at 2002 WL 25438099
(listing Grameen Bank, Opportunity International, and ACCION International as
non-profits that provide capital for loans for poor people); Michael J. Papa et
al., Communication Monographs, Sept. 1, 1997, available at 1997 WL 27554199
(describing Grameen Bank as "a non-profit, value-based organization that targets
the poorest of the poor for social and economic development programs); Loans for
the Tiniest Businesses, N.Y. Times, Sept. 10, 2000, 3, at 10, (describing the
Grameen Bank as a "Bangladeshi nonprofit organization" that "pioneered the
industry in 1976 and has lent money to 2.3 million people..."). In fact,
however, the Grameen Bank is a for-profit institution. See Bornstein, supra note
9, at 26; A short history of Grameen Bank, supra note 9 ("Grameen Bank is owned
by the rural poor whom it serves. Borrowers of the Bank own 90% of its shares,
while the remaining 10% is owned by the government.").





n34.  Bornstein, supra note 9, at 95 ("Yunus [the founder of the Grameen Bank]
was adamant that Grameen not be perceived by members as another giveaway
program."); Id. at 231 (quoting Yunus: "Credit without strict discipline is
nothing but charity.").





n35.  Id. at 231. See also Kenneth Anderson, Microcredit: Fulfilling or Belying
the Universalist Morality of Globalizing Markets?, 5 Yale Hum. Rts. & Dev. L.J.
85, 104 (2002) (commenting on microcredit generally: ""Credit,' "repayment,'
"interest rates,' "risk,' "rates of return,' "collateral': this, of course, is
the terminology of banking."); Philip M. Nichols, A Legal Theory of Emerging
Economies, 39 Va. J. Int'l L. 229, 299 (1999) ("Grameen Bank acts in many
respects as a typical commercial bank, albeit with a customer base consisting of
the very poor of Bangladesh."); Solomon, supra note 8, at 195 (likening the
Grameen Bank to a "typical commercial bank").





n36.  Bornstein, supra note 9, at 292-95 (discussing the Bank's efforts to
become self-sufficient, and the importance placed on this goal by the Bank's
donors); Muhammad Yunus, Banker to the Poor: Micro-Lending and the Battle
Against World Poverty 204 (1999) ("In Grameen we always try to make a profit so
that we can cover all our costs, protect ourselves from future shocks, and
continue to expand."); Jane E. Larson, Free Markets Deep in the Heart of Texas,
84 Geo. L.J. 179, 242-43 (1995) (stating that the Grameen Bank makes profits,
not on credit operations, but by "profitably investing funds that it borrows
from national and international sources at highly concessional rates of
interest, and thereby supplementing its credit operations budget"). This
admiration is directed to microcredit programs generally. See, e.g., Jaffer,
supra note 5, at 184 ("Although most [microfinance institutions] are financed,
at least initially, through grants or low-interest loans from aid organizations
or donor governments, very many have achieved operational self-sufficiency
(consistently positive cashflow), and a significant number have achieved
financial self-sufficiency (consistently positive cashflow, adjusting for
subsidies received and write-offs for non-recoverable loans)."). A number of
studies of the Grameen Bank, however, dispute the claim that it has achieved
self-sufficiency. See, e.g., Jude L. Fernando, Nongovernmental Organizations,
Microcredit, and Empowerment of Women, 554 Annals Am. Acad. Pol. & Soc. Sci.
150, 165 (1997) ("A project evaluation report of the Grameen Bank (GB) in 1994
noted that "GB budgets failed to predict loan growth accurately and [the Bank]
did not use the annual budgets to control the lending program, when the demand
for loans, especially the new seasonal loans and housing loans escalated.'").





n37.  See, e.g., Keith N. Hylton, Banks and Inner Cities: Market and Regulatory
Obstacles to Development Lending, 17 Yale J. on Reg. 197, 226 (2000) ("The
Grameen Bank operates in Bangladesh and provides loans to groups, typically
consisting of five borrowers from the same village, under agreements in which
all members of the group are liable for the amount loaned to one member. This
transfers a large part of the risk to the borrower, and the parties themselves
have incentives to monitor the borrower to make sure that he repays the loan.
Moreover, groups will seek out members who are creditworthy, based on
information they have from day-to-day experience in their communities.");
Jaffer, supra note 5, at 187 (attributing the success of microlending more than
anything else to the peer lending methodology); Daryl J. Levinson, Collective
Sanctions, 56 Stan. L. Rev. 345, 396-98 (2003) (listing the lending-related
advantages of group lending); Solomon, supra note 8, at 196 ("The formation of
solidarity groups provides an effective mechanism for the Bank's expansion of
credit assistance to the poor.").





n38.  See supra notes 13-16 and accompanying text.





n39.  See, e.g., Mohammad A. Auwal & Arvind Singhal, The Diffusion of Grameen
Bank in Bangladesh: Lessons Learned about Alleviating Rural Poverty, 14
Knowledge: Creation, Diffusion, Utilization 7, 16 (1992) (stating that the model
relies on a "healthy dose of peer pressure and peer support," and "replaces
material collateral with a kind of social collateral"); Jaffer, supra note 5, at
201 ("Solidarity lending...provides a screening method that is reliable,
inexpensive, and that suffers no diseconomies of scale."); Levinson, supra note
37, at 396 ("Peer selection by borrowers mitigates the huge information
asymmetries inherent in underdeveloped credit markets. While assessing the
credit risks of Bangladeshi villagers would be prohibitively costly for a bank,
the villagers themselves are intimately acquainted with each other's honesty,
financial status, and work ethic."); Solomon, supra note 8, at 198 ("Treating
the borrowers as a group throughout the loan process enables the Bank to reduce
its analysis of each loan application, thereby decreasing the high transaction
costs that...discourage loans to small businesses. Because group members assume
mutual responsibility for each others' loans, the Bank can reduce staff time
devoted to tracking loans and service more borrowers."); Jacob Yaron, What Makes
Rural Finance Institutions Successful?, 9 World Bank Res. Observer 49, 55 (1994)
("By leaving much of the screening process in the hands of people who know the
borrower very well, Grameen Bank decreases one element of risk that faces most
lenders: imperfect knowledge as to whether a borrower intends to default.").





n40.  Anthony D. Taibi, Banking, Finance, and Community Economic Empowerment:
Structural Economic Theory, Procedural Civil Rights, and Substantive Racial
Justice, 107 Harv. L. Rev. 1465, 1527-28 (1994) (describing the peer-group
lending model, which makes members "meet regularly to evaluate business plans,
track repayments, exchange information, and lend mutual support," and through
which microloan program graduates "learn[] economically, socially, culturally,
and politically useful skills and emerge with a track record of business
success, a credit history, and a small asset base"); Solomon, supra note 8, at
197 (concluding that the scrutiny from other group members results in
enterprises that are better planned and more likely to make a profit).





n41.  Bornstein, supra note 9, at 20; Solomon, supra note 8, at 199. Indeed,
ACCION International, another large and well-known microlender claims that this
so-called "incremental" lending methodology, which makes use of "small, quick
loans that escalate in size," is key to maintaining a high repayment rate.
Katherine Stearns, The Hidden Beast: Delinquency in Microenterprise Credit
Programs 43-44 (1991).





n42.  See, e.g., Nichols, supra note 35, at 299-300; Jane Kaufman Winn, How to
Make Poor Countries Rich and How to Enrich Our Poor, 77 Iowa L. Rev. 899, 932-33
(1992) (reviewing Hernando de Soto, The Other Path (1989)).





n43.  For a detailed discussion of rotating credit associations, see generally
Cao, supra note 5; Thierry van Bastelaer, Imperfect Information, Social Capital
and the Poor's Access to Credit 6-8 (Center for Institutional Reform and the
Informal Sector Working Paper No. 234, 2000). Also known as Rotating Savings and
Credit Associations ("ROSCAs"), RCAs, function by distributing pooled funds
among members of the group, either "randomly, by auction or by collective
decision." Id. at 6.





n44.  Cao, supra note 5, at 874 ("Simply defined, a rotating credit association
is "a group who pool their funds on a regular basis then rotate the pool around
the group until all members have received it,' essentially functioning as both a
savings and lending device.").





n45.  Nichols explains:



   Grameen Bank acts in many respects as a typical commercial bank, albeit with
a customer base consisting of the very poor of Bangladesh. In operation,
however, Grameen Bank has borrowed from the indigenous - and very relational -
rotating savings and credit associations that exist in a broad arch from Japan
to the bottom of Africa. While Grameen Bank approves applicants, virtually all
administrative tasks, including screening applicants for actual loans, are
performed by local groups of borrowers... Grameen Bank suggests that hybrid
institutions should be used to bridge the change from a relational to formal
orientation. In the context of a theory of emerging economies, a "big bang'
creation of a complete network of formal institutions is unlikely to succeed,
whereas institutions based on an understanding of the relational foundation can
more constructively be used to direct change in these countries.

 Nichols, supra note 35, at 299-300.





n46.  See, e.g., Simon, supra note 5, at 52-53 (focusing on the inclusion of
"discipline" as one of the Sixteen Decisions); Steven D. Jamar, A Lawyering
Approach to Law and Development, 27 N.C. J. Int'l L. & Com. Reg. 31, 44-45
(2001) ("Central to the Bank's success is the pledge it requires all borrowers
to memorize and implement, the so-called Sixteen Decisions."); Morin, supra note
5, at 135 ("Another important feature of the Grameen model is the "group
training' in which members learn the rules of the bank and memorize a social
contract called the "Sixteen Decisions.'"). Indeed, such comments suggest that
this development agenda contributes both to the success of the lending program
and to poverty reduction.





n47.  The Sixteen Decisions of Grameen Bank, supra note 18. The complete list is
as follows:



   1. We shall follow and advance the four principles of Grameen Bank -
Discipline, Unity, Courage and Hard work - in all walks of our lives.

   2. Prosperity we shall bring to our families.

   3. We shall not live in dilapidated houses. We shall repair our houses and
work towards constructing new houses at the earliest.

   4. We shall grow vegetables all the year round. We shall eat plenty of them
and sell the surplus.

   5. During the plantation seasons, we shall plant as many seedlings as
possible.

   6. We shall plan to keep our families small. We shall minimize our
expenditures. We shall look after our health.

   7. We shall educate our children and ensure that they can earn to pay for
their education.

   8. We shall always keep our children and the environment clean.

   9. We shall build and use pit-latrines.

   10. We shall drink water from tubewells. If it is not available, we shall
boil water or use alum.

   11. We shall not take any dowry at our sons' weddings, neither shall we give
any dowry at our daughters [sic] weddings. We shall keep our centre free from
the curse of dowry. We shall not practice child marriage.

   12. We shall not inflict any injustice on anyone, neither shall we allow
anyone to do so.

   13. We shall collectively undertake bigger investments for higher incomes.

   14. We shall always be ready to help each other. If anyone is in difficulty,
we shall all help him or her.

   15. If we come to know of any breach of discipline in any centre, we shall
all go there and help restore discipline.

   16. We shall take part in all social activities collectively.







n48.  See, e.g., Report on UNESCO's Contribution to Poverty Eradication and on
Action Considered within the Framework of the United Nations Decade for the
Eradication of Poverty, U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization,
152d Sess., Provisional Agenda Item 3.6.1, at 6, U.N. Doc. 152 EX/13 (1997)
("Recognizing the importance of micro-finance programmes favouring the poor,
particularly rural women, UNESCO has joined hands with Bangladesh's Grameen Bank
in promoting this concept and diffusing the success story of Bangladesh's
experiment to other countries of the world."); Cristina N. Campanella, The
United Nations' New Approach to Human Development and Poverty, 17 N.Y.L. Sch. J.
Hum. Rts. 951, 954 (2001) ("These "Grameen Banks' have been particularly
beneficial to poor rural women who could not normally qualify for a bank
loan."); Etienne, supra note 29, at 164 ("The Grameen Bank has provided an
opportunity for women to achieve previously unimaginable goals and to promote
change in their own lives and the lives of other women."); Patricia Waak,
Shaping a Sustainable Planet: The Role of Nongovernmental Organizations, 6 Colo.
J. Int'l Envtl. L. & Pol'y 345, 351 (1995) ("The Grameen Bank of Bangladesh, the
BKK Credit Program in Indonesia, the Working Women's Forum in India, and the
FINCA program in Latin America are all projects that are enhancing the status of
women by providing a means for owning land, building small business, and setting
up markets for crafts and other enterprises."); Wahid, supra note 32, at 4 ("One
of the significant achievements of the Grameen Bank has been its contribution to
the emancipation, status, and economic independence of women."). Such interest
extends to microcredit programs more broadly. See Shelly Feldman, NGOs and Civil
Society: (Un)stated Contradictions, 554 Annals Am. Acad. Pol. & Soc. Sci. 46, 57
(1997) ("What represents NGO Success in the 1990s is the NGO's ability to
allocate resources and increase the participation of women in their programs...
The activities they have encouraged include chicken rearing, crafts, and fish
pond cultivation, common home-based activities of rural women, or tailoring and
trade generally associated with new forms of exchange for women. This diverse
array of activities has been critically important in recasting rural gender
relations and expanding opportunities for women."); Taylor, supra note 20, at
319 ("Women as a group receive special emphasis because "the poorest, landless,
most destitute heads of household are women.'").





n49.  Grameen Bank, supra note 9 ("As of July, [sic] 2004, it has 3.7 million
borrowers, 96 percent of whom are women.").





n50.  Breaking the vicious cycle of poverty through microcredit, supra note 15
("Women were initially given equal access to the schemes, and proved not only
reliable borrowers but astute entrepreneurs. As a result, they have raised their
status, lessened their dependency on their husbands and improved their homes and
the nutritional standards of their children."); see also Bornstein, supra note
9, at 141-42 (describing the Bank's founder's desire to change men's attitudes
toward women by giving women economic status); Yunus, supra note 36, at 71 ("It
is not by chance that women constituted less than 1 percent of all the borrowers
in Bangladesh prior to Grameen. The banking system was created for men.").





n51.  Credit delivery system, supra note 10 (noting that the Bank seeks to
"focus increasingly on women from the poorest households, whose urge for
survival has a far greater bearing on the development of the family"); see also
Bornstein, supra note 9, at 142 (quoting the Bank's founder as saying that women
are "natural and better fighters" against poverty); Yunus, supra note 36, at 72
("The more money we lent to poor women, the more I realized that credit given to
a woman brings about change faster than when given to a man.").





n52.  Indeed, some among them have concluded that just one or the other of these
characteristics may be the key to successful poverty reduction. See e.g.,
Jaffer, supra note 5, at 187, 200 (arguing that the Grameen Bank's success - and
that of other microlenders using the peer lending method - results from its use
of the solidarity circle, because this device alone may account for below-market
default rates, tremendous costs savings and overall efficiencies). On the other
hand, some, including the Bank itself, have also attributed the Bank's success
to one or more of several other characteristics of its methodology: 1)
collecting payments in small, frequent installments; 2) forced savings (in which
borrowers must contribute a certain percentage of their loan disbursements
toward group and individual savings accounts and emergency funds); and 3) the
Bank's extensive network of branches in rural villages and hundreds of employees
who visit the branches on a very regular basis in order to ensure timely
payments and enforce the Bank's social development agenda. Credit delivery
system, supra note 10. See also, e.g., Pankaj S. Jain, Managing Credit for the
Rural Poor: Lessons from the Grameen Bank, 24 World Development 79, 79-89 (1996)
(concluding that shared norms and close monitoring by bank staff accounted for
the Grameen Bank's success); Solomon, supra note 8, at 199 (discussing small
loans and extensive branches as important to the Bank's success). See generally
Susan Holcombe, Managing to Empower: The Grameen Bank's Experience of Poverty
Alleviation (1995) (discussing the importance of having an extensive network of
branches and employees). Although portions of my analysis could apply to these
characteristics of the model, I have not addressed them simply because they are
less often discussed as important ingredients in the Bank's formula for success,
and are therefore less a subject of public debate in domestic development
communities.





n53.  Professor Simon is the most prominent example in this regard. Simon, supra
note 5, at 50-57 (discussing the Grameen Bank's use of values analogous to the
Protestant Ethic to promote economic, social and political participation); see
also Morin, supra note 5, at 136 ("Most U.S. microenterprise development
projects remain true to the original goals and philosophy of the Grameen Bank.
They are established as a tool not only for economic development, but also for
human development and community development. Thus, most programs emphasize
collaboration, skills-building, empowerment, and responsibility to the community
to a far greater extent than traditional business development efforts.");
Solomon, supra note 8, at 202 ("Bank's experience demonstrates a link between
economic revitalization and an improved social structure...."). Many in the
United States have recognized the interconnection between economic, social and
political development. See, e.g., David Dante Troutt, Ghettoes Made Easy: The
Metamarket/Antimarket Dichotomy and the Legal Challenges of Inner-City Economic
Development, 35 Harv. C.R.-C.L. L. Rev., 427, 427-34 (2000) (discussing at
length the relationship between "wealth formation and consumer infrastructures"
and "a relationship with government typically characterized by political
participation and accommodation").





n54.  For discussions of the CED movement, see generally Simon, supra note 5;
Scott Cummings, Community Economic Development as Progressive Politics: Toward a
Grassroots Movement for Economic Justice, 54 Stan. L. Rev. 399 (2001).





n55.  Simon, supra note 5, at 3 ("Though there are many variations, the core
definition of CED embraces (1) efforts to develop housing, jobs, or business
opportunities for low-income people, (2) in which a leading role is played by
non-profit nongovernmental organizations (3) that are accountable to
residentially defined communities."); Cummings, supra note 54, at 400-01
("During the unprecedented surge of 1990s prosperity, community economic
development (CED) emerged as the dominant approach to poverty alleviation,
touted by politicians as a market-based alternative to outdated welfare policies
and championed by civil rights leaders as a critical link to economic
equality... Espoused by advocates of different ideological stripes, the simple
logic of market-based CED - that increasing for-profit initiatives in
geographically discrete low-income neighborhoods could produce economic
transformation and community empowerment - became an antipoverty axiom.");
Jones, supra note 8, at 199 ("Strategies for CED include revitalization of
decaying neighborhoods to enhance the economic status of low-income people by
building local institutions; encouraging economic independence and
self-sufficiency through entrepreneurship for low-income people and minorities;
encouraging private sector joint ventures with local institutions; and
heightening participation by low-income people in areas such as political, civil
and social rights movements."); McFarlane, supra note 1, at 308 ("Community
economic development can be characterized as a hybrid process that promotes the
overall quality of life in a neighborhood by viewing the neighborhood
holistically and valuing its human assets. Community economic development also
treats the neighborhood as a discrete and insular economic unit. The focus
becomes one of encouraging the creation of new business and the relocation of
existing business in the targeted neighborhood in order to improve the economic
conditions for residents of that area."); Louise G. Trubek, Symposium Issue:
Lawyering for a New Democracy, 2002 Wis. L. Rev. 271, 274-75 (2002) ("Community
economic development...successfully incorporates democratic opportunity,
economic participation, and community empowerment.").





n56.  Simon, supra note 5, at 51-57, 62-67; Troutt, supra note 53, at 427-34;
Solomon, supra note 8, at 202. This connection between economic, social and
political investment can be found in the rhetoric of international institutions
as well. See, e.g., G.A. Res. 97, U.N. GAOR, 52d Sess., 77th plen. mtg., U.N.
Doc. A/RES/52/194 (1998) (stating that "microcredit programmes have proved to be
an effective tool in freeing people from the bondage of poverty, and have led to
their increasing participation in the mainstream economic and political process
of society").





n57.  In Parts IV.C and V, I discuss the fallacy in believing that these
fortuitously matching values are either well-matched or even indigenous in their
sources.





n58.  Professor Simon describes this as a social value as well: the valorization
of wealth pervasive in the Protestant ethic. Simon, supra note 5, at 56-57. He
suggests that this social value teaches people survival skills. Id. ("The more
recent literature...urges wealth creation in minority communities as an
important social goal. Although wealth sometimes means public or collective
assets, these writers also suggest that private, individual wealth has social
benefits. Wealthy individuals are a potential philanthropic base for their
communities. They are role models that give hope to others in the community.
They serve as positive images to counter negative stereotypes of outsiders about
group members. While the old Protestant Ethic valued wealth as a sign of God's
favor, the new ethic values it as a sign of mainstream society's favor."); see
also Hylton, supra note 37, at 226-27 ("The evidence suggests that the lending
programs have had an effect on wealth accumulation and behavior.").





n59.  Servon, supra note 20, at 82-84 (discussing the experiences of some
microentrepreneurs in being subjected to "demeaning" and "inappropriate" jobs in
the welfare system); Id. at 11 ("In addition to helping people start and
stabilize businesses rather than preparing them for dead-end or non-existent
jobs, microenterprise programs help prove to people that with access to the
right resources they can do something useful that also engages them."); Morin,
supra note 5, at 171-72 ("Current welfare reform programs emphasize "quick
employment,' placing a limit on the number of participants in a state who can be
engaged in education or skills training. By contrast, microenterprise programs
"provide an alternative form of employment for welfare recipients who are
subject to the time limits on benefits embodied in the 1996 welfare reform
law.'").





n60.  See Servon, supra note 20, at 39 (quoting a funding source for the Mott

achieve its development aims... The distinguishing feature and fundamental

n61.  See, e.g., President George Bush, Address to the World Bank/International
Monetary Fund Annual Meeting (Sept. 27, 1989) (discussing Hernando de Soto's
development proposal concerning formalizing poor "informal" workers, stating:

http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/research/papers/1989/89092700.html (last visited
July 5, 2005). One of the more stark recent examples of this reasoning can be

1996, Pub. L. No. 104-193, 110 Stat. 2105, 2184 (1996) ("The welfare system

n62.  In Part IV.A, I detail the problem of market failure in the inner city
credit market. In short, such market failure results from information problems
and high transaction costs, among other things, which prevent mainstream lenders
from lending to inner city borrowers.

n64.  I use the term "formality" here to refer to the imposition of legal rules
and consequences in connection with a transaction in which the participants
previously would have engaged with only unstated cultural or social rules, see
infra notes 293-303 and accompanying text, as well as to the more "personal
formality" described by Professor Simon in his discussion of the "orderly
collaboration" attempted by the CED movement. Simon, supra note 5, at 55
(describing such formality as "associated with norms of respect accorded actors
in mainstream institutions").

n67.  Kenneth Anderson notes that self-sufficiency may be "the Holy Grail of the
microcredit community" because it implies "being able to self-finance growth out
of poverty from revenues of the poor communities themselves, the poor
bootstrapping their own communities out of poverty." Anderson, supra note 35, at
103.





n68.  See supra note 36 and accompanying text; see also Shahidur R. Khandker,
Fighting Poverty with Microcredit: Experience in Bangladesh 103 (1998)
(detailing the Bank's basis for determining self-sufficiency and projecting when
the Bank could become fully self-sufficient); Jaffer, supra note 5, at 184
(describing the Bank as one of a number of microlenders that have achieved
operational and/or financial self-sufficiency and commenting on the
attractiveness of this feature); Muhammad Yunus, Grameen Bank at a Glance ("GB
does not see any need to take any donor money or even take loans from local or
external sources in future. GB's growing amount of deposits will be more than
enough to run and expand its credit programme and repay its existing loans."),
at http://grameen-info.org/bank/GBGlance.htm (last visited June 28, 2004). But
some have disputed the Grameen Bank's claim of self-sufficiency, often by
pointing out that it bases this claim on factors that a traditional for-profit
business would not, such as the benefit the Bank derives from borrowing at lower
than market rates but investing at market rates. See, e.g., Rahman, supra note
15, at 130-31 (describing a number of studies that have concluded that the Bank
is not self-sufficient); Philip M. Nichols, Swapping Debt for Development: A
Theoretical Application of Swaps to the Creation of Microenterprise Lending
Institutions in Sub-Saharan Africa, 27 N.Y.U. J. Int'l L. & Pol. 43, 77 (1994)
("Although Grameen Bank claims to be profitable, it currently makes a profit
only because it borrows money at concessionary rates from donors, and reinvests
at prevailing rates.").





n69.  Thus, many U.S. observers of the Grameen Bank have been keenly interested
in reports about the Bank's interest rates, default rates, funding sources,
balance sheets, and similar data. See Chi-kan Richard Hung, From South to North:

Solomon, supra note 8, at 195-201. U.S. microlending organizations have mimicked
(or matched) the Bank in paying similarly thorough attention to their own
financial status and health. E.g., The Aspen Institute, supra note 8, at 1.

n88.  The Aspen Institute, supra note 8, at xv (noting that 72.4% of
microenterprise agencies provide services to urban areas, 60.5% to rural areas,
and 41.8% to suburban areas). This distinction between urban, suburban and rural
is sensible, as populations often differ greatly between urban inner city
settings and suburban or more rural communities. Such differences can have broad
programmatic implications concerning such things as types of business started
(for example, agricultural versus street vending) and types of cultural
associations that can be leveraged in the lending process (for example among
minority or immigrant populations in different inner cities).

   Additionally, default rates and enforcement measures differ widely among U.S.
microlenders. See, e.g., Servon, supra note 20, at 37-38 (discussing a 1994
study by the Mott Foundation that found an "overall delinquency rate of 19.2
percent...and an annual default rate of 9.5 percent"); Stearns, supra note 41,
at 13 (asserting that different microlenders use different measures for
determining default rates, and that the effect can be reporting that is
misleading or inflated); Hung, supra note 69, at 245 ("U.S. programs waited
between 3 and 6 months before writing off a delinquent loan as a loss.
Accordingly, the default rates for the U.S. average, Working Capital, and the
NCRC would be 4.7, 3.2, and 6.9 percent, respectively."). But see Jeremy Black
et al., For Good Measure: Performance of the U.S. Microenterprise Industry 34
(The Aspen Institute 2002). This recent study of forty-six microenterprise
programs in the United States indicates an average default rate of five percent
for FY 2000. Forty percent of the reporting programs (seventeen microlenders in
all) had default rates below 2.2%.

changes to the more generalized training and social development provided by U.S.

n96.  Talen et. al., supra note 8, at 334; see also Servon, supra note 20, at 39
("As they mature, many programs are emphasizing training at least as much as
lending."); Hung, supra note 69, at 241 ("Adding training is a significant
adaptation of the peer-group lending methodology to an industrial economy like
the United States."); The Aspen Institute, supra note 8, at xviii (reporting
that eighty-eight percent of microenterprise agencies surveyed provided
one-on-one counseling to microentrepreneurs and seventy-seven percent provided
"classroom-type" business training). One commentator notes:



   While the focus of the U.S. programs remains on the provision of credit, most
administrators feel that, in the paper-based and legally sensitive settings of
developed countries, some amount of training and technical assistance is
needed... Most programs include a limited overview of business planning and cash
flow in the orientation sessions for new [lending] groups. The primary purpose
is to give group members a foundation upon which they can question each other
about business ideas and effectively "review' loan proposals from members of
their group.

 Linda Hoke, Creating an Entrepreneurial Culture: Microenterprises in the
Southern Economy 9, 11 (Southern Growth Policies Board, SGPB Alert No. 32,
1990). In contrast, the Grameen Bank's philosophy is to avoid providing training
or business advice. See Bornstein, supra note 9, at 135, 336; Yunus, supra note
36, at 140.





n97.  The number of loans made by U.S. microenterprise programs is perhaps the
most telling evidence of a diverging practice, despite the similar rhetoric used
by U.S. programs and the Grameen Bank. According to The Aspen Institute, of the
540,852 individuals served since the programs were established, only 34,472
borrowers have received loans. Moreover, thirty-three percent of the
microenterprise agencies surveyed provide only training and counseling and do
not disburse any loan funds. The Aspen Institute, supra note 8, at xvi, xix; see
also Black et Al., supra note 91, Appendix A at 46 (listing the number of
programs that are training-led versus credit-led); Lisa Servon, Fulfilling the
Potential of the U.S. Microenterprise Strategy, in Replicating Microfinance in
the United States 169, 177 (James H. Carr & Zhong Yi Tong eds., 2002) ("Nearly
all U.S. microenterprise programs include a training component, which in many
cases dominates the lending activity.").





n98.  For example, as I describe below, these organizations must also consider
carefully whether their expectations about the market's ability to alleviate
poverty are realistic. See infra notes 206-210 and accompanying text. On the
other hand, these training-focused organizations are far more effective than the
lending-focused organizations in alleviating the conditions that may cause
continuing market failure, quelling some of my concerns on that issue. See infra
notes 268-270 and accompanying text.

n102.  See, e.g., Jones, supra note 60 at 441 ("[A] central change in CED
practice is the increased importance of economic self-sufficiency" and thus of
microenterprise programs); Solomon, supra note 8, at 202 (noting that U.S.
"microenterprise lenders assume that access to capital and the entry of
microentrepreneurs into the market improves economic welfare"); Lucie E. White,
Feminist Microenterprise: Vindicating the Rights of Women in the New Global
Order?, 50 Me. L. Rev. 327, 330 (1998) (discussing the belief of some feminist
legal activists that "by owning small businesses women will become powerful as
market actors"); see also Cummings, supra note 54, at 438 (describing and then
critiquing microenterprise, a "central component of market-based CED
strategies," as a poverty alleviation effort).





n103.  With the signing of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity
Reconciliation Act of 1996, Pub. L. No. 104-193, 110 Stat. 2105 (1996),
President Clinton radically redefined welfare in the United States.
Specifically, this statute eliminated Aid for Families with Dependent Children
("AFDC"), and substituted a more limited and restrictive welfare program,
Temporary Assistance to Needy Families ("TANF"). The new law established work
requirements for recipients of assistance who are able to work, as well as a
five-year limit on the receipt of federally funded assistance. Although the 1996
Act expired in 2002, it was reauthorized in 2003 by the Welfare Reform Extension
Act of 2003, Pub. L. No. 108-40 (2003). The 2003 Act includes new mandates and
funding for government promotion of marriage, conditions which have been
criticized for their unproven effectiveness, coercive nature, and the
possibility that they may unduly place domestic violence victims at increased
risk. Id. Yet another indicator of the shift from maintenance to
self-sufficiency was the Empowerment Zone legislation passed in 1996, which
Audrey McFarlane describes as "different from previous urban revitalization
efforts because its emphasis is on business and job development rather than the
mere provision of social services." McFarlane, supra note 1, at 297.





n104. " The Charles Stewart Mott Foundation initiated its Microenterprise
Welfare-to-Work Demonstration and Evaluation in 1998." Ilgar Alisultanov et.
al., Microenterprise as a Welfare to Work Strategy: One Year Findings 3 (The
Aspen Institute, Oct. 2002), available at
http://www.fieldus.org/publications/WTWResearchRpt2.pdf (last visited July 5,
2005). The demonstration found that "in the year after program enrollment, the
household income of participants grew by 29 percent, from $ 11,689 to $ 15, 068
on average... Across all participants, the share of TANF benefits in total
household income declined from thirty percent to thirteen percent in the year
after program enrollment." Id. at 6. Participants in the demonstration included
the Women's Self-Employment Project, the Institute for Social and Economic
Development, and the Worker Ownership Resource Center, among various other
organizations providing microenterprise programs. Id. at 4. See also Burrus &
Stearns, supra note 89, at 9 (stating that "the growing national debate on
welfare reform encouraged ACCION to contribute its knowledge of and experience
with microenterprise development as a possible alternative to welfare for some
individuals"); Jones, supra note 8 at 202 ("One half to two-thirds of
microenterprise programs target welfare recipients for self-employment
training."). In addition, it may well be true that early "successes" in
microlending spurred the drive for welfare reform in its early stages and
provided more left-leaning national politicians with a sense of legitimacy.





n105.  See, e.g., Joanna Ledgerwood, Microfinance Handbook: An Institutional and
Financial Perspective 2 (1999) (discussing how the "need to achieve financial
sustainability" impacts the goals of the microfinance industry); Stearns, supra
note 41, at 7 (describing financial self-sufficiency as integral to long-term
survival of microlenders); Anderson, supra note 35, at 103
("Sustainability...for a long time has been the Holy Grail of the microcredit
community."); Burrus & Stearns, supra note 89, at 10 (stating that a key lesson
that ACCION has learned from its experiences in Latin America, which has been
incorporated into the launch of its U.S. initiative, is that "microlending
operations must be managed with an objective of economic viability. In order for
programs to address the unmet credit need of the microenterprise sector in the
United States on a permanent basis, they must eventually move away from
donations and derive enough income from lending to cover the costs of lending").
But see Anderson, supra note 35, at 103 ("Microcredit organizations only very
rarely succeed in covering their costs; self-sustainability is much more the
extraordinary exception than the rule for microcredit organizations."); Taibi,
supra note 40, at 1527 ("Given the small size of the loans involved, the high
transaction costs, and the costs of providing technical assistance, it is
unlikely that [microenterprise] programs can be self-sufficient, even if they
charge market rates of interest."). This objective is part of a broader
discussion about the proper role of non-governmental organizations vis-a-vis
states and the market. See, e.g., Bishwapriya Sanyal, The Role of NGOs: Charity
and Empowerment: NGOs Self-Defeating Quest for Autonomy, 554 Annals Am. Acad.
Pol. & Soc. Sci. 21, 21-32 (1997); Taylor, supra note 20, at 308.





n106.  Servon, supra note 20, at 56; see supra note 94 and accompanying text;
see also Himes & Servon, supra note 79, at 48 (stating that "gaining confidence
was closely linked to the sense of opportunity clients gained from the ACCION
programs").





n107.  However, a significant number of U.S. microlenders lend to people who are
not poor. See Howells, supra note 5, at 171 ("U.S. microenterprise support
programs fail to focus exclusively, or even predominantly, on welfare-dependent
persons."); Hung, supra note 69, at 239 (stating that only 42% of the U.S.
programs in his study targeted low-income residents in the community"); The
Aspen Institute, supra note 8, at xvii (stating that 70% of microlenders
reported that more than 50% of their clients' household income was below 80% of
the area median income as defined by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban
Development). Moreover, studies have noted that U.S. micro-borrowers have far
more access to credit than Bangladeshi women. See, e.g., Hung, supra note 69, at
232-33 (stating that 82% of Grameen Bank borrowers had not received a loan
before, in contrast to only 22% of U.S. micro-borrowers [this percentage in the
United States may be even lower because Hung's study did not include loans from
family and friends]). As I will discuss in greater detail below, this latter
statistic also suggests that U.S. microlenders are not reaching the poorest of
the poor. See infra notes 159, 257-258 and accompanying text. On the other hand,
the above statistics may not adequately reflect the lower availability of
credit, bank accounts and other formal participation in the financial market
experienced by African Americans and other racial minorities in the United
States. See infra note 237 and accompanying text.





n108.  Concerning the Grameen Bank's borrowers, see Breaking the vicious cycle
of poverty through microcredit, supra note 15 (stating that the success of the
Grameen Bank approach "shows that a number of objections to lending to the poor
can be overcome if careful supervision and management are provided). Moreover:



   For example, it had earlier been thought that the poor would not be able to
find remunerative occupations. In fact, Grameen borrowers have successfully done
so. It was thought that the poor would not be able to repay; in fact, repayment
rates reached 97 percent. It was thought that poor rural women in particular
were not bankable; in fact, they accounted for 94 percent of borrowers in early
1992.

 Id. Concerning U.S. programs, see Servon, supra note 20, at 56 (discussing one
microlender's focus on teaching women about business and financing); Burrus &
Stearns, supra note 89, at 41 (stating that an ACCION client is "likely never to
have had access to any formal or informal credit source, including family or
friends, as to have had a credit card or other kind of credit, usually for
consumer purposes or from a supplier"). The Association for Enterprise
Opportunity relates:



   AEO has learned that low-income entrepreneurs can greatly benefit from
increased knowledge of the benefits of banking and savings principles. For
example, entrepreneurs need to learn the importance of establishing checking
accounts and savings accounts, like Individual Development Accounts (IDAs); the
importance of establishing a credit rating and, in many instances, learning
about credit rehabilitation. They need to understand the importance of tax laws
and other regulatory issues; the importance of sound accounting principles and
types of insurance, etc.

 Association for Enterprise Opportunity, Key Elements of Microenterprise
Development, at http://www.microenterpriseworks.org/about/keyelements.htm (last
visited July 5, 2005).





n109.  Concerning microbusinesses in Bangladesh, see Mohammad A. Auwal,
Promoting Microcapitalism in the Service of the Poor: The Grameen Model and its
Cross-Cultural Adaptation, 33 J. Bus. Comm. 27, 31 (1996) ("The Grameen members
use these indigenous skills to invest loans in more than 400 individual
income-generating activities and more than 100 group business enterprises....").
Concerning microbusinesses in the United States, see Peggy Clark & Amy J. Kays,
Enabling Entrepreneurship: Microenterprise Development in the United States
29-30 (1995) Clark and Kays state (stating that in the United States,
"microbusiness activities include desktop publishing, catfish farming,
specialized high-volume embroidery, jewelry-making, and clothing sales....");
Talen et al., supra note 8, at 334-35 ("In developing countries,
microenterprises are usually engaged in production-based economic activities,
such as food processing and petty trade, whereas in the United States
microenterprises can be found in industries across the board, from manufacturing
to services to sales."). However, as I will discuss, there are also some
significant differences in start-up costs, markets and level of business
knowledge that appear necessary for micro-entrepreneurs to succeed in Bangladesh
versus in the United States. See infra notes 144-162 and accompanying text.

have been repaid, a borrower pays her interest, which is slightly above the

is to keep the interest rate as close to the market rate, prevailing in the

n114.  Azizah al-Hibri, On Being a Muslim Corporate Lawyer, 27 Tex. Tech L. Rev.
947, 956 n.29 (1996) ("It is worth reflecting upon the fact that Grameen Bank
started with a different lending approach to the poor, based on low interest
rates. It appears, however, that market forces, such as the demands of capital
suppliers, have made the bank restructure these rates upward."); Khandker et
al., supra note 110, at 63-65 (emphasizing self-sufficiency in measuring the
Grameen Bank's success, and discussing the increase in interest rates as related

n115.  I use the term "above-market" here to refer to commercial interest rates
in the mainstream market for credit. These are the rates that the Bank and
others use as a reference point. See discussion supra note 113 and infra note
116 and accompanying text. Arguably, however, mainstream commercial rates are
not a meaningful reference point because interest rates vary with risk and there
are no loans in the mainstream market that carry the same risk as those in the
microcredit market. The lack of physical collateral, the small loan size
relative to loan cost, and the guarantee of the circle all distinguish
microloans from mainstream loans.





n116.  Rahman, supra note 15, at 133 (stating that in 1994-95, "the annual net
interest rate charged by the Grameen Bank was 20 percent, which was 8 to 10
percent higher than the commercial market rates in the country."); Id. at 146
(according to this study, because the "bank charged interest on borrowers'
partially paid-off principal," the "actual annual interest realized from
borrowers [that year] was 31.68 percent."); al-Hibri, supra note 114, at 956
n.29 ("The bank charges interest four points above the commercial rate.")
(quoting David Bornstein, The Barefoot Bank with Cheek, Atlantic Monthly, Dec.
1995, at 40).





n117.  Ishtiaq Hossain, An Experiment in Sustainable Human Development: The
Grameen Bank of Bangladesh, 15 J. of Third World Stud. 39, 41 (1998) (noting
ninety-eight percent repayment rate of Grameen Bank borrowers); Nichols, supra
note 68, at 67 (stating that the Grameen Bank has a ninety-eight percent rate of
repayment, which is significantly greater than the "commercial default rate in
Bangladesh of seventy to ninety percent"); Yunus, supra note 110, at 114, 117
(stating that the repayment rate "hovers between 96 and 100 percent"); Credit
delivery system, supra note 10 ("The repayment rate on loans is currently - 95
per cent - due to group pressure and self-interest, as well as the motivation of
borrowers.").





n118.  Holcombe, supra note 52 (discussing importance of extensive network of
branches and employees); Ruhul Amin et al., Poor Women's Participation in
Income-Generating Projects and Their Fertility Regulation in Rural Bangladesh:
Evidence from a Recent Survey, 22 World Dev. 555, 556 (1994) (citing studies
showing that the Bank's success in maintaining a high recovery rate ranging
between ninety-six and one hundred percent is "thanks either to group
responsibility and group pressure and/or grassroots mobilization efforts");
Jain, supra note 52, at 79, 83 (arguing that the ninety-eight percent repayment
rate of Grameen Bank borrowers should not be attributed to the group guarantee
innovation - which did not, in fact, guarantee loan repayment of individual
members - but rather to Grameen Bank's fostering of a "credit-responsive culture
among borrower members," making it a ""cultural habit' for each individual
member to follow Bank norms"); Nichols, supra note 68, at 69 (arguing that
Grameen Bank's "operational success" is a result of the fact that "it lends only
to persons whose projects will probably generate sufficient income to repay the
loan" and "policing of borrowers is done at the local level"); Rahman, supra
note 110, at 197, 203 (observing the importance of Grameen Bank workers in
forming loan groups, familiarizing group members with Bank rules and
regulations, closely supervising members once loans are disbursed, and
explaining how loans are repaid in small weekly installments so members do not
feel the "burden'); Solomon, supra note 8, at 199 (discussing small loans and
extensive branches as important to the Bank's success); Joseph E. Stiglitz, Peer
Monitoring and Credit Markets, 4 World Bank Econ. Rev. 351, 353 (1990)
(discussing the Bank's reliance on local knowledge).





n119.  Nichols, supra note 35, at 299-300 ("Grameen Bank acts in many respects
as a typical commercial bank, albeit with a customer base consisting of the very
poor of Bangladesh."); Solomon, supra note 8, at 195 (likening the Grameen Bank
to a "typical commercial bank"). But see Yunus, supra note 36, at 61-62
(describing the Bank's methodology as the opposite of commercial banks in
Bangladesh, which, because of such things as written forms and requirements
concerning physical collateral, make it impossible for the poor to borrow
money); Shahidur R. Khandker, Grameen Bank: Impact, Costs, and Program
Sustainability, 14 Asian Dev. Rev. 97, 103 (1996) (discussing how, in contrast
to traditional banks that loan on the basis of physical collateral, Grameen Bank
introduced innovative methods to reduce the "behavioral and material risks of
lending," e.g., group lending, mandatory savings, mandatory insurance to protect
against material production risks, and the introduction of seasonal loans).





n120.  See Rahman, supra note 110, at 197; see also Jaffer, supra note 5, at 186
(noting that one theory for the success of microfinance institutes (MFIs) is
that they have "relied heavily on "peer pressure' and pre-existing social norms,
relying on culture, religion, and "social collateral' to provide the incentives
conventionally provided by physical collateral"); Id. at 203-04 (noting that
physical collateral may result in an "inevitable disconnect between the
interests of the borrower and the interests of the lender - assuming that the
project is less than 100% secured..."). This disconnect, however,



   is significantly mitigated in the solidarity lending model because, though
the individual borrower has little or no incentive to minimize losses on his own
project, the other members of the group have an incentive to pressure the
individual in question to minimize losses, as long as the profits from their own
projects are expected to exceed the losses from their co-members' projects.

 Id..





n121.  Thus, the Bank's rhetoric emphasizes income generation. See Bornstein,
supra note 9, at 24 ("By placing resources directly into the hands of poor
people, [the Grameen Bank] got them involved in myriad businesses... It might
take decades or generations, but, Yunus felt, eventually they would be able to
carve out profitable niches in the world economy."); Id. at 230 (quoting
Muhammad Yunus as saying, "We are not doing any favors. We are in business");
Yunus, supra note 36, at 140 ("Giving the poor access to credit allows them to
immediately put into practice the skills they already know - to weave, husk rice
paddy, raise cows, peddle a rickshaw. And the cash they earn is then a tool, a
key that unlocks a host of other abilities and allows them to explore their own
potential."); Breaking the vicious cycle of poverty through microcredit, supra
note 15 ("The assumption is that if individual borrowers are given access to
credit, they will be able to identify and engage in viable income-generating
activities.").





n122.  See Bornstein, supra note 9, at 220-23 (describing the Bank's admirable
efforts to attain "total operational transparency" by keeping detailed
statistics on all aspects of the Bank's operations, including on the borrowers).
Yet, if more recent studies are to be credited, somewhere along the line, the
Bank's efforts to keep accurate statistics about microbusinesses have failed.
One explanation for this failure might be that, while the head office of the
Bank is keeping detailed statistics on borrowers' business successes and
failures, the branch officers and/or the borrowers are not conveying accurate
information. This hypothesis seems to be supported by more recent studies. See
infra notes 126-130 and accompanying text. In addition, Bornstein's relatively
detailed interviews revealed a lack of consensus among top managers about the
Bank's goals. While some emphasized the Bank's operational sustainability,
others worried that the Bank's rapid expansion prevented it both from ensuring
the sustainability of the microenterprises and from reaching the poorest of the
poor. Bornstein, supra note 9, at 295-96.





n123.  See Bornstein, supra note 9, at 175-76, 289 (describing the Bank's
aggressive projections concerning expansion and how the Bank surpassed those
projections).





n124.  Id. at 297-99 (citing a study that examined household earnings,
immunization rates, and health and nutritional status of children); Yunus, supra
note 36, at 202 (describing the Bank's goal of attaining "poverty-free" status
for all its branches and defining "poverty-free" to include owning a house with
a tin roof, having beds for all family members, having safe drinking water,
having access to education, having no food shortages, and having sufficient
income-earning opportunities for all adult family members); Yunus, supra note
110, at 114, 117 (noting studies on the Grameen Bank that suggest the Bank has
had a significant positive effect on the schooling and nutrition of children,
e.g., for every ten percent increase in borrowing by a member, the likelihood
that her daughter would be in school increased by almost twenty percent);
Hossain, supra note 117, at 39, 41 (noting increased educational levels among
children of Grameen Bank borrowers, and an overall increased standard of
living).





n125.  See Breaking the vicious cycle of poverty through microcredit, supra note
15 ("It is estimated that the average household income of Grameen Bank members
is about 50 percent higher than the target group in the control village, and 25
percent higher than the target group non-members in Grameen Bank villages. The
landless have benefited most, followed by marginal landowners.") Furthermore,
"this has resulted in a sharp reduction in the number of Grameen Bank members
living below the poverty line, 20 percent compared to 56 percent for comparable
non-Grameen Bank members." Id. It is unclear how the Bank defines and determines
"income level," but this claim is supported by others. See Khandker et al.,
supra note 110, at 77-80 (noting an increase in rural wages and in savings);
Hossain, supra note 117, at 41 (lauding the measurable improvements in assets of
borrower-members); Rahman, supra note 110, at 199 (noting significant increases
in the level of income, acquisition of land and wealth by Grameen Bank members
as compared with similarly situated control groups). However, according to
Aminur Rahman, one independent study of the Grameen Bank's program concluded:
"Had the subsidy been simply transferred directly to households, they would have
been as well off (at least in terms of current consumption and ignoring the
costs of making the transfers)." Rahman, supra note 15, at 131-32.





n126.  Rahman, supra note 15, at 115 (quoting Yunus: "The moment you [the
lender] stopped supervising, there would be a risk for abuse of the loan."); see
also Helen Todd, Women at the Center: Grameen Bank Borrowers after One Decade 23
(1996). The Bank also requires borrowers to prove as a condition of receiving
new loans that they have started and maintained the businesses they claimed on
their original loan applications. Rahman, supra note 15, at 106-07 (describing
the Bank's policy of requiring borrowers to justify any reported changes in
investment projects at the time of new loan applications - and finding that
perhaps consequently borrowers and lower level bank workers do not report
changes in projects, instead reporting the same project as was in the original
application every year). These requirements appear to apply only to
business-related loans rather than to loans from the solidarity circle savings
accounts, which can be used for non-business purposes. Yunus, supra note 36, at
65.





n127.  Rahman and Todd both found that group chairpersons and borrowing center
leaders regularly misreport the use of loan funds on such forms, despite knowing
the truth about how the funds are used. Rahman, supra note 15, at 116; Todd,
supra note 126, at 23-24. Further, Todd concluded that Bank workers know of this
practice. Id. at 25.





n128.  Rahman, supra note 15, at 115-17 (reporting that, although spot checks by
more senior Bank officers are part of the Bank's official policy, it is rare for
such officers even to visit any given Bank branch).

only seventeen percent of the loans were used "at least in part for the official
purpose," and in another study village only twenty-eight percent were).





n130.  Rahman, supra note 15, at 106-07. Further, in that village, Rahman found
that many loan officers were aware of the widespread problem of loan diversion.
See also Todd, supra note 126, at 24 (finding in her study village that

n133.  The U.S. Census Bureau, under the Personal Responsibility and Work
Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (PWORA or Welfare Reform Act), collects
data measuring the effects of welfare reform. Covering the period from 1992
through 2001, the Survey of Program Dynamics (SPD), a nationally representative,
longitudinal survey, and the Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP)
provide data for both government cash assistance programs (AFDC/TANF and
Supplemental Security Income) and non-cash assistance programs (housing
assistance, energy assistance, food stamps, and free or reduced price lunch).
Data includes information related not just to employment levels and assets, but
also education enrollment, food security, family conflict levels, substance
abuse and other similar categories. See U.S. Census Bureau, U.S. Department of
Commerce, Preparing to Measure Welfare Reform Using the Longitudinal Survey of
Program Dynamics: 2001 3-8 (2001), at
http://www.census.gov/prod/2001pubs/spd2001-1.pdf (last visited July 15, 2004);
see also Demographics Survey Division, U.S. Census Bureau, Survey of Program
Dynamics (2003), at http://www.sipp.census.gov/spd (last visited July 15, 2004).





n134.  While the ultimate goal of microlending in the United States may be
disputed, many influential members of the development community would agree that
microlending seeks to alleviate poverty by means of job creation. See, e.g., The
Small Business Administration's Microloan Demonstration Program and Business
Development Programs: Hearing before the U.S. Senate Comm. on Small Bus,. 103d
Cong., 1st Sess. at 1 (1994) (opening statement of Sen. Dale Bumpers)
(describing the Small Business Administration's microloan program "as a tool for
combating poverty, unemployment, and underemployment by offering people the
dream of successful business ownership"); Jones, supra note 80, at vii
("Microenterprise development is a community economic development and
anti-poverty tool designed to create jobs through self-employment."); Servon,
supra note 20, at 3 (noting that the "single common denominator [of
microenterprise programs] is that they serve as lenders of last resort,
providing credit to people who want to be self-employed"); Howells, supra note
5, at 164 ("Microenterprise programs...assume that people can draw themselves
out of poverty through self-employment."); The Aspen Institute, supra note 8, at
xvii ("Most practitioner agencies indicate that poverty alleviation is a primary
goal for their organization.").





n135.  Equally concerning are studies that have begun to keep more careful
statistics about U.S. microenterprises and have reported a much spottier record
of success. See infra notes 156-62 and accompanying text. Kenneth Anderson, in
arguing this same point, concludes that the "test of success is precisely how
many clients are able to graduate to unsubsidized credit." Anderson, supra note
35, at 119. Anderson, however, does not conclude that the purpose of microcredit
is necessarily to integrate the poor into the mainstream market. Id. ("In
describing markets created or sustained by microcredit institutions as "faux'
markets, I do not intend to denigrate them. There can be sound social policy
reasons why it is useful to create such markets even when the ultimate function
is not to draw people into the "real' market.").

evaluation techniques. See infra notes 163-166 and accompanying text.





n137.  Important historical examples of such efforts in the United States
include Thomas Jefferson's attempts to constitutionalize broad distribution of
property rights, (see Letter from Thomas Jefferson to James Madison (Oct. 28,
1785), in 8 The Papers of Thomas Jefferson, 25 Feb. to 31 Oct. 1785, at 682
(Julian P. Boyd ed., 1953) (in which Jefferson stated that the "fundamental
right to labour," as it belongs to the unemployed poor, may trump the property
rights of large landholders)); Booker T. Washington's National Negro Business
League (see Louis R. Harlan, Booker T. Washington and the National Negro
Business League, in Booker T. Washington in Perspective: Essays of Louis R.
Harlan 98, 105 (Raymond W. Smock ed., 1988)), some of the legislation passed as
a result of Lyndon B. Johnson's War on Poverty (see Economic Opportunity Act of
1964, Pub. L. No. 88-452, 201, 78 Stat. 508 (1964) (repealed 1981)), and the
efforts of the South Shore Bank in Chicago (see Rochelle Lento, Community
Development Banking Strategy for Revitalizing Our Communities, 27 U. Mich. J.L.
Reform 773, 783-90 (1994)). For a historical overview of some of these efforts,
see Cummings, supra note 54, at 410-37.





n138.  Unless otherwise specified, this more entrepreneurial form of
participation is what I refer to when I use the terms "market participant" and
"market participation."





n139.  See Anderson, supra note 35, at 108-09 ("The purpose of microcredit is to
enable the poor to engage in market activity themselves, creating small or micro
businesses of one kind or another... The purpose, in other words, is that they
use their borrowed capital to enter into market transactions as producers and
not merely as customers."). See generally Servon, supra note 20, at 1-5, 19-13;
Simon, supra note 5, at 88-101.





n140.  Servon, supra note 20, at 2; see also Feldman, supra note 48, at 57
(noting the pressure felt by nongovernmental organizations to "create
income-earning opportunities, a theme that is most apparent in the international
success of the Grameen Bank Project"). However, a recent study of U.S.
microlenders refutes the hopeful assumptions of many in the United States that
microcredit will effectuate large-scale poverty alleviation through economic
development. That study concludes that fifty-eight percent of U.S. microlenders
do not even lend to people of low incomes, instead focusing on economic
development alone. Hung, supra note 69, at 239 (adding that the more sustainable
U.S. programs tend to serve the working poor rather than the "extremely poor").





n141.  Interestingly, some commentators have followed the Bank's lead in using
social welfare criteria as a measure of success even as the success they laud is
that of market participation. See, e.g., Jaffer, supra note 5, at 207 (measuring
the Bank's success by its borrowers' ability to reach daily required caloric
levels and to cross over the "extreme poverty line").





n142.  Taylor notes:



   Comparison with other approaches shows little difference between
[microcredit] and other poverty alleviation models. Providing money to a
population through almost any means will ordinarily have a short-term positive
impact on poverty. More funds in an economy cause short-term spikes in economic
indicators as recipients of funds use them, typically for consumption purposes.
The problem, of course, is that once the funds are expended, their positive
impact evaporates and the objective indicia of economic welfare fall. For
purposes of meaningful impact on poverty, the long-term effect of alleviation
models is far more important. In that area, microcredit seems to do no better
than other alternatives.

 Taylor, supra note 20, at 326-27. Kenneth Anderson proposes that, if
microcredit is in fact "stripped of its special bootstrapping element," then it
"must compete with other, often direct forms of welfare provision for the very
poor, including direct investment in health care, education, and the rest of
direct social services for the poor." Anderson, supra note 35, at 120.





n143.  As I discuss below, a few studies in the United States have begun to keep
statistics about the survival rate of businesses begun with the aid of
microcredit. See infra notes 156-162 and accompanying text. These studies are
only a beginning. More in-depth statistics are required about all aspects of
such businesses.





n144.  See, e.g., Hung, supra note 69, at 240 ("The increasing demand and
emphasis on business skills in U.S. programs reflects the more complex business
environment in the integrated economy, even for a local community, than the
village economy in...developing countries."); Taub, supra note 61, at 8
(contrasting the Bangladeshi "small and highly localized markets" with the
United States' "international, national, and state-wide" markets); see also
Anderson, supra note 35, at 117 (discussing the "extraordinarily local markets
in which microcredit borrowers typically operate their microbusinesses"). For
more on this, see infra text accompanying notes 417-426 (discussing the
existence of an informal market in the United States, but questioning whether
microlenders are servicing it).

   I use the term "informal" here to signify, first and foremost, an economy in
which services are sold, and goods are produced and sold, by numerous small
businesses rather than by one or a few large firms. See Regina Austin, "The
Black Community," its Lawbreakers, and a Politics of Identification, 65 S. Cal.
L. Rev. 1769, 1804 (1992) (The "informal economy is characterized by operations
that are "small scale,' "labor intensive, requiring little capital,' and
"locally based'"). I also use the term to signify the nature of these small
businesses - namely street vendors, home workers and door-to-door salespeople -
and of their business relationships - namely that they transact business without
permits, written contracts, clear evidence of title, or expectation of reliable
enforcement of their rights. See Regina Austin, "An Honest Living": Street
Vendors, Municipal Regulation, and the Black Public Sphere, 103 Yale L.J. 2119,
2120 (1994) (discussing street vendors as members of the informal economy);
Richard A. Epstein, The Moral and Practical Dilemmas of an Underground Economy,
103 Yale L.J. 2157, 2177 n.1 (1994) ("The informal economy avoids licenses and
other forms of administrative review...."); Saskia Sassen, The Informal Economy:
Between New Developments and Old Regulations, 103 Yale L.J. 2289, 2289 (1994)
("The "informal economy' refers to those income-generating activities occurring
outside the state's regulatory framework that have analogs within that
framework."). See generally de Soto, supra note 1 (describing street vendors
operating without permits, receipts or tax payments); David Kennedy, Laws and
Developments, in Contemplating Complexity: Law and Development in the 21st
Century (Amanda Perry-Kessaris & John Hatchard eds., 2003).





n145.  Hung, supra note 69, at 240; Taub, supra note 61, at 8.





n146.  See, e.g., Hung, supra note 69, at 229 ("The informal economy of a
developing country is likely to constitute a proportionally larger segment of
its whole economy than that of an industrial country such as the United
States."); Mark Schreiner & Jonathan Morduch, Opportunities and Challenges for
Microfinance in the United States, in Replicating Microfinance in the United
States 19, 24 (James H. Carr & Zhong Yi Tong eds., 2002) ("Large retailers and
service providers...do not have a strong presence in Bangladesh, Bolivia, or
Indonesia; shopkeepers and street vendors in those countries, unlike those in
the United States, compete mostly against each other, not against large
factories or chains of restaurants or retailers.").





n147.  See Talen et al., supra note 8, at 340 (noting that in the United States
there is a "limited market demand for goods and services produced by
microenterprises. Instead of the vast pools of demand that exist in developing
countries, the United States faces..."puddles of demand.'"); Taub, supra note
61, at 8 (describing the Good Faith Fund as failing to contribute to economic
development, in that it fails to create "additional wealth for a region," or to
"generate new money or provide additional employment opportunities"). But
consider Kenneth Anderson's comments concerning microenterprises in developing
countries:



   It is not always evident that the businesses serve any purpose other than to
trade items around the community of the poor without generating substantial new
income. This possibility of inefficient activity that would not take place but
for the subsidized funds provided by microcredit organizations themselves is one
example of the risks of microcredit distorting local markets. On the other hand,
it has been noted that many services of a relatively modest kind - bicycle
repair or shoe repair, for example - are often not provided within poor
communities themselves, even though there are strong grounds for thinking the
activity to be economically sustainable, since even poor people spend money on
such services but must go outside the local community to do so. Microcredit
sometimes enables individuals to start providing such services within the local
community, at a net welfare gain in part because income turns over within the
local community and in part because it is more efficient to offer and obtain
such services close to home.

 Anderson, supra note 35, at 109.





n148.  See supra notes 140-141 and accompanying text. It is possible that some
of this "information gap" is filled by legal clinics such as those described by
Susan Jones. Jones, supra note 8, at 202-08. However, lawyers cannot fill the
entire information gap. Moreover, it is not clear just how many
microentrepreneurs have access to legal services as they attempt to enter new
markets.





n149.  Such signals might include seals of approval, certifications or permits.
See Talen et al., supra note 8, at 347 (recommending research into niche
products and markets as a means of increasing mainstream market participation);
Taylor, supra note 20, at 336 (suggesting that state involvement in microlending
efforts can help develop markets and correct demand/supply); see also Anderson,
supra note 35, at 112 ("Being committed to market principles in local markets is
one thing, while being committed to the terms of global markets is perhaps
another.").

See supra notes 98-99.





n151.  Anderson, supra note 35, at 118-19. Anderson, however, does not condemn a
"faux" market for the poor as necessarily a negative outcome of microcredit

at 119. In reaching this conclusion, however, he assumes the possibility of
certain benefits of microcredit - such as business training - that I conclude
the Grameen Bank model fails to provide.

n155.  See discussion infra Sections IV.B and V. As I discuss, many in the
development community do in fact explicitly seek to integrate the poor into more

n156.  See The Aspen Institute, supra note 8, at xvi ("Most practitioners
reported that job creation/business development, community economic development,
