n157.  See, e.g., Servon, supra note 20, at 44-45; Taub, supra note 61, at 2;
see also Schreiner & Morduch, supra note 146, at 54 (citing two studies that
"suggest that microfinance may help about 1 in 100 displaced workers become
self-employed who otherwise would not have," and another study finding that "the
ratio for people on public assistance may be closer to 1 in 1,000"). But see
Talen et al., supra note 8, at 340 n.5 (stating that "approximately 15,000 jobs
have been created or retained" as a result of microlending in the United States
in the last 15 years).





n158.  Servon, supra note 20, at 131-32; Schreiner & Morduch, supra note 146, at
54; see also Howells, supra note 5, at 171 ("U.S. microenterprise support
programs fail to focus exclusively, or even predominantly, on welfare-dependent
persons."). This finding comports with statistics about self-employment more
generally. According to one study, only eight to twelve percent of all American
adults (not just those on welfare) "are serious about starting their own
businesses, and only about 1 to 2 percent actually end up starting one. Of those
started, only about half become viable and remain in business." Talen et al.,
supra note 8, at 341 (summarizing a study by the National Commission on
Entrepreneurship, and adding that the problem is exacerbated by the fact that
many Americans turn to self-employment in recessionary times, thereby reducing
their chances of success even further).





n159.  See Clark & Kays, supra note 109, at 2, 19 (noting that while the
majority of clients participating in U.S. microenterprise programs "fall below
or are near standard definitions of the poverty line, most programs also serve
clients who earn moderate incomes"); Simon, supra note 5, at 220 ("Even heavily
subsidized home or business ownership is not a plausible option for most poor
people. Many of them cannot benefit substantially from job training and
placement without vastly more extensive support - whether in terms of therapy,
basic education, child care, or transportation - than current programs
contemplate."); Nitin Bhatt et al., The Challenges of Outreach and
Sustainability for U.S. Microcredit Programs, in Replicating Microfinance in the
United States 191, 204 (James H. Carr & Zhong Yi Tong eds., 2002) ("That most
U.S. programs are serving a majority of "nonpoor' clients may not be a bad
thing, and it can be explained by the fact that if someone has been successful
in starting and sustaining a profitable business, that person may no longer be
classified as poor."); Howells, supra note 5, at 171 (providing a list of
reasons why "microenterprise programs tend to help the richer poor"); Lisa J.
Servon, Fulfilling the Potential of the U.S. Microenterprise Strategy, in
Replicating Microfinance in the United States 169, 182 (James H. Carr & Zhong Yi
Tong eds., 2002) ("Few U.S. microenterprise programs primarily serve the "truly
disadvantaged.'"). Indeed, one of the more comprehensive sources of information
about U.S. microlenders, The Aspen Institute, bears these figures out. The 2002
Directory of U.S. Microenterprise Programs found that "70% of [U.S. agencies
surveyed] report that more than 50% of their [Fiscal Year] 2000 clients'
house-hold income was below 80% of the HUD median income for their location."
The Aspen Institute, supra note 8, at xvii. As a point of comparison, eighty
percent of the HUD median income limit for Fiscal Year 2005 in Boston was $
66,150 for a family of four. U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development,
HUD Income Limits - Fiscal Year 2005, at
http://www.cityofboston.gov/dnd/pdfs/HUD_Income_ Levels_Rent_Limits.pdf (last
visited July 5, 2005).





n160.  See, e.g., United States Small Business Administration, Research Summary:
Business Survival Rates by Age Cohort of Business (2001) (showing survival rates
of small businesses by age of business and employment size, and finding that
businesses with one to four employees had a thirty-one percent survival rate),
at http://www.sba.gov/advo/research/rs122.html (last visited June 24, 2005). Two
longitudinal studies focusing on borrowers refute this finding to some extent.
Specifically, one study found that, although only 408 of the 1300 people who
participated in the Self-Employment Investment Demonstration Project started
businesses, seventy-nine percent of those businesses were still in operation 2.6
years after start-up. Robert E. Friedman et al., Building Assets: Self
Employment for Welfare Recipients: Overview of the Findings from the Self
Employment Investment Demonstration 4 (1995). Another found that forty-nine
percent of the businesses started by microentrepreneurs studied were still
operating after five years. Peggy Clark et al., Microenterprise and the Poor:
Findings from the Self-Employment Learning Project Five-Year Survey of
Microentrepreneurs viii (The Aspen Institute Economic Opportunities Program,
1999), at http://fieldus.org/li/microenterprise.html (last visited June 24,
2005). However, the Friedman study, and others, have found that the number of
jobs created through microcredit programs was quite limited or unknown. See,
e.g., Friedman et al., supra, at 12 (finding that even the successful
microbusinesses produced an average of 1.5 full and part-time jobs each).
Moreover, at least one commentator has critiqued such studies for lacking
control groups, concluding independently that the number of poor people moved
from welfare to self-employment with the aid of microcredit is "probably no more
than 6 in 1,000." Bhatt et al., supra note 159, at 195-96 (describing the
findings of Schreiner). But see Clark & Kays, supra note 109, at 3 (finding that
forty-six percent of microbusinesses are profitable on a monthly basis).





n161.  Bhatt et al., supra note 159, at 196 (describing one study that found
that the net profit for the average successful microenterprise was only $ 3011,
a minor addition to overall income level); Howells, supra note 5, at 169
("Although microenterprise programs enable a subset of poor households to
increase family income by packaging self-employment income with other sources of
income, income from self-employment is rarely sufficient, by itself, to enable
families to move above the poverty line.").





n162.  Taub, supra note 61, at 10-11 (describing microlending as useful
primarily to the working poor, those who are already able to "take some minimal
risks," and who already have "at least one moderately secure income").
Curiously, a recent study has suggested that the fact that micro-loans are
diverted from microenterprise-related uses up to twenty-five percent of the time
in developing countries is a benefit because the funds are used to pay for
household expenses, thereby stabilizing the household. Talen et al., supra note
8, at 335, 337. Such a conclusion adds to my concern that U.S. proponents of
microlending are using the wrong criteria to determine success.





n163.  See, e.g., Black et al., supra note 91, at 8 (listing the major
categories of performance criteria as: reaching target groups, achieving program
scale (including magnitude of lending activity), credit program effectiveness
(examining size, quality and level of risk of lending portfolio), training
program effectiveness, and program efficiency and sustainability measures
(focusing on issues of microlender self-sufficiency)). My point, here, is that
the majority of criteria used to evaluate microlenders' success focus on
expansion of the microlending program rather than on the impact on borrowers.
See also Howells, supra note 5, at 166 (commenting that the publicity about U.S.
microlenders focuses on their organizational success rather than on the success
of their borrowers). Moreover, a recent publication from a conference on
microlending that was well-attended by industry experts ended with a list of
programmatic recommendations only two of which arguably focused directly on job
development or market participation by the poor - while the others focused on
outreach and sustainability of the microlenders. Talen et al., supra note 8, at
347-50.





n164.  Bhatt et al., supra note 159, at 195 ("A limited number of studies exist
that examine the impact of microcredit on loan recipients."). See also David
Hulme & Paul Mosley, Finance Against Poverty 42 (1996) (discussing the
importance of self-sustainability in the context of microlenders).





n165.  FIELD Publications, supra note 82; ACCION Publications Series, supra note
81. A senior officer of ACCION has stated that his organization has published
fewer longitudinal studies about borrowers not out of lack of interest or
understanding of their importance, but rather out of lack of funding for such
studies. Interview with Livingston Parsons, III, supra note 93.





n166.  Another area that seems to have been left largely untouched by U.S.
studies is research and discussion about barriers to market entry by
micro-entrepreneurs, information about their patrons and clients, and more
broadly, information about the quantity and quality of their market
participation. For example, in describing the business characteristics of most
Self-Employment Learning Project (SELP) entrepreneurs, Clark & Kays neglect to
mention any discussion of the microbusiness' clients, nor any detailed
discussion of the microentrepreneurs' market participation. Clark & Kays, supra
note 109, at 26-31. Other important institutional reports on the performance of
the U.S. microenterprise industry also neglect to discuss any specific details
of the microentrepreneurs' market participation. See generally Black et al.,
supra note 91 (omitting treatment of market participation by microentrepreneurs)
. These issues are critical given the greater complexity of markets in the
United States.

   Like the Grameen Bank, U.S. programs appear to use "social" criteria (at
least as much as quantitative standards) to measure success vis-a-vis their
borrowers, including such criteria as increases in borrower self-confidence,
discipline, and community participation. See, e.g., Servon, supra note 20, at 74
(stating that some microlenders use quantitative measures and others use
qualitative criteria); id. at 132 ("To evaluate these programs appropriately, it
will be necessary to look at social welfare indicators such as increases in
individual self-esteem and family stability, as well as traditional economic
development outcomes such as jobs created and changes in income."); Jones, supra
note 8, at 195 n.3 ("[A] primary goal of microenterprise development programs is
the success of microenterprise participants measured by positive personal
outcomes such as improved self-esteem, exercising control over one's life and
household income, taking advantage of educational opportunities or alternative
employment, and the overall ability to exercise personal and economic
choices.").





n167.  I also place some faith in the methodological rigor of Aminur Rahman's
study of female Grameen borrowers. See Rahman, supra note 15, at 22-38
(discussing his methodology in detail and comparing it to that of earlier
studies of the Bank). An anthropologist and native Bangladeshi who lived among
his subjects for eleven months, Rahman's appears to be the first study of the
Grameen Bank using more qualitative anthropological methods. Rahman's study
focused on a Bangladeshi village in which the Grameen Bank had been operating
for at least a decade, and which, in most respects, was representative of the
villages in which the Bank works. Id. at 25-28. Despite his efforts to find a
representative sample, the size of his database is, of course, a limitation of
his study.





n168.  Such concerns and limitations also apply to my use of a fairly limited
number of studies of U.S. microlending efforts.





n169.  See supra notes 39, 63-64 and accompanying text. Interestingly, the
founder of the Grameen Bank describes the solidarity circle as having been
conceived in order to create "support and protection," to "smooth out the
erratic behavior patterns of individual members, making each borrower more
reliable in the process," and to create "moral responsibility." Yunus, supra
note 36, at 62-63.





n170.  See supra notes 39, 63-64 and accompanying text; see also Yunus, supra
note 36, at 62-63 (stating that the solidarity circle helps enhance each

n171.  Bornstein, supra note 9, at 86 (describing a conversation with villagers
who said that, because of the pressure from the Bank to repay their loans, the
peer groups do not accept "completely poor people" into their groups because
they "don't repay their loans"); id. at 191 (quoting a bank manager as saying,
"some managers give hints that it's better to avoid the very poorest people");

influential group leader in her study village); id. at 174 (these criteria were
echoed by some of the bank workers Todd interviewed, one of whom stated:
"Landless, yes; but not hopeless."); Sidney Ruth Schuler & Syed M. Hashemi,
Credit Programs, Women's Empowerment, and Contraceptive Use in Bangladesh, 25

See, e.g., Hulme & Mosley, supra note 164, at 113 ("the poorest...receive few
direct benefits from income-generating credit initiatives."); Rahman, supra note

Bank's failure to reach the poorest to its emphasis on high loan recovery,

n176.  I borrow the term "factional" from Rahman, who describes the borrowers in

integral part of "patron-client' relationships between the rich and the poor."
Id. See also Todd, supra note 126, at 176 (describing loan centers as "mirroring
the divisions and factions that exist in the village," in that "groups are
divided by [neighborhood] and caste").





n177.  Rahman, supra note 15, at 80-81, 117-24; see also Bornstein, supra note

the center. If they won't help, then you're out. No matter what, the Bank has to
get its money back."); Counts, supra note 10, at 69-70 (stating that the
pressure on Bank workers to collect repayment on time and increase membership
results in higher pressure on members both from fellow borrowers and from the
Bank). Taylor generalizes this problem to the microcredit industry as a whole.
Taylor, supra note 20, at 327, 329.

n183.  Rahman, supra note 15, at 140-45. For a discussion of the same problem in
the microcredit industry in general, see Hulme & Mosley, supra note 164, at 122
("The virtuous circle of "low income, credit, investment, more income, more
credit, more investment' is seductive; unfortunately, it does not mirror the
reality that the majority of very poor households face in sustaining a

n184.  See, e.g., Burrus & Stearns, supra note 89, at 29-31 ("Attempts to form
groups of individuals who do not know each other has [sic] not proven to be an
efficient lending approach."); Hung, supra note 69, at 249 ("Practically none of
the groups in the U.S. sample has denied anyone from joining the group" because
such groups "tend to be more randomly assigned."); Taub, supra note 61, at 6
(describing the Good Faith Fund's decision to construct groups after its initial

n185.  Burrus & Stearns, supra note 89, at 30. In fact few, if any, U.S.
programs have imported the Grameen Bank's version of the solidarity circle in
its exact form. Indeed, "many programs have abandoned peer lending for more
traditional individual loans." Fund for Innovation, Effectiveness, Learning and
Dissemination, Microenterprise Development in the United States: An Overview 4
(2000) available at http://fieldus.org/publications/fact_sheet1.pdf (last
visited June 24, 2005); see also Dianne Solis, Microcredits Lend Money to the
Little Entrepreneurs Most Banks Avoid, Dallas Morning News, Jan. 23, 2002, at 1H
(noting ACCION USA's estimate that no more than fifteen percent of its loans are
currently made using solidarity groups in the United States). While Burrus and
Stearns highlight the successful use of solidarity groups by ACCION in New York
(where eighty percent of 295 new borrowers from April to November of 1995
entered as group borrowers), the use of such groups in other major U.S. cities -
San Antonio, San Diego, and Chicago - has been significantly less successful.
They suggest that the high percentage of group borrowers in New York is, in
part, attributable to the fact that many successful borrowers told their friends
about peer lending, so that newer borrowers were already familiar with the group
lending concept. They also point out that in certain niche markets, where the
entrepreneurs already know each other (taxi drivers in San Antonio, swap meet
vendors in San Diego, etc.), solidarity group lending has proven successful. See
Burrus & Stearns, supra note 89, at 29-31. See also Taub, supra note 61, at 5
(describing the decision of the Good Faith Fund in Arkansas to stop using peer
lending because it failed). These organizations have cited as reasons for the
failure of this technique the lack of trust among circle members (especially
where loans are large enough to be of use in starting and maintaining a new
enterprise), the difficulty of convening group meetings, and problems with
enforcement. Id. at 6-8.





n186.  See, e.g., Taub, supra note 61, at 6-7. Seventy-two percent of the U.S.
programs in Hung's study use a weaker version of the joint liability rule, which
"stops the remaining group members' access to future loans when a loan in the
group is delinquent." Hung, supra note 69, at 235.





n187.  See, e.g., Servon, supra note 20, at 69-72 (describing Working Capital's
step lending process, in which it lends in increments of $ 500 to $ 5000 in
order to allow group members to build a record with each other).





n188.  This may in part be because U.S. programs do not have the choice of
employing some of the more coercive enforcement measures used by the Grameen
Bank and its borrowers against each other. The apparent consequence of some of
the practices of U.S. programs is a much spottier record with respect to default
rates. See, e.g., Mohammad A. Auwal, supra note 109, at 40 (1996) (noting that
Arkansas' Good Faith Fund had a forty percent default rate in its first two
years); Taub, supra note 61, at 5 (noting Good Faith Fund's forty-eight percent
default rate in 1989 while using the peer lending approach, and its subsequent
eleven percent default rate in 1993 and 1994 after it stopped using that
methodology). It appears that no study has investigated whether borrowers
nonetheless feel enough pressure to repay loans that they engage in the debt
recycling and loss of savings experienced by many Grameen Bank borrowers.

n203.  Thus, for example, some microlenders' programs emphasize training, at

n204.  See Servon, supra note 20, at 95 (describing the even greater importance
of training in programs that work with welfare recipients who, more than others,
"may be lacking in basic skills or self-esteem and self-confidence"). Bhatt and
Tang describe:



   [Some] programs...focused more on motivating and empowering participants and
less on assessing the viability of their business plans. They often failed to
equip their graduates with the knowledge and skills needed to assess the market
potential of their venture start-up or growth ideas. In some instances, the
training provided was so generic and inappropriate that it was of hardly any use
to participants, who ultimately needed to evaluate whether their specific
ventures had a good chance of making money in the marketplace.

 Nitin Bhatt & Shui-Yan Tang, Making Microcredit Work in the United States:
Social, Financial, and Administrative Dimensions, 15 Econ. Dev. Q. 229, 231
(2001). They continue:



   Although many programs' stated mission is economic development, their
training sessions are often geared toward social empowerment rather than
business development. Although empowering individuals is certainly important for
poverty alleviation and community development,...policy makers need to recognize
that it may not necessarily translate into the development of income-generating
microenterprises or the enhancement of participants' economic self-sufficiency
in the short run.

 Id. at 238. On this, Clark and Kays add:



   The welfare-to-self employment strategy is a unique subset of the
microenterprise field, employing a specialized set of interventions that are
particularly appropriate for people on welfare. While providing the same general
package of direct microenterprise development assistance that includes technical
assistance and credit, these programs offer a tailored, participatory set of
training workshops and technical assistance interventions that may include
workshops on self-esteem building, setting goals, analyzing the viability of
starting a microbusiness, balancing a budget, and other topics.

 Clark & Kays, supra note 109, at 24.





n205.  See, e.g., Servon, supra note 20, at 54-56 (describing Women's Initiative
for Self Employment in San Francisco, whose strategy is one of "holism...helping
women make better-informed life decisions"). The Institute for Social and
Economic Development states that it "helps [its] clients to develop the life
skills they will need to achieve success - whether in self-employment or
employment." Institute for Social and Economic Development, Frequently Asked
Questions, at http://www.ised.org/faqs.asp#5 (last visited July 5, 2005). It
continues: "We also provide linkages with social service agencies to help them
overcome barriers...to economic independence, including personal financial
management training, homeownership education, alcohol/substance abuse
counseling, etc." Id. Kavita Ramdas describes the WSEP in similar terms:



   WSEP's training process develops self-esteem in its clients. In WSEP circles,
small groups of low-income women come together to jointly manage their member's
repayment of loans. Women demonstrate samples of their products, debate
financing and marketing strategies, and organize neighborhood fairs. In training
sessions, they learn financial skills and legal regulations which are useful in
all aspects of their lives...[many] find that WSEP's training enables them to
move into more traditional wage employment, and makes them feel more confident
about improving their economic conditions.

 Kavita Ramdas, Self-Employment for Low-Income Women, Equal Means (1991) at 20,
22. A similar program exists in New Mexico:



   WESST corp's business consulting service is a series of one-on-one hour long
sessions with an experienced business or professional consultant. These sessions
will help you determine the answers and information you need to start or enhance
your business. WESST corp does not do the work for you. Rather you will develop
the self-confidence and ability to acquire the necessary knowledge and
information to help your self [sic].

 Wesst Corp., The Women's Economic Self-Sufficiency Team, at
http://www.laplaza.org/b_e/wesst_corp.html (last visited July 5, 2005).

n227.  These programs generally have used precisely the social and behavioral
definitions of success used by the Grameen Bank, but also have gone further by
focusing on psychological improvements in women as a result of their efforts.
See, e.g., Servon, supra note 20, at 54-61; see also supra notes 106, 202-204
and accompanying text. In this respect, U.S. programs are similar to some
programs overseas. See Susy Cheston & Lisa Kuhn, Empowering Women Through
Microfinance, in Pathways Out Of Poverty: Innovations In Microfinance For The
Poorest Families 167, 201 (Sam Daley-Harris ed., 2002). The pair cites
self-confidence as a crucial area to foster empowerment of women, but notes the
difficulty in measuring increased levels of self-esteem. Since, they suggest,
"self-esteem and self-confidence are closely linked with knowledge," and Rwandan
women participating in a micro-finance program reported an increase in their
level of knowledge about issues affecting family and related to business, it
follows that the same women also experienced a rise in self-confidence. Id.
Nepalese and Ghanaian lending programs reported similar increases in women's
self-confidence. Id.





n228.  According to the U.S. Census Bureau, 31.1 million Americans were living
in poverty in 2000. U.S. Census Bureau, Poverty: 2000 Highlights (2001),
available at http://www.census.gov/hhes/poverty/poverty00/pov00hi.html (last
revised July 5, 2005). Approximately 90% of adults on welfare are women.
Charlotte Snow, The Impact of Welfare Reform on Women, 25 Hum. Rts. 14, 14
(1998).

   In addition, American women suffer disproportionately from domestic violence,
accounting for up to 85% of victims. Erin L. Han, Mandatory Arrest and No-Drop
Policies: Victim Empowerment in Domestic Violence Cases, 23 B.C. Third World
L.J. 159, 159 n.2 (2003). According to Han:



   More women seek medical attention for harm suffered at the hands of an
intimate partner than for injuries caused by auto accidents, rapes, and muggings
combined. Women are more likely to be beaten, raped, or killed by a current or
former male partner than by anyone else. Between 22 and 35% of female emergency
room patients are there because of injuries inflicted on them by their partners.
One out of four pregnant women has a history of being abused. One-third to
one-half of female homicide victims were murdered by a male partner.

 Id. at 160. Finally, although domestic violence occurs at all levels of
economic class, the lower the household income, the more likely domestic
violence is to occur. See Lawrence A. Greenfeld et al., U.S. Dep't of Justice,
Violence by Inmates: Analysis of Data on Crimes by Current or Former Spouses,
Boyfriends, and Girlfriends 14 (1998), available at
http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/pub/pdf/vi.pdf (last visited Apr. 21, 2005)
(finding that those with incomes between $ 7,500 and $ 25,000 experience nearly
three times the amount of domestic violence as those with incomes above $
50,000).

   Again, there may be important differences in the forms of coercion women in
the U.S. experience as compared to women in Bangladesh. For example, the higher
rate of single women borrowers in the U.S. may result in a lower rate of loan
diversions to men. However, these differences do not, without research,
eliminate the possibility of gender-based vulnerabilities.

n235.  Keith N. Hylton & Vincent D. Rougeau, Lending Discrimination: Economic
Theory, Econometric Evidence, and the Community Reinvestment Act, 85 Geo. L.J.
237, 253-62 (1996); Michael Klausner, Market Failure and Community Investment: A
Market-Oriented Alternative to the Community Reinvestment Act, 143 U. Pa. L.
Rev. 1561, 1565 (1995). See generally Joseph E. Stiglitz & Andrew Weiss, Credit
Rationing in Markets with Imperfect Information, 71 Am. Econ. Rev. 393 (1981)
(discussing market failure in credit markets more generally).





n236.  Simon, supra note 5, at 27-28; Cao, supra note 5, at 853-57; Hylton,
supra note 37, at 206-23. For an analysis also attributing inaccessibility of
credit to race discrimination and other problems that go beyond market failure,
see generally Taibi, supra note 40, and Troutt, supra note 53. While
acknowledging the presence of discrimination, and federal statutory efforts to
address it (in the form of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act ("ECOA") and the
Community Reinvestment Act ("CRA"), Cao and Hylton argue that it is these market
inefficiencies, at least as much as discrimination, that prevent mainstream
commercial lenders from lending in the inner city. Cao, supra note 5, at 853-55;
Hylton, supra note 37, at 222.





n237.  See Klausner, supra note 235, at 1564-67 (discussing how the bank's
willingness to incur the costs of evaluating the creditworthiness of a
particular borrower depends on the magnitude of the costs in relation to the
expected returns of the loan); see also Cao, supra note 5, at 855-57 ("Lenders
performing a rational cost-benefit analysis will likely decide against lending
to borrowers who lack certain indicia of creditworthiness."). Hylton connects
the information problem to the fact that low-income residents of inner-city
neighborhoods have very brief, if any, credit history because low-income does
not allow the opportunity for savings, most use local convenience stores and
liquor stores to cash checks, and many transactions are carried out in cash.
Citing statistics from 1989, he states: "Only forty-five percent of black
households maintain checking accounts, compared to eighty percent of white
households." Hylton, supra note 37, at 209 The high costs of lending to the
inner city poor (combined with a lack of collateral) result in lenders engaging
in "credit rationing," where borrowers willing to pay the high rates of interest
are precluded from borrowing because their willingness to pay the high interest
rates sends a signal to the lender that the investment is too risky - in other
words, that they are motivated not by their belief in the success of the
project, but rather by their belief that the probability of their having to
repay the loan is small. Cao, supra note 5, at 855-57; Hylton, supra note 37, at
207-17; Jaffer, supra note 5, at 188-93. This creates a gap in the credit
market.





n238.  See Cao, supra note 5, at 856 (emphasizing that monitoring costs, while
present in all loan transactions, are certainly a concern for banks in more
marginal transactions); Klausner, supra note 235, at 1568 (discussing the high
costs associated with evaluating and monitoring the borrower risk); see also Bd.
of Governors of the Fed. Reserve Sys., Report to the Congress on the
Availability of Credit to Small Businesses 29 (2002) (discussing the increase of
monitoring costs for very small business borrowers because the close
interdependence between the business and the owner necessitates monitoring the
general well being of the owner as well as the performance of the business
itself), available at
http://www.federalreserve.gov/boarddocs/rptcongress/sbc_rep.pdf (last visited
July 5, 2005) [hereinafter Report to the Congress].





n239.  Simon, supra note 5, at 44-45 ("To the extent that an applicant can post
assets as security for loan commitments, the lender has less need to rely on
assessments of her reliability."); Cao, supra note 5, at 851, 856-57 (noting
that the absence of collateral increases transaction costs and can result in
"rational redlining," i.e., "those who need money the most are those who can
borrow the least"); Hylton, supra note 37, at 214 (collateral aligns borrower
and lender incentives, which in turn mitigates the problem of "moral hazard,"
i.e., the tendency of borrowers to undertake risky investments); Jaffer, supra
note 5, at 189 ("Collateral can often compensate for some of the gap in
information between lender and borrower, providing a way to both increase the
borrower's stake in the success of the project and reduce losses to the bank in
the event of default."); Ronald J. Mann, Explaining the Pattern of Secured
Credit, 110 Harv. L. Rev. 625, 638 (1997) ("The advantages that a lender
receives from a grant of collateral can lower the lender's anticipated overall
costs and thus indirectly lower the costs that the borrower must pay to induce
the lender to make the loan.").





n240.  Mann, supra note 239, at 639 ("The most obvious advantage to the lender
of issuing secured credit is that receiving collateral increases the likelihood
that the lender will be able to collect the loan forcibly if the borrower does
not voluntarily repay it.").





n241.  For some examples of state usury laws, see Cal. Fin. Code. 22303 (2003);
Mass. Ann. laws ch. 172A, 9 (2003); Mont. Code Ann. 31-1-108 (2002); N.Y. Penal
Law 190.42 (2003). Microlending in other countries is not necessarily limited by
usury laws. One commentator suggests that high interest rates, with real rates
at 50% or more (charged, for example, by several microfinance programs in
Indonesia) are vital for the success of microfinance programs, as they are
necessary for program self-sustainability in the face of high default rates. He
argues that subsidies (such as usury laws) which result in "cheap" credit harm
the programs because "cheap" credit encourages abuse and fails to reach its
intended target, the poor. Yoko Miyashita, Comment: Microfinance and Poverty
Alleviation: Lessons From Indonesia's Village Banking System, 10 Pac. Rim. L. &
Pol'y 147, 159-60 (2000).

note 40.





n244.  Simon, supra note 5, at 42-48; see also Cummings, supra note 54, at 443
(describing community development corporations which have been promoted by
members of the CED movement as "catalysts for local economic growth, working to
correct market failures by channeling resources into areas with high
concentrations of poverty"); Klausner, supra note 235, at 1569-70 (discussing
what he calls "market imperfections").





n245.  See, e.g., Michael S. Barr, Banking the Poor, 21 Yale J. on Reg. 121, 124
(2004); Richard A. Posner, A Theory of Primitive Society, with Special Reference

Lending Discrimination: A Law and Economics Analysis, 73 Tex. L. Rev. 787, 805
(1995).





n246.  For example, the problem of the money lender, who often monopolizes rural
credit markets in Third World countries, has attracted much attention as
exemplary of widespread market failure. See Jaffer, supra note 5, at 187-88,
193-95; Stiglitz, supra note 118, at 351-52, 362.





n247.  Following on Anthony Taibi's analysis, for example, in contrast to the
Equal Credit Opportunity Act, which "posits an acultural, meritocratic "thing'
called "creditworthiness,'" solidarity circle members are the ones who "evaluate
business plans, track repayments, [and] exchange information." Taibi, supra note
40, at 1479, 1527. In addition, the solidarity circle alleviates many of the
"administrative tasks" and "operating costs" that prevent the Community
Reinvestment Act from "altering loan-granting outcomes permanently." Id. at
1511, 1527.





n248.  See, e.g., Cao, supra note 5, at 884-88 (discussing the screening
function in the context of ROSCAs, which solve information asymmetries by
relying on borrowers themselves to screen, monitor, and enforce loans, since the
group has "ample information concerning the identity, history, and background of
its members at its disposal."); Jaffer, supra note 5, at 202 (describing that,
in the "solidarity lending model," "members of the group likely come from the
same village, have known one another all their lives, and are intimately
familiar with one another's financial situation."); Stiglitz, supra note 118, at
353 ("The Grameen Bank is able to exploit the local knowledge of the members of
the group. It has devised an incentive structure whereby others within the
village do the monitoring for it."). Hylton notes that Grameen's peer lending
strategy "transfers a large part of the risk to the borrower, and the parties
themselves have incentives to monitor the borrower to make sure that he repays
the loan. Moreover, groups will seek out members who are creditworthy, based on
information they have from day-to-day experience in their communities." Hylton,
supra note 37, at 226. See also supra note 39 and accompanying text.





n249.  See Cao, supra note 5, at 888-89; Jaffer, supra note 5, at 183, 200-01.





n250.  Klausner describes how mainstream commercial banks decide to forego
lending in low-income neighborhoods where the cost of information is high, the
loan amount is relatively small, and the number of credit-worthy applicants is
low. However, increased lending reduces the cost of information since the bank
can rely on information generated by past lending in the neighborhood. The
drawback of this system is that once some borrowers in the neighborhood begin to
exhibit signs of default, the mainstream banks use that information to determine
the risk and credit-worthiness of all borrowers from the surrounding area. See
Klausner, supra note 235, at 1568-69. See also Simon, supra note 5, at 43-48
(discussing positive externalities and complementarities in this context).





n251.  No U.S. program has reached the economies of scale attained by the
Grameen Bank. Nor has any U.S. program achieved the level of operational and
financial independence attained by the Grameen Bank, although Accion
International comes closer than most. See Talen et al., supra note 8, at 339-40;
see also Servon, supra note 20, at 20 (pointing out that even the largest U.S.
programs are not nearly the size of the Grameen Bank, which has significant
consequences for self-sustainability.) Thus, whether because the market is so
much more complex and less penetrable, or for other reasons, it remains to be
seen whether even these benefits will be realized.





n252.  See supra notes 38-40 and accompanying text. See also Stiglitz, supra
note 118, at 361 (concluding that the guarantee requirement in fact provides
incentive for group members to monitor each others' actions).





n253.  See supra note 40 and accompanying text. Jaffer, for example, appears to
assume that borrowers in developing countries already possess enough information
about the local economy to be able to assess business risk. Jaffer, supra note
5, at 202 ("Members of the group...are also likely to be familiar with the
particular idiosyncrasies of the local economy, and to be well-informed about
the prospects for the borrower's project."). However, he also acknowledges that
they may be unqualified to analyze such information adequately. Id. at 205. As I
discuss below, Jaffer's initial assumption is not safe to make concerning
borrowers in the U.S. inner city. See infra notes 255-257 and accompanying text.





n254.  See Servon, supra note 20, at 18 (discussing the need of American
microentrepreneurs for economic literacy to deal with the complex regulatory
scheme of doing business in the U.S., e.g., tax returns, licensing, etc., which
are absent in the informal economies of less developed countries); Hung, supra
note 69, at 237, 240-41, 244-45, 248-51 (correlating higher default rates in the
U.S. to the more sophisticated business skills required to participate in the
U.S. economy); Hylton, supra note 37, at 227 (pointing out the relatively
short-term investment of the typical business project financed by the Grameen
Bank). But see Mustafa A. Rahman et al., Grameen Bank in Employment Creation and
Poverty Alleviation, 4 The Bangladesh Pub. Admin. J. 52, 65-66 (1990) (giving a
breakdown of the types of projects financed by the Grameen Bank, including
longer-term processing and manufacturing, which accounted for 28% of total loans
during the period from 1976 to 1991).





n255.  See supra notes 142-161 and accompanying text. These findings might be
explained by the differences between the formality of the inner city economy and
the informality of the Bangladeshi village economy. Formality in this context
connotes at least more detailed business plans for a broader range of more
complex businesses. Alternatively, the U.S. findings may simply have been more
comprehensive and/or focused in tracking this issue.





n256.  Hung describes the former as character risk and the latter as project
risk; he too reaches the conclusion that the solidarity circle solves only for
the former risk. Hung, supra note 69, at 248-51. If U.S. programs follow the
lead of those U.S. organizations who have already experimented with the
solidarity circle, they will not enforce guarantees and thus will lose this
means of solving the informational gap. Alternatively, U.S. programs can follow
the Grameen Bank's lead in enforcing guarantees by circle members even if they
have not acquired the information necessary to screen and monitor a defaulting
borrower. I will discuss below some of the implications of such a system of
indigenous enforcement. See infra notes 321-328 and accompanying text. For now,
suffice it to say that U.S. programs must also then face the possibility of
importing the problems of debt recycling and systematic loss of savings that
result from the pressures faced by individual borrowers and their guarantors in
the context of such strict enforcement.





n257.  See supra note 158 and accompanying text. This conclusion is also borne
out by the number of U.S. microlenders who choose not to lend to even low-income
people. See supra note 107 and accompanying text.





n258.  In particular, the Microcredit Summit ought to be concerned about these
findings. See Microcredit Summit Campaign, supra note 83. The founder of the
Grameen Bank, whose original goal was to reach the poorest of the poor, should
be concerned about these findings, as well. See Yunus, supra note 36, at 40-42.





n259.  A few legal and non-legal scholars have recognized this transfer, though
at least some of them have not appeared to consider the impact of such a
transfer on the borrower's ability to maintain a small business. See Jaffer,
supra note 5, at 205 ("Another weakness of the solidarity lending model is its
transfer of risk from the lender to the borrowing group."); Hung, supra note 69,
at 240 (acknowledging the costs of participating in a group lending program);
Stiglitz, supra note 118, at 353 ("The members of the borrowing groups in the
Grameen Bank bear risks that, in the absence of the monitoring problem, could
much better be absorbed by the bank... They have been induced to bear more risks
than they otherwise would.").





n260.  It bears underscoring that, in a properly functioning commercial market,
these costs are typically either borne by the lender, or by the borrower in the
form of higher interest rates or more stringent requirements concerning
collateral, and business-related covenants and representations. Although the
mainstream borrower must collateralize its loan with physical assets, this more
passive form of collateralization does not typically require the active expense
of time that the solidarity circle requires.





n261.  Jaffer recognizes that such risk would be better borne by the lender
because the lender is more "diversified" and the borrowers, many of whom are
operating at a "subsistence level," are more risk averse. Jaffer, supra note 5,
at 205. However, he does not consider the consequences of accepting such a risk
on the borrowers' businesses.





n262.  See Rahman et al., supra note 254, at 56-57 (describing the added cost to
Grameen Bank participants of the mandatory training period, weekly meetings,
group fund account and emergency fund). Hung hints at this possibility in his
comparative study of microlending programs in the U.S. and developing countries.
Hung, supra note 69, at 240.





n263.  See, e.g., United States v. Jon-T Chems., Inc., 768 F.2d 686, 690 (5th
Cir. 1985), cert. denied, 475 U.S. 1011 (1986) (citations omitted) ("Under the
doctrine of limited liability, the owner of a corporation is not liable for the
corporation's debts. Creditors of the corporation have recourse only against the
corporation itself, not against its parent company or shareholders. It is on
this assumption that "large undertakings are rested, vast enterprises are
launched, and huge sums of capital attracted.'"); Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v.
National Distillers & Chem. Corp., 483 F.2d 1098, 1102 (5th Cir. 1973), modified
per curiam, 490 F.2d 916 (5th Cir. 1974) ("Basic to the theory of corporation
law is the concept that a corporation is a separate entity, a legal being having
an existence separate and distinct from that of its owners."). See generally
Harry G. Henn & John R. Alexander, Laws of Corporations 73 (3d ed. 1983). This
trend has continued with the introduction of limited liability companies in all
50 states. See George G. Yearsich et al., Securities Law Aspects of
Partnerships, LLCs and LLPs 824, 862 (2004).

   Kenneth Anderson has recognized this problem in the microcredit context. He
notes:



   The use of joint and several liability whether in a strictly legal sense,
under written contract, or in a practical sense, as in making a borrower's
circle jointly and severally liable for debts of the group as a condition of new
loans, runs in some sense exactly opposite the direction of enterprise law in
such places as the United States. Indeed, the trend in the United States has
been to allow a wider range of entities to operate with limited liability of
owners from demands of their creditors through such trends as the development of
limited liability companies.

 Anderson, supra note 35, at 107. Jaffer hints at this limitation in concluding
that the "tradeoff" from microlending "is that a borrower whose project is
succeeding may not have complete incentives to increase the return of her
project, if losses on other group members' projects are expected to outweigh any
possible returns on her own project." Jaffer, supra note 5, at 204.





n264.  It is certainly possible in mainstream transactions to compromise limited
liability in the face of greater lender comfort, through the device of personal
guarantees by directors and other means. It is important to note, however, that
such compromises are the exception rather than the rule.

planning and implementing micro level development decisions.").

n281.  My point here hinges on my assumption that would-be male entrepreneurs
are extensively excluded from market participation too. If the cause of market
failure in the inner city is societal discrimination against women, then a focus
on women as lending targets may be more appropriate. See Anderson, supra note
35, at 98-99 (discussing market irrationality in the form of gender
discrimination in developing countries). Indeed, such a focus is likely more
appropriate at higher levels of income, where men are able to access the market
more freely. However, while I do not have data on this point, I suspect that the
cause of market failure among the very poor, while partly attributable to gender
discrimination, goes deeper - resulting in the exclusion of women and men alike.
Moreover, if the rationale for targeting women is to level the playing field,
then current programmatic efforts must acknowledge that they are not providing a
silver bullet for poverty reduction.





n282.  Again, I do not intend this argument to challenge the contentions of
those courts and legal scholars who have targeted (and would consider targeting)
women in order to compensate them for past discrimination or to level the
playing field. For discussions of the debate concerning similar/different
treatment of women, see generally Kahn v. Shevin, 416 U.S. 351 (1974); Judith
Olans Brown et al., The Failure of Gender Equality: An Essay in Constitutional
Dissonance, 36 Buff. L. Rev. 573 (1987).

n302.  The CED movement's discourse on formality is not nearly as developed as
that of the Law and Development movement. To my knowledge, the CED movement has
not incorporated the term "Rule of Law" in its discourse, nor has it really
defined the theoretical importance of laws and legal systems to the practice of
CED. Nonetheless, formality does seem to have some theoretical importance to
CED. For example, Professor Simon has commented on the importance of "personal
formality," which includes the ability to read balance sheets and to follow
Robert's Rules of Order in the conduct of meetings, as a means of "imposing
structure on relations." Simon, supra note 5, at 424-25. See generally Posner,
supra note 245 (discussing from a Law and Economics perspective the wealth
maximizing behaviors of "primitive" societies, concluding that such behaviors
are less efficient than those of "advanced" societies). Perhaps the closest
analogy to de Soto's work overseas is Jane Larson's proposal for "regularizing"
colonias in U.S./Mexico border towns. See Jane E. Larson, Informality,
Illegality, and Inequality, 20 Yale L. & Pol'y. Rev. 137, 140 (2002). For
purposes of my analysis in this section, I will use the rhetoric of the Rule of
Law, as defined by the Law and Development movement, but with the expectation
that some of the purposes of the Rule of Law are also important to broad
segments of the CED and Law and Economics movements.





n303.  With this claim, I am not arguing that there is no place for informality
in development efforts that seek to increase market participation. Nor, in fact,
do I disagree with the Bank's original goal, which involved the creation of
informal collaborative efforts as a means for preparing borrowers for formal
market interaction with those operating outside of the Grameen structure.
Rather, my point here is that the Bank's actual use of informality undermines
this goal both by interfering with borrowers' relations with outside market
participants and by leveraging informal competition rather than collaboration.





n304.  See supra notes 143-151 and accompanying text.





n305.  I am not arguing here that informality presents a conflict because it
jeopardizes the formality of our entire legal system. Rather, as I discuss
below, even where courts are a last resort, the informality of devices like the
behavioral conditions and the solidarity circle conflict with the more
well-defined contractual conditions that typify mainstream business
relationships. Thus, while informal behaviors could be seen as reducing
transaction costs in very local (i.e., informal) markets, these same behaviors
might serve as entry barriers to participation in more mainstream markets.





n306.  See Ohnesorge, supra note 295, at 99-100.





n307.  De Soto, supra note 295, at 40-46.





n308.  Id. at 41.





n309.  See supra notes 290-291, 295-299 and accompanying text. Again, in this
section, I refrain from discussing whether such efficiency is sought by the
target population. See discussion infra Parts IV.C, V.





n310.  In mentioning written (as opposed to oral) contracts here, I acknowledge
the tension between some of Law and Development's expectations concerning the
rule of law and formalization and the reality of literacy rates in Bangladesh
and other areas where the rule of law has been exported. I begin to address this
tension in Part VI. Simply put, the target population may not value the rule of
law. That, of course, has consequences for the success of any development
program. In this section, however, I take the structural goal of formal
participation at face value and evaluate the Bank's ability to meet that goal.

recitation of the Sixteen Decisions. Rahman, supra note 15, at 89-91. My
analysis here does not cover this aspect of the behavioral program, largely
because I wish to focus on the impact of this program on the most formal aspects
of the loan transaction. To the extent that the weekly meetings are considered

n315.  Some might counter that precedent for this type of contractual
relationship arguably already exists in this country in the form of welfare
applications, which require certain uses of grant money, prohibit certain
behaviors, and so on. Others have commented extensively on this type of
behavioral conditioning in the context of welfare. For example, Professor Lucy
Williams critiques two popular behavior modification models of welfare reform in
the 1980s. Lucy A. Williams, The Ideology of Division: Behavior Modification
Welfare Reform Proposals, 102 Yale L. J. 719, 721 (1992). Specifically, Williams
points out that Wisconsin's "Learnfare" statute is based on faulty premises
about the relationship between social problems such as truancy and welfare to
the extent that it originally conditioned welfare eligibility for teenage
mothers on regular school attendance (and the program has, in fact, failed to
increase school attendance or reduce the dropout rate). Id. at 726-37. With
respect to the truancy problem, Williams also contrasts the relationship the
government has with welfare and non-welfare recipients: Non-welfare recipients
receive a tax break for each dependent regardless of truancy. Id. at 734-35. See
generally Linda C. McClain, "Irresponsible" Reproduction, 47 Hastings L. J. 339
(1996) (finding that current models of welfare reform reflect "a problematic
gender ideology and troublesome stereotypes about people in poverty, and rely
upon reductive accounts of human motivation in the area of reproductive
behavior"). Other examples include subsidized housing programs that regulate
tenant behavior. See, e.g., 42 U.S.C. 13661 (2005) ("[A] public housing agency
or an owner of federally assisted housing, as determined by the Secretary, shall
establish standards that prohibit admission to the program or admission to
federally assisted housing for any household with a member who the public
housing agency or owner determines is illegally using a controlled
substance...."). Whatever one's position on the validity of behavior
modification in the ongoing debates about welfare, such social engineering seems
a better fit for regulatory practices than private contracts.





n316.  Conditions in mainstream loan agreements typically require certain
business-related occurrences prior to loan disbursement. Such conditions provide
little precedent for imposing non-business-related behavioral requirements. For
example, in standard loan forms, typical conditions focus on such financial
events as late payment or bankruptcy. See, e.g., James C. Van Horne, Financial
Market Rates and Flows 111 (2d ed. 1984). An exception might be the requirement
of personal guarantees or use of personal assets to fully collateralize business
loans.





n317.  If, on the other hand, these conditions could be proven to reduce the
loan risk to the lender, then they might be justifiable as a means of
eliminating the lender's transaction costs. However, the Bank's social
conditioning has not been, nor can it readily be, justified on these grounds.





n318.  It is also questionable whether such conditions would be legally
enforceable. In the welfare context, the Supreme Court has struck down
legislation that sanctioned the conditioning of benefits on behavior
modification rules, such as the "suitable home" and "man in the house" rules
limiting women's sexual and reproductive behavior and disqualifying families for
the mother's suspected immorality. See King v. Smith, 392 U.S. 309, 321-27
(1968).

   Yet another questionable aspect of using social development as consideration
is the issue of whether such consideration is really voluntary, or whether it is
more akin to the type of "forced exchange" more typically imposed by money
lenders and which microcredit lenders seek to replace. See Johnson & Rogaly,
supra note 131, at 6.





n319.  See supra notes 96-97, 203-204 and accompanying text. The structure
chosen by U.S. microlenders might very well be an answer to some of the concerns
I have raised here. In this respect, then, U.S.. microlending programs might be
distinguishable from non-practitioners in the U.S. who admire the Grameen Bank's
program. The former may have concluded that the type of raw conditioning
attempted by the Grameen Bank is simply inappropriate in the U.S. inner city.
Perhaps this should implicate its appropriateness in Bangladesh, too. It is
particularly to the non-practitioners, then, that I address my analysis
concerning formality in transactions.





n320.  See supra notes 204-205 and accompanying text.





n321.  This more business focused training is, however, more justifiable as a
loan condition to the extent that it serves to reduce the lender's risk. It does
not solve the borrower's entry problems.





n322.  Jaffer, supra note 5, at 201-03.





n323.  See supra notes 37-39 and accompanying text.





n324.  As Kenneth Anderson states, "there is a certain irony in the dependence
of microcredit, at least in some instances, on thoroughly non-market forms of
obligation, rather than the classic capitalist notion of legally enforceable
contract, as the mechanism of repayment." Anderson, supra note 35, at 107.





n325.  In addition, there appears to be no assurance that new borrowers have the
benefit of simple, consistent, easily enforceable rules with which to comply
within a circle. Thus, as was found by Rahman, the circle might employ more
factional decision-making that, even if it did employ a code of family honor
rather than a business-related code, would not follow its own code consistently.
See supra notes 170-174 and accompanying text. I am not suggesting, here, that
one code is better than the other, but rather that a more formal code would be
more easily and obviously enforceable by outside institutions.





n326.  Yunus, supra note 36, at 70.





n327.  Cao, supra note 5, at 892-917. See generally Kennedy, supra note 144
(arguing that the "informal" sector can be sufficiently stable - "economically
productive," and capable of "security, transparency and reliability" for
effective participation by those who are in that sector).





n328.  See supra notes 175-181 and accompanying text.





n329.  This, then, would be an interim solution at best. One risk would be that
it would be used indefinitely, thereby returning us to the problem of having
created a marginal market for the poor. Another risk would be that this
particular type of informal behavior would not be a good stepping stone to the
mainstream market, as will be discussed further below. Thus, assuming that a
certain amount of controlled informality might be appropriate as a transitional
device, this particular use of social collateral might not be.





n330.  This concern seems particularly relevant, considering the possibility
that such conditioning could be perceived as a double standard imposed on the
poor in the context of loan transactions, but not on mainstream businesses
receiving benefits such as the depreciation deduction. Query whether such an
alternative credit market would impair microentrepreneurs' participation in
their product and service markets as well. The theory here would be that the
costs of doing business informally in the market for credit and formally in the
market for products or services would be too high.





n331.  Indeed, these conditions run the risk of creating a false sense of
participation which could not be sustained in the mainstream economy.





n332.  Indeed, Kenneth Anderson theorizes that this is exactly the function many
microlenders may be serving, a function which they need to acknowledge
explicitly. He adds:



   The rationale for microcredit would have to be that the welfare subsidy
offered is more efficiently used to subsidize the business, rather than simply
directly granting the same aid for purposes of direct consumption because, even
if the microbusiness cannot fully cover its costs, it can generate profits that
create a net utility greater than a direct consumption subsidy alone would.
(These net utilities might, and typically do, include intangible utilities in
the form of greater training and expertise and ability to engage in other forms
of economic activity; they may include such things as learning how to manage
money or rudimentary bookkeeping or other skills.)

 Anderson, supra note 35, at 97. See also Servon, supra note 20, at 127
(commenting that, in the U.S., the "success of these programs derives from their
provision of a wide range of resources - through networks, training, and support
- that include but are not limited to credit"). These are the net utilities,
however, that the Grameen Bank's informal approach fails to capture.





n333.  The broader question for U.S. practitioners, especially lawyers, is what
gains they think are achieved by formalizing transactions. In other words, by
practicing corporate law on behalf of the poor, are lawyers helping
micro-entrepreneurs reach the market (and if so, of course, which market)? Here,
there appears to be a strong assumption that a direct transfer of lawyering
skills will suffice as an aid to the poor - again, that formality is good and
important. See, e.g., Jones, supra note 8, at 208-18 (describing the legal
services provided by her law school's transactional lawyering clinic to small
and microentrepreneurs, including advice about choice of entity, tax law,
licenses and permits, contract drafting, insurance, and intellectual property).
See generally Jones, supra note 80 (detailing the ways in which lawyers can
contribute to microenterprise development efforts). While such lawyering for the
poor may indeed be the best form of aid we can provide, this assumption too must
be tested.





n334.  Indeed, the failure of indigenousness may have been the single greatest
cause of the crisis undergone by the Law and Development movement in the 1970s.
It was a key moment of progress in development efforts abroad when that movement
recognized that a "one size fits all" development package created in, and
modeled on, the United States was systematically failing when exported to the
Third World. See infra notes 340-342 and accompanying text.

n344.  In addition, the use of the solidarity circle in particular leads us to
assume that informal and indigenous norms are captured, better yet leveraged, in
the lending process. According to this reasoning, whatever the cultural norms of
the particular target population are (whether saving face, valorization of the
collective, and so on), such norms will be the basis of peer pressure in the
context of the loan transaction.





n345.  See Simon, supra note 5, at 62-67 (suggesting that republican political
thought gives a political cast to the defining themes of CED, including that of
local economic self-sufficiency advanced by microcredit and other CED programs).





n346.  See William E. Forbath, Caste, Class, and Equal Citizenship, 98 Mich. L.
Rev. 1, 20 (1999). Forbath observes that: "To Madison or Jefferson, the
socioeconomic key to individual freedom and citizenly independence was ownership
of productive property, and at various times both men said citizens had a right
to sufficient property upon which to work to support themselves and their
families and championed broad distributive policies on that basis." Id. at 14.
Forbath points out that in his Draft Constitution for Virginia, Jefferson
included a provision that ""Every person of full age...shall be entitled to an
appropriation of 50 acres...in full and absolute dominion.'" Id. at 14 n.58
(citing Jefferson's Draft Constitution for Virginia). Forbath also notes
Jefferson's statement that the ""fundamental right to labour,' as it belongs to
the unemployed poor, may trump the property rights of large landholders." Id.
See also Mark E. Brandon, Home on the Range: Family and Constitutionalism in
American Continental Settlement, 52 Emory L.J. 645, 665 (2003) (describing
Thomas Jefferson as "a progenitor of a strand of American ethos known as
agrarian republicanism"). Hoke describes civic republicanism as a theory that
"conceives of individuals as fundamentally situated - located in families,
communities, and specific cultures - rather than isolated and atomistic
abstractions bereft of temporal and spatial locus...." S. Candice Hoke,
Preemption Pathologies and Civic Republican Values, 71 B.U. L. Rev. 687, 704
(1991). She continues: "Civic republicanism is committed to principles of civic
virtue, open-minded deliberation, substantive political equality, and
participatory citizenship." Id.

   For a brief yet illuminating critique of civic republicanism and its
traditional roots, see generally Linda K. Kerber, The Republican Civic
Tradition: Making Republicanism Useful, 97 Yale L.J. 1663 (1988). Kerber
discusses traditional civic republicanism's "tendency to homogeneity and the
tyranny of the majority as well as liberalism's tendency to enshrine private
property rights." Id. at 1665. Kerber remarks that "classical republican
tradition assumed that deliberation was possible only in small and exclusive
communities; the absence of the dependent classes - defined by race, gender, and
property - was essential to the republican view of the world, not an easily
correctable accident." Id.

n373.  Here I am making a number of claims. First, it is easier for the
experimenter to disassociate himself from the subject when that subject is
different in gender. This disassociation may also occur with respect to race, or
gender and race. Both postcolonial and feminist scholars have described this
process, often referring to it as "othering." See, e.g., Mohanty, supra note
365, at 51-80. Second, the claim that the choice of women as a target population
leads to greater social investment in this group is actually a veiled means by
which to disinvest in the process of truly indigenous development, the latter of
which is at least threatening, if not financially disadvantageous, to the
majority population. Taub writes:



   Historically, the South, in general, invested relatively little in education,
because to do so would ultimately undermine the low wage structure which the
wealthy perceived was necessary for them to maintain their positions. In that
kind of setting, local elites are unlikely to support programs which encourage
independence and opportunity for the low income people in their communities.

 Taub, supra note 61, at 10. Third, simply put, this comfort stems from a
patronizing attitude. See generally Brown et al., supra note 355 (discussing
state protective legislation for women workers as a product of patronizing
assumptions about pregnant women).

n375.  See supra notes 219-224 and accompanying text. Although Rahman's figures
are quite compelling in establishing a link between the Bank's programs and
further marginalization of women, additional investigation into issues of
causation is certainly warranted.





n376.  And, indeed, the empirical studies of U.S. programs show that those that
target women often describe themselves as training-focused and are quite
resource-intensive. See supra notes 225-227 and accompanying text.





n377.  The full implications of a hybrid model are too complex to be addressed
in this Article. Although the implications of hybridity have been
under-researched, a number of scholars and practitioners have begun to question
the extent of transferability. See, e.g., Servon, supra note 20, at 18
("Although it is encouraging that U.S. policymakers have begun to look outside
U.S. borders for ways to combat persistent poverty, differences in economic,
political, and social contexts between the developed and developing worlds
deeply affect the potential and limits of the microenterprise strategy for the
United States."); Talen et al., supra note 8, at 338 (concluding that the best
practices developed by microlenders overseas are of little use in the U.S.);
Taub, supra note 61, at 2 (discussing whether transferability can encompass the
"particular activities or practices, or the principles of the effort").





n378.  And of core dreams and myths - of greater economic security for women,
for example.





n379.  I should note here that I use the term hybridity quite differently from
the use of that term by postcolonialist scholars. In a section entitled
"Hybridity," The Post-Colonial Studies Reader states:



   Most post-colonial writing has concerned itself with the hybridized nature of
post-colonial culture as a strength rather than a weakness. Such writing focuses
on the fact that the transaction of the post-colonial world is not a one-way
process in which oppression obliterates the oppressed or the colonizer silences
the colonized in absolute terms. In practice it rather stresses the mutuality of
the process. It lays emphasis on the survival even under the most potent
oppression of the distinctive aspects of the culture of the oppressed, and shows
how these become an integral part of the new formations which arise from the
clash of cultures characteristic of imperialism. Finally, it emphasizes how
hybridity and the power it releases may well be seen to be the characteristic
feature and contribution of the post-colonial, allowing a means of evading the
replication of the binary categories of the past and developing new
anti-monolithic models of cultural exchange and growth.

 The Post-Colonial Studies Reader 183 (Bill Ashcroft et al. eds., 1995). In this
Article, I do not take such a hopeful view. Instead, I suggest that the
hybridity that has resulted here has particular characteristics that replicate
the more "monolithic" examples of cultural exchange that more recent development
efforts hope to avoid.

he earned his Ph.D).





n381.  Id. at 110. Approximately 85% of Bangladeshis are Muslim, though at least
one study has concluded that many Bangladeshi Muslims may not be orthodox.
Bornstein, supra note 9, at 161. The Bank's founder counters this argument as
follows: "Many Islamic scholars have also told us that the Shariah [Islamic
legal code] ban on the charging of interest cannot apply to Grameen, since the
Grameen borrower is also an owner of the bank." Yunus, supra note 36, at 110.
See also Bornstein, supra note 9, at 142 ("The Islamic injunction against
interest was, in real terms, a fantasy. Everyone knew that well-to-do villagers
who made a grand show of piety often doubled as moneylenders."); id. at 161
(describing the far less orthodox behavior of most Bangladeshi Muslims compared
to Muslims in Saudi Arabia). While many countries with Muslim majorities have
ignored this prohibition, see Ross Cranston, Credit, Security and Debt Recovery:
Law's Role in Reform in Asia and the Pacific, 39 St. Louis U. L.J. 759, 776
(1995), my point here is to question the level of cultural comfort with this
program rather than to raise a legal challenge.

Women (1995). For a broader anthropological and legal discussion of informal
market participation, see generally Rosemary Coombe, The Cultural Life Of
Things: Anthropological Approaches To Law And Society In Conditions Of
Globalization, 10 Am. U. J. Int'l L. & Pol'y 791 (1995).





n386.  See Cao, supra note 5, at 921-22 ("Although state-subsidized entities,
such as community development banks, may succeed in emulating some of the
benefits of rotating credit associations, the very involvement of the state
itself may result in a distortion of the particular mix of community,
informality, and flexibility that gives such entities their greatest comparative
advantage.").





n387.  See id. at 874-85 (describing how RCAs function).





n388.  See id. at 907 ("While formal institutional lending operates on the
premise that lenders and borrowers are disaggregated entities likely resulting
in high transaction costs for lenders, [RCAs] work only if "lenders and
borrowers' constitute a single entity with convergent commitments.").
Importantly, Cao notes that it is this "aggregation of interests" that "produces
an institutional structure that acts as a disincentive against defection or
default and also against abuse...by the group against its individual members."
Id. at 908 (emphasis added). If Professor Cao is right, then this indigenous
limit on group pressure is also lost in the Grameen Bank's institutionalization.





n389.  Id. at 882-84; Taub, supra note 61, at 6-7 (describing the Good Faith
Fund's experience in Arkansas, where the peer lending approach, tried in a
community without "strong preexisting social ties," failed).





n390.  Professor Cao discusses this fact in detail, and uses it as a basis for
advocating that courts enforce the private rules established by RCAs. See Cao,
supra note 5, at 882, 892-917.

   My contention about the rigidity of the Bank's rules is disputed by the Bank.
The founder, for example, claims that "with each passing year the borrowers
assume more responsibilities for the management of their own affairs" and
develop "more innovative approaches to preventing and solving problems." Yunus,
supra note 36, at 66.





n391.  Professor Cao suggests that this is precisely the reason that RCAs are
here to stay. While community development banks, for example, are "too
institutionalized and too formal" to have developed a "systematic
self-sustaining methodology," RCAs are "completely self-sustaining and
self-funding." Cao, supra note 5, at 920-21.





n392.  See id. at 905-06. These important differences underlie the RCAs' truer
indigenousness, contrasted with the Grameen Bank's institutionalized
indigenousness. Thus, the RCAs likely do have the advantage noted by Professor
Cao of protecting and maintaining local markets. Id. at 906-07.





n393.  See supra note 339 and accompanying text.





n394.  See supra note 370 and accompanying text. Furthermore, even if these
directives were entirely indigenous, their imposition in the context of a
financial transaction is, of course, not.





n395.  Kenneth Anderson suggests this possibility by asking whether microcredit
might "run the risk of distorting local capital and credit markets
in...damaging, and often unanticipated, ways." Anderson, supra note 35, at 95.
Anderson, however, appears to conclude that, in many places where microcredit
programs operate, there really is no market for "commercial capital," thereby
reducing this risk. Id. at 96. In my view, Anderson's focus on commercial
capital is too narrow.





n396.  There is a vibrant discussion among scholars and practitioners who work

generally Cummings, supra note 54; McFarlane, supra note 1, at 298, 301, 306.





n397.  In the context of importation, of course, the Grameen Bank's
institutionalization of indigenous norms is only the first in a series. As U.S.
microlenders have begun to import the Grameen Bank model, further
institutionalizations have occurred, analogies have been drawn, and
reinterpretations of aspects of the model have been made. One example is the
transformation of the solidarity circle from a guarantee relationship based on
cultural notions of shame into a forum for business discussions and training.

n400.  Indeed, Audrey McFarlane has argued that the very notion of development
is a "conservative principle" that "prioritizes or addresses social problems
only to the extent the problem can be transformed into one with an exchange
value and thereby exhibits the potential for private profit." McFarlane, supra
note 1, at 300.





n401.  Here, I am referring to both the Grameen Bank and U.S. microlenders as

n406.  Unfortunately, sorting through the consequences of hybridization could be
quite challenging. If the model were truly indigenous to the West, perhaps it
would have worked better here (though the independent problems of market failure
and formalization suggest otherwise). But the model is a hybrid, and one that
has in fact been altered to fit local conditions in the U.S. Thus a diagnosis of
its failure in any given location will have to inquire into whether the failure
is a result of a lack of indigenousness, a faulty adaptation, or entirely
different flaws. I am indebted to Dan Danielsen for raising this set of issues.





n407.  In other words, if informality and indigenousness are simply devices in
the service of non-indigenous goals, at the very least, we should examine
whether the same concerns expressed by Trubek and Galanter are also applicable
to the Grameen Bank model. See Trubek & Galanter, supra note 293, at 1080-93
(listing as causes of the crisis in Law and Development the "ethnocentric and
naive aspects of the model," its possible irrelevance, its non-neutrality,
doubts about universality, skepticism about policy motives, and a "loss of
faith" in legal liberalism, among others). As I discuss in the following
section, it should be useful to the CED movement to review these concerns
carefully.





n408.  Indeed, Audrey McFarlane emphasizes the importance of looking beyond each
inner city to the entire city. McFarlane, supra note 1, at 327. Adding to the
complication of translation is the notion of the "global city," where there may
in fact be immigrants from cultures that may have used traditional RCAs. For
discussions of the global city, see generally Peter Marcuse & Ronald D. van
Kempen, Globalizing Cities: A New Spatial Order? (2000); Saskia Sassen, The
Global City: New York, London, Tokyo (1991).





n409.  This is not completely uncharted territory. Some scholars have already
begun to discuss development in a more comparative sense. See, e.g., Cao, supra
note 5, at 850-51 (discussing the similarity of the vicious cycle of poverty in
undeveloped urban areas in the U.S. and in developing countries); McFarlane,
supra note 1, at 303 (comparing development in poor communities in the U.S. with
international development efforts). These discussions typically make more
general references to similarities in development strategies rather than
comparing such strategies in depth.





n410.  See Trubek & Galanter, supra note 293, at 1090 (describing how "empirical
knowledge of the third world" created a "glaring discrepancy between their

n411.  See, e.g., Int'l Labour Office Geneva, World Labour Report: Industrial

n412.  Among other reasons, this lens seems as appropriate to this endeavor as,

post-colonial lens might serve to elucidate, or that such a lens would provide
valuable information about the workability of a particular development effort.
Although some might resist the notion that a post-colonial lens would be

n415.  In addition, I mean to suggest that the lessons that the Western
development community can learn from its experiences with the Grameen Bank model
are lessons about globalization. In important respects, globalization redefines
the "local" as well as, of course, the global. As the technologies of
globalization facilitate transferability, development thinkers must dig deeper,
and dig differently, in order to understand how best to answer the needs of
those who are marginalized by the effects of globalization.





n416.  See, e.g., Barbara P. Thomas, Politics, Participation and Poverty:

n417.  Austin describes street vending as a "microcosm of black

of security, they might be able to pursue opportunities to expand or to invest

supported in such endeavors.

                                US Official News

                           February 24, 2015 Tuesday

Rural Development Regulations-Update to FmHA References and to Census References

LENGTH: 61764  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Federal Register, Government of USA has issued the following news
release:


Action

Direct Final Rule.
Summary

Rural Development (RD) is amending its regulations by updating references to the
Farmers Home Administration (FmHA) and clarifying and updating references to the
census data. These actions will provide consistency in terminology between
program regulations. In addition, clarifying and updating references to census
data is needed to account for changes to the decennial Census, which, starting
with the 2010 decennial Census is no longer reporting income and unemployment
data. Additional revisions are being implemented to show the regulations that do
not apply to the Farm Service Agency (FSA) and to remove outdated or unnecessary
language.
Unified Agenda
Allocation Formulas

This rule will become effective April 27, 2015 without further action unless the
Agency receives significant written adverse comments or written notices of
intent to submit adverse comments on or before March 26, 2015. If the Agency
receives significant adverse comments or notices, the Agency will publish a
timely notice in the Federal Register withdrawing those provisions on which
adverse comment were received.
